## Chapter 4 — Public Places, Private Panic By the time Thursday rolled around, the blood emoji had become a joke you could buy. Someone—probably Josh Ward, because he had the entrepreneurial spirit of a rat—was selling “🩸🩸🩸” stickers for £1 a sheet out of his blazer pocket at break. People were putting them on planners, water bottles, the back of toilet doors. Someone had drawn three little drops on the whiteboard in maths and Mr Patel had sighed like he’d aged ten years in one lesson. Asha watched it happen like she was underwater. Every time her phone buzzed, her body reacted before her brain: a tightness in the chest, a cold drop in the stomach, a flush up her neck. She started leaving her phone face down in lessons like it was an animal that might bite. She couldn’t leave it off, though. Not properly. That felt like walking into traffic with your eyes shut. At lunch, they met in the same strip behind the maths block, because rituals were comforting even when they were stupid. Theo had dark shadows under his eyes. Connor looked like he’d slept, technically, but only because he’d passed out from exhaustion rather than peace. Mina’s eyeliner was sharper than ever, like she’d applied it with fury. Connor said, “Right. The bus. Why the bus?” Mina leaned back against the wall, arms folded. “Because it’s public. Because she thinks we won’t do anything in public. She’s right.” Asha stared at the ground. She’d been googling blood donation buses at three in the morning like a normal person. The NHS one came to town once a month and parked outside the big supermarket because it was the only place with a car park that didn’t require a sacrifice to enter. Theo whispered, “What if it’s not her?” Mina’s eyes narrowed. “Who else would it be?” Theo’s hands twitched at his sides. “I don’t know. Someone who… someone who hates us.” Connor’s laugh was brittle. “That’s a long list, mate.” Asha forced herself to speak. “We don’t have to do anything. We can just… go and look. See if anyone’s there. We’re not bringing anything.” Connor glanced at her. “We’re not bringing anything *yet*, you mean.” Asha’s cheeks burned. She hated that they all knew, now, about her message, about the way she’d tried to steer it. She hated that she deserved it. Mina said, “What about your old phone?” to Theo. Theo flinched. “I couldn’t— I didn’t—” Connor cut in, “He didn’t bring it.” Theo’s face crumpled. “My mum came into my room and started asking why I was ‘off’ and then she went through my drawers because she thinks I vape and—” Mina scoffed. “Do you vape?” Theo looked offended. “No. I just look like someone who vapes.” “Accurate,” Connor muttered, but there was no bite in it. Asha’s throat tightened. “So we have nothing to bring even if we wanted to.” Mina’s gaze flicked to Asha’s face. “You’re relieved.” Asha opened her mouth, then shut it. She was relieved. She was also terrified that relief meant something about her. They agreed to meet after school at the corner shop by the supermarket—Asha refused to say “outside the donation bus” like it was a plan rather than a looming humiliation. The day crawled. In history, someone turned around and whispered, “Did you get the blood text?” with a grin like it was gossip about a celebrity. Asha said, flatly, “No,” and hated how convincing she sounded. At 3:20, she told Mum she was going to the library. “You are going to the library?” Mum repeated, suspicious, like “library” was a slang term for “doing crimes.” “Yes,” Asha lied. “With… Mina.” Mina’s name worked like a badge of legitimacy. Mina’s mum would probably report their exact book choices to the council. Mum sighed. “Be back for dinner. And don’t go near that canal. They’ve been talking about it on the radio.” Asha’s stomach lurched. “The radio?” “The radio,” Mum said, turning to straighten a shelf of crisps. “People have nothing better to do. There’s always some nonsense. Just come home.” Asha nodded too hard. “Yeah. Of course.” Outside, the air was damp and cold in that late-autumn way that got under your clothes. Connor was already by the trolley bay, hands shoved deep in his pockets, trying to look like he wasn’t waiting. Theo arrived, breathless, hair too neat. Mina arrived last, hood up, tote bag swinging. None of them spoke for a moment. The supermarket doors whooshed open and shut. A man pushed a trolley full of Red Bull and frozen chips like he was preparing for war. Somewhere, a child screamed. “Right,” Connor said, forcing brightness. “Let’s go donate blood. Bit of civic duty.” Mina shot him a look. “Don’t.” “Sorry,” Connor said immediately, and then, quieter, “Sorry.” They walked across the car park as if it was the longest distance any of them had ever travelled. The bus was there: a big white vehicle with NHS branding and cheerful posters of smiling people holding plasters. A volunteer in a hi-vis vest stood by the steps handing out leaflets. A queue of mostly older people waited, chatting like it was a normal errand. Asha’s heart hammered. It was so ordinary it felt unreal, like someone had photoshopped their panic into someone else’s day. Theo muttered, “This is… insane.” Connor whispered, “Maybe the blood emojis were just… advertising.” Mina deadpanned, “Yes. Because nothing sells blood donation like terrorising teenagers.” Asha’s phone buzzed in her pocket. She didn’t take it out. She could feel it vibrating against her thigh like a pulse. They hovered near the trolley bay pretending to check their phones. Asha watched the bus steps. Watched faces. Tried to spot someone who looked like a threat. Leah wasn’t subtle when she appeared. She didn’t burst out of nowhere. She simply walked across the car park with the steady pace of someone going to work. Hair scraped back. Practical coat. Work trainers. She carried a paper coffee cup. She looked tired in a way that made Asha suddenly aware that Leah had been dealing with the aftermath for a year, every day, while Asha had been revising for exams and pretending she wasn’t thinking about it. Leah’s eyes found them immediately. No hesitation. No scanning. Like she’d been looking at them already, in her head, for months. Connor’s shoulders tensed. “That’s her,” he whispered. Mina’s face went still. Theo made a small sound, like a swallowed gasp. Asha’s mouth went dry. She felt frozen and furious at herself for freezing. Leah stopped a few metres away. Close enough that the smell of coffee reached them. She didn’t smile. She didn’t look dramatic. She looked like she’d run out of patience. “You lot,” she said. Connor attempted a laugh. “Alright, Leah.” Leah’s gaze flicked over him and dismissed him like he was background noise. Her eyes landed on Asha. Asha’s heart lurched. She hated being seen. “You declined my request,” Leah said. Asha swallowed. “I didn’t know it was you.” Leah’s mouth twitched, almost a smile and not at all. “Course you did.” Mina’s voice was sharp. “What do you want?” Leah looked at Mina, properly, like she’d noticed her presence now. “You,” she said. Then she looked back at Asha. “And you.” Theo shifted, trying to make himself smaller. Leah’s gaze flicked to him and sharpened. Theo’s voice came out thin. “We didn’t—” Leah cut him off. “Don’t,” she said, and it wasn’t a shout. It was worse: calm, like she’d heard every version of their denial already and none of them mattered. The volunteer by the bus called, cheerfully, “Next, please!” as if this was all a normal Tuesday. Connor stepped forward, trying to regain control with charm. “Look, we’re not doing this here.” Leah stared at him. “Why? Because there’s adults around? Because there’s cameras? Because it’s public?” Her eyes flicked to the bus. “You like public when it’s jokes and stickers.” Asha’s cheeks burned. She hated that Leah knew about the stickers. She hated that Leah knew anything. Mina said, low, “This is about Rowan.” Leah’s jaw tightened. For the first time, something moved behind her eyes—pain, maybe, or rage. “Yes,” she said. “It is.” Asha forced herself to speak. “Leah, if you’re the one sending the messages—” Leah’s laugh was short, humourless. “If?” She took a step closer. Asha could see the rawness at the edge of Leah’s mouth where she’d been chewing it. “You still doing that thing where you pretend you don’t know? Like it’s going to save you?” Asha’s throat tightened. “I don’t know what you want from us.” Leah looked at her for a long moment. Then she said, very quietly, “He still can’t hold a pen properly.” The car park noise didn’t stop. A trolley clattered. Someone beeped their car. A baby cried. But Asha felt like the world had shifted. Theo made a choked sound. Connor went very still. Mina’s face tightened, and for a second she looked younger than fifteen. Leah continued, voice flat. “He’s got exercises. Every day. Like it’s a job. He gets tired. He gets angry. And then he feels stupid for being angry because everyone says ‘at least you’re alive’ like that’s the whole point of living.” Asha’s eyes stung. She blinked hard, furious with herself for it. Leah’s gaze slid to Connor. “You remember him being funny? Loud? He doesn’t talk much now. Not because he can’t. Because he doesn’t want to. Because you lot made him—” She stopped. Her throat worked. She took a breath, like swallowing something sharp. Mina’s voice was rough. “We didn’t mean—” Leah snapped, finally, a crack in the calm. “I don’t care what you meant.” People in the queue glanced over. The volunteer frowned, uncertain. Connor put his hands up, palms out. “Alright. Alright. What do you want? Just— tell us.” Leah looked back at Asha. “You kept it,” she said, and the words landed with weight now, not creepiness. “You kept the messages. You kept the video. You kept the truth. You let them say it was an accident and you let him become a rumour.” Asha’s voice shook despite her efforts. “We didn’t keep—” Leah’s eyes narrowed. “Don’t lie to me. Not now. Not here.” She leaned in slightly. “You don’t get to tidy this up.” Asha felt something inside her—anger, shame—rise like bile. “I was trying to stop it getting worse!” Leah’s expression didn’t change. “For who?” Asha opened her mouth. No answer came. Leah stepped back. Her voice dropped again, controlled. “00:03,” she said. “Under the bridge. Bring what you stole.” Connor said, “No.” Leah’s gaze flicked to him. “Then don’t. Stay home. See what happens.” Theo whispered, “What happens?” Leah looked at him, and Asha saw something like disgust. “You’ll find out,” Leah said. Then she turned and walked away, coffee in hand, blending into the car park like she’d never been there. For a second they stood frozen. Then Mina breathed out. “Well,” she said. “That was… extremely clarifying.” Connor swore under his breath. “She’s mental.” Mina’s eyes flashed. “She’s grieving.” Connor’s jaw clenched. “She’s threatening us.” “She’s threatening you with the truth,” Mina shot back. “Different.” Theo’s voice was small. “We have to do something.” Asha’s phone buzzed. She pulled it out. Not a text. Instagram notifications. Josh Ward’s story had been updated. A new screenshot. A new red marker scrawl. 🩸🩸🩸. But this one was worse. It was Theo’s message from last year, timestamped, and beneath it a blurry still image: a flash-lit shape on the ground, someone’s leg bent wrong, someone laughing in the background. Asha felt her stomach drop through the tarmac. Theo made a strangled sound. “No. No, no, no.” Connor grabbed Asha’s phone and stared. His face drained. “That’s… that’s the video.” Mina’s voice went cold. “It’s out.” Asha’s hands shook. She took her phone back and scrolled, desperate, as if scrolling could undo it. Comments were already appearing. “omg” “is that rowan??” “wtf you lot are sick” “it was an accident leave them” “🩸🩸🩸” Asha’s vision blurred. She could taste metal in her mouth. Theo whispered, “My mum’s going to see.” Connor’s voice was tight. “We need to get ahead of it.” Mina laughed, sharp. “Ahead? We’re already behind. We’ve been behind for a year.” Asha stared at the still image on the screen. Her own message, her own plea not to ring anyone, had been turned into mockery. The thing she’d tried to bury was now being dug up by strangers with emojis. Her phone buzzed with a message request. Unknown number. Not emojis this time. Just: TOO LATE TO BE QUIET.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong craft in several key areas while maintaining the darkly comic British YA tone established in the plan. The writing successfully balances humor with genuine tension, creating an atmosphere where teenage anxiety feels both relatable and consequential. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Each character maintains their distinct voice and behavioral patterns established in the profiles. Asha's controlling tendencies manifest through her desperate attempts to manage the narrative ("We don't have to do anything. We can just... go and look"), while Connor deflects with increasingly brittle humor ("Right. Let's go donate blood. Bit of civic duty"). Mina's moral clarity cuts through the group's self-deception ("She's threatening you with the truth. Different"), and Theo's performative anxiety rings authentic. The dialogue feels natural and age-appropriate, avoiding both overly sophisticated language and forced slang. The setting work is excellent, grounding the supernatural-feeling threat in aggressively mundane reality. The blood donation bus becomes a perfect symbol of the story's central tension - something wholesome and civic-minded corrupted by the characters' guilt. The author skillfully uses environmental details (the volunteer with leaflets, the queue of pensioners, the screaming child) to create cognitive dissonance between the characters' internal panic and the world's indifference. Leah's introduction is masterfully handled. Rather than appearing as a hooded figure or dramatic antagonist, she arrives with "the steady pace of someone going to work," carrying coffee, looking tired. This grounds her in reality while making her more threatening - she's not performing menace, she's simply done with their evasions. Her revelation about Rowan's ongoing struggles ("He still can't hold a pen properly") lands with devastating effectiveness because it's specific, physical, and ongoing rather than abstract. The chapter's structure builds tension effectively, moving from the absurd commercialization of their trauma (blood emoji stickers) to the confrontation to the final revelation that their secret is already leaking. The pacing allows for both character moments and plot advancement without feeling rushed. The writing style maintains the established voice well, with observational humor that feels defensive rather than glib. Lines like "Someone—probably Josh Ward, because he had the entrepreneurial spirit of a rat" capture the narrator's sharp, slightly cruel wit while revealing character psychology. However, there are some minor weaknesses. Occasionally the internal narration becomes slightly overwrought ("Asha felt her stomach drop through the tarmac"), though this generally stays within acceptable bounds for YA fiction. Some transitions feel slightly abrupt, particularly the jump from the confrontation to checking Instagram, though this mirrors realistic teenage attention patterns. The chapter successfully advances both plot and character development while maintaining the story's central themes about truth, complicity, and the impossibility of containing consequences. It follows the established plan closely while allowing for organic character moments and realistic teenage behavior. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 5 — Who Gets to Tell the Story By Friday morning, the school had decided it was having an incident. You could tell because there were more adults in high-vis vests than usual and because the Headteacher stood at the gates smiling too hard, like she was greeting Ofsted and not a pack of teenagers with phones full of someone else’s worst night. Asha walked in with her stomach in a knot and her hood up until a prefect told her to take it down in the tone of someone who’d discovered authority last week and was drunk on it. “Uniform,” the prefect said, eyes flicking to Asha’s face like she expected blood drops to appear there. Asha forced her mouth into something that wasn’t a scowl. “Cheers.” “Don’t be rude,” the prefect snapped automatically, because teenagers. Asha went past, shoulders tight. Every few steps she caught her name in someone else’s mouth. Not shouted. Not confronted. Just the soft, delighted passing of it, like contraband. “—that’s her.” “—she was there.” “—saw her message.” In the corridor outside tutor, Josh Ward was holding court, phone in hand, grinning like he’d invented gossip. “It’s on private now,” he told a cluster of Year 10s, too loud. “You have to follow me. Proper exclusive.” Asha’s skin crawled. Mina was right. The scariest part wasn’t the midnight texts. It was that the story had become entertainment. Connor appeared at her side and muttered, “Ignore him.” Asha didn’t look at Connor. She couldn’t, not yet. She’d seen his face last night in the car park—angry, scared, protective—and she’d hated how much she wanted to hide behind it. Mina was already at the end of the corridor, arms folded, leaning against the wall like she was holding the building up through pure spite. Theo wasn’t there. Asha’s phone buzzed. Another DM. Tilly: ppl are saying u lot pushed him. is that true?? Asha stared at the message until the words stopped meaning anything and became a shape: accusation. She typed and deleted four different replies. *No* felt too thin. *It was an accident* felt like a lie, even if it wasn’t entirely. She put the phone in her pocket and walked to Mina. “Where’s Theo?” she asked. Mina’s eyes slid to Asha. “Avoiding being alive.” Connor said, “He texted me. His mum took his phone.” Mina’s mouth twisted. “Well. That’ll solve it, then.” Connor’s jaw tightened. “Can you not—” Before Mina could reply, Mr Durnham appeared, clipboard in hand, wearing the expression of someone trying not to panic in front of children. “Asha,” he said, too brightly. “Connor. Mina.” He glanced around. “Theo Mercer as well, when you see him.” Asha’s stomach dropped. “What—” “Don’t worry,” Mr Durnham said, which was how you knew you should worry. “We just need a quick chat. Come with me.” They followed him down the corridor. Heads turned. Whispering followed. Asha felt like she was walking naked. Mr Durnham led them into a small meeting room off the main office. There was a bowl of sweets on the table like someone had read a manual on How To Make Teenagers Confess and decided sugar was the key. Mrs Kline, the safeguarding lead, sat waiting. Her face was kind in the way of someone who’d seen too much. “Sit,” she said gently. Asha sat. Connor sat. Mina stayed standing for a second, then sat with exaggerated reluctance. Mr Durnham closed the door and stood by it like a bouncer. Mrs Kline folded her hands. “We’ve had reports,” she began, “of distressing messages being circulated and of images connected to an incident last summer.” Asha’s throat tightened. She kept her face blank. She could do blank. She’d practised. Connor said, “It’s not us sending it.” Mrs Kline nodded slowly. “We’re not here to accuse you of sending anything. We’re here to make sure everyone is safe. There are rumours of students being pressured to meet at the canal late at night.” Mina snorted. “Canal’s got more security warnings than the nuclear code.” Mr Durnham shot her a look. Mrs Kline didn’t react. She’d probably heard worse. “Asha,” Mrs Kline said, voice gentle, “did you receive any messages?” Asha’s instinct screamed: deny. Keep it contained. Don’t make it official. Official meant records. Records meant adults. Adults meant consequences that didn’t care about her intentions. She heard Leah’s voice in her head: *For who?* Asha swallowed. “Yes,” she said, quietly. Connor’s head snapped towards her. Mina’s eyes flicked, interested despite herself. Mrs Kline nodded. “Thank you for telling me. Can you show me?” Asha’s hands shook as she pulled out her phone. The bowl of sweets sat between them like an offering. She opened the texts. The emojis. The bridge photo. MEET WHERE YOU LEFT IT. YOU KEPT IT. Mrs Kline’s expression tightened, but she kept her voice calm. “Who do you think is sending these?” Asha’s mouth went dry. She could say Leah. She could say Rowan’s sister. She could point a finger and let the school do what the school did: contain, manage, protect itself. Connor spoke before she could. “We don’t know.” Mina said, flat, “Leah Bennett.” Connor hissed, “Mina—” Mina didn’t look at him. “It’s her. She wants us at the bridge at 00:03. She thinks we ‘stole’ something.” Mrs Kline leaned forward. “Leah Bennett? Rowan Bennett’s sister?” Asha felt her stomach drop. So they did know. They’d always known. It hadn’t been a secret. It had just been a thing adults filed away under *Handled.* Mr Durnham cleared his throat. “Leah is not a student here,” he said quickly. “So it’s— it’s not within our—” “Within your what?” Mina snapped. “Your jurisdiction? Your little email bubble?” Connor’s voice was sharp. “Mina, stop.” Mina’s eyes flashed at Connor. “Why? Because you’re scared of your dad? Because you’re scared of consequences? Newsflash: Rowan already got consequences.” The room went very still. Mrs Kline’s face softened, and that softness made Asha feel worse. “Mina,” she said quietly, “I understand you’re angry. But we need to keep this calm.” Mina laughed under her breath. “Sure.” Mrs Kline turned back to Asha. “Asha, can you tell me what ‘you kept it’ might refer to?” Asha’s mind flashed: Theo’s old phone. The video. The drafted “what we say” message. Her own frantic text telling them not to ring. Asha looked at the bowl of sweets. A fun-size Mars Bar sat on top, wrapper gleaming. The absurdity of it made her throat burn. Connor said, “Nothing. It’s just— it’s just to scare us.” Mrs Kline held Connor’s gaze. “Connor. I need honesty.” Connor’s jaw worked. He looked suddenly seventeen in a room with adults, the bravado stripped away. “It’s about… last summer,” he said. “About Rowan.” Mr Durnham’s shoulders stiffened. “We’re not revisiting—” Mina cut in, voice low. “We never visited it properly in the first place.” Asha’s chest tightened. In her head she saw the canal path, the flash of phone lights, Rowan on the ground making a sound like he was trying not to scream, Connor swearing, Theo filming, Mina yelling to ring someone, Asha saying *don’t ring, don’t ring* because she could already see the headlines and the parents and the police. She’d thought she was being responsible. She’d been being scared. Mrs Kline said, “Did you go to the canal last night?” Asha shook her head. “No.” Connor nodded. “No.” Mina hesitated, then said, “No.” Mrs Kline exhaled. “Good. You must not go. If you feel threatened, if you are being blackmailed or harassed, we need to involve the police.” Connor’s face tightened. “No.” Mrs Kline blinked. “Connor—” Connor’s voice was strained. “My dad’s a police officer.” Mr Durnham looked relieved, as if this solved something. “Well then,” he said, “we can handle this quietly—” Mina’s head snapped around. “Quietly. There it is.” Mr Durnham flushed. “I didn’t mean—” Mina stood, chair scraping. “You always mean quietly.” Mrs Kline’s voice sharpened slightly. “Mina, sit down.” Mina stayed standing. “No. Because I’m not doing this again.” Asha stared at Mina, heart hammering. Again. Mina had been the one last summer who’d wanted to ring. Asha remembered the look Mina had given her in the dark: betrayal, confusion, anger. A look Asha had avoided ever since by pretending it hadn’t happened. Mrs Kline said, “I’m going to call your parents. All of your parents. There will be a meeting.” Connor’s head jerked up. “You can’t.” Mrs Kline’s expression hardened gently. “I can. This is safeguarding.” Asha’s stomach dropped into her shoes. Parents. Meetings. Official. Her phone buzzed in her pocket, like it was laughing at her. Unknown number: 🩸🩸🩸 Then, a message. MIDNIGHT. ONE CHANCE. Asha’s mouth went dry. She pulled the phone out under the table, hiding it with her thigh like a delinquent. Unknown: VIDEO + CHAT. Unknown: OR I SEND EVERYTHING. Unknown: INCLUDING THE PART YOU EDITED OUT. Asha’s vision blurred. Edited out. She hadn’t edited anything. Had she? Had she convinced herself she hadn’t? Her mind raced, grasping. There had been a moment—brief—where Rowan had tried to get up and someone had shoved him back down, laughing. Not hard. Not meant to hurt. Just— Asha’s breath caught. She’d never told herself that part clearly. She’d always filed it under *chaos,* under *not my fault,* under *accident.* Connor’s voice cut through. “Asha? You alright?” Asha looked up. Everyone was looking at her. Mrs Kline said, “Asha?” Asha forced a smile that felt like cracking glass. “Yeah,” she said. “Just… stressed.” Mrs Kline nodded as if that was the whole story. “We will handle this,” she said. “Do not respond. Do not engage. We will speak to the police liaison and—” Mina laughed, sharp. “Police liaison. Like it’s a careers advisor.” Connor said, “Can we go now?” Mr Durnham opened the door, eager to end the discomfort. They spilled back into the corridor. The air felt colder out here, like the school had exhaled them. Connor grabbed Asha’s elbow. “What did it say?” he whispered. “You went weird.” Asha pulled her arm away too quickly. “Nothing.” Mina’s eyes narrowed. “It said something.” Asha’s throat tightened. She could lie. She could keep controlling. That was what she did. But Leah’s question echoed: *For who?* Asha looked at Connor and Mina, then down the corridor where students flowed around them like water around stones, all of them with phones, all of them with mouths. “It wants the video,” she said, voice low. “And the chat. And—” She swallowed. “It says there’s a part we edited out.” Theo wasn’t there to hear it. Maybe that was for the best. Maybe it was for the worst. Connor’s face went pale. “What part?” Asha opened her mouth. The memory hovered, slippery and sharp. Mina’s voice was quiet. “The part where it wasn’t an accident.” Asha flinched. “It was an accident.” Mina held her gaze. “Was it?” Asha couldn’t answer. Because she didn’t know which version was true anymore, or if she’d ever known. Connor’s phone buzzed. He glanced at it and swore under his breath. “My dad’s calling,” he said. Mina’s laugh was brittle. “Perfect.” Asha looked at her own phone again. The message sat there, patient. MIDNIGHT. ONE CHANCE. Asha could feel the day closing in around that point, like everything was being pulled towards it. Daylight didn’t fix it. It just showed more clearly how many people were watching. And how little control she had left.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong craft in several key areas while maintaining the darkly comic British YA tone established in the plan. The writing effectively captures the institutional response to crisis - the school's performative concern, the adults' desire to contain rather than address, and the way teenagers navigate being simultaneously protected and surveilled. The character work is particularly strong. Asha's internal conflict between control and honesty feels authentic, as does her growing realization that her "management" of the situation was actually cowardice. Mina's moral clarity cuts through the adults' bureaucratic language effectively ("Police liaison. Like it's a careers advisor"), while Connor's fear of his police officer father adds realistic complexity. The absent Theo creates tension through his absence - his phone being confiscated by his mother feels like a believable teenage consequence that complicates the group dynamic. The dialogue captures distinct voices well. Mrs. Kline's professional gentleness ("We're not here to accuse you of sending anything. We're here to make sure everyone is safe") contrasts sharply with Mina's cutting directness and the students' defensive responses. The adults speak in institutional language that reveals their priorities - containment over truth. The escalation feels organic. The school meeting serves multiple functions: it shows how institutions handle crisis, forces the characters into uncomfortable honesty, and raises the stakes by involving parents. The final text messages effectively ratchet up pressure while revealing new information about "the part you edited out." However, there are some weaker elements. The opening description of the school's response, while atmospheric, occasionally veers toward telling rather than showing ("By Friday morning, the school had decided it was having an incident"). Some metaphors don't quite land - "Asha felt like she was walking naked" is functional but clichéd. The chapter successfully follows its plan of showing institutional self-protection and the group beginning to splinter. The revelation about the "edited out" part creates genuine tension and moral complexity without feeling contrived. The writing maintains the established tone - darkly comic but not at the expense of the serious underlying issues. The pacing works well, building from the morning gossip through the official meeting to the final threatening messages. The chapter ends on an effective cliffhanger that feels earned rather than manipulative. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 6 — Midnight Is a Stupid Time to Be Brave Asha got home to find her mum sitting at the kitchen table with her phone in her hand like it was a weapon. Asha froze in the doorway. Her blazer was damp from rain that wasn’t quite rain, just air that had decided to be wet. She could taste metal in her mouth, like she’d been chewing coins. Mum looked up. Her face did that thing where it went very still before anger arrived, like the pause in a microwave before it beeps. “Sit,” Mum said. Asha’s stomach dropped. “What—” “Sit,” Mum repeated, sharper. “Now.” Asha sat. On the table was a printed screenshot. Actual paper. Someone had gone to the effort of using a printer in 2025. The absurdity of it made Asha want to laugh and cry at the same time. The screenshot was of Asha’s message from last summer. Asha: don’t ring anyone. just get him up. PLEASE Under it, in someone’s handwriting, was 🩸🩸🩸, like a curse. Mum tapped the paper. “Explain.” Asha’s throat tightened so hard it felt like swallowing glass. “Where did you get that?” Mum’s eyes flashed. “School rang. They said there are ‘online rumours’. They said your name is being mentioned. And then Mrs Patel from the shop next door sent me this because her niece is in your year and apparently everyone thinks it’s fine to share other people’s messages like sweets.” Asha’s hands curled under the table. “It’s taken out of context.” Mum stared at her. “Context?” Asha swallowed. She could do the safe version. She could say: prank. Blackmail. Someone’s being weird. She could avoid Rowan’s name. But Mrs Kline was calling parents. The school was already in it. The truth was going to arrive at Mum’s door anyway; Asha could either control how or be steamrollered. “It was last summer,” Asha said, voice small. “There was an accident.” Mum’s gaze sharpened. “The canal?” Asha flinched. Mum had been listening. The radio. The town. Of course Mum knew. Asha nodded. Mum’s face changed, pain flickering through the anger. “Rowan?” Asha’s breath caught. Hearing his name here, in their kitchen, made her want to curl into the cupboard under the sink. “Yes.” Mum looked away, jaw working, and then looked back with fury. “And you told them not to ring anyone?” Asha’s eyes stung. “I didn’t— I didn’t want anyone to get in trouble.” Mum’s laugh was short and ugly. “You didn’t want *you* to get in trouble.” Asha opened her mouth. Closed it. Because yes. Because she’d been thinking about consequences like they were a disease you avoided by disinfecting the evidence. Mum leaned forward. “Are the police involved?” “No,” Asha said quickly. “Not— not yet.” Mum’s eyes narrowed. “Not yet.” Asha’s phone buzzed in her blazer pocket. She didn’t move. Mum held out her hand. “Give me your phone.” Asha’s heart lurched. “Mum—” “Give,” Mum said, and her voice was the voice that had made Asha eat vegetables and apologise when she didn’t mean it and stop walking home with boys who catcalled her. It was not a negotiable voice. Asha stared at her phone like it was a limb she was about to lose. Her mind flashed: unknown number, emojis, screenshots, midnight, Leah. If Mum took her phone, Asha would lose the only warning system she had. She would be blind. “I need it,” Asha said. “For— for schoolwork.” Mum’s mouth twisted. “You can do your schoolwork on paper like God intended. Phone. Now.” Asha’s hand shook as she pulled it out and placed it on the table. Mum flipped it over, face down, and Asha felt strangely exposed, like she’d just handed over her skin. Mum stood. “You are not going out tonight,” she said. Asha’s stomach dropped. “Mum, I wasn’t—” Mum cut her off. “You were. I know you. You were going to go and ‘sort it’. You are a child, Asha. You don’t sort things like this at midnight. You come to me.” Asha looked up, eyes burning. “And what? You ring the school and they ring the police and everyone thinks I’m a monster?” Mum’s face tightened. “If you did something wrong, you face it.” Asha flinched. “We didn’t— we didn’t push him.” Mum’s gaze held hers. “Did you leave him there?” Asha’s breath caught. She remembered the towpath, Rowan’s face in phone light, the moment they moved away because someone said they’d heard a car, the fear that they’d be caught, the ridiculous thought of detention in the middle of emergency. “No,” she lied. Mum’s shoulders sagged a fraction, like she didn’t believe her but didn’t want to break her. “Go upstairs,” Mum said quietly. “I’m ringing Mrs Kline back.” Asha stood on legs that felt like borrowed stilts and went to her room. Upstairs, she sat on her bed and stared at the wall. Without her phone, the room felt too quiet. She could hear Mum’s voice downstairs, low and urgent, the clink of cups. Asha’s laptop sat on her desk. She opened it and logged into Instagram like a starving person. Her feed was a mess of blood emoji jokes and people pretending to be horrified while liking everything. She searched Leah’s name. leahb__ Private. The profile picture was a blurry shot of two kids: Leah and Rowan, younger, faces pressed together, laughing. Rowan’s grin was wide and stupid and alive. Asha’s throat tightened. A ping: a message request. On her laptop. Leah had found a way around the phone. leahb__: midnight. one chance. Asha’s hands went cold. leahb__: video + chat. Asha typed without thinking. Asha: i don’t have the video The reply came instantly. leahb__: you don’t need to have it to know it exists. Asha’s stomach lurched. leahb__: if you don’t bring it, i send everything. to school. to parents. to police. to whoever wants a story. Asha’s fingers hovered. She could type an apology. She could type a threat. She could type *please*. Instead she typed: Asha: what do you want There was a pause long enough for Asha to imagine Leah staring at her screen, jaw clenched, deciding whether to be human or cruel. Then: leahb__: i want you to stop hiding. Asha’s eyes stung. leahb__: i want someone to say what actually happened. not “accident” like it’s weather. Asha’s throat tightened. She typed, because she couldn’t not. Asha: it was an accident Three dots appeared. Vanished. Appeared again. leahb__: was it? Asha’s breath caught. The shove. The laugh. The moment that had been filed away under chaos. Downstairs, Mum’s voice rose slightly. “No, I’m telling you, she’s not leaving the house—” Asha’s blood went cold. She imagined Mrs Kline’s calm voice, Mr Durnham’s clipboard, Connor’s dad’s uniform. Asha slammed the laptop shut like it had bitten her. She sat there, shaking. Midnight. One chance. She couldn’t go. Mum had her phone. Mum would lock the door if she had to. Asha stared at her window. The garden gate below. The alley that led to the side street. She hated herself for immediately calculating exits. She wasn’t brave. She was panicked. A tap at the window made her jump so hard she nearly fell off the bed. She froze. Another tap. Then a whisper, muffled through glass. “Asha. Open up.” Connor. Asha yanked the curtain aside. Connor stood in the garden, hood up, face pale in the security light, looking like a boy about to do something stupid. Asha cracked the window. Cold air rushed in. “What are you doing?” she hissed. Connor’s breath puffed in little clouds. “You’re not answering. Thought you’d been murdered by your mum.” Asha’s throat tightened. “She took my phone.” Connor’s eyes widened. “Christ.” Asha shook her head. “You can’t be here.” Connor glanced at the kitchen window downstairs. “Is she—” “On the phone,” Asha whispered. Connor leaned closer. “We have to go tonight.” Asha’s stomach dropped. “No. Connor, no.” He swallowed. The bravado was gone. “Theo’s… he’s gone weird. Mina’s fuming. Leah’s not stopping. And my dad— my dad’s sniffing round. If my dad finds out from someone else, it’ll be worse.” Asha stared at him. “Why are you here?” Connor’s laugh was shaky. “Because you’re the one who thinks in straight lines when the rest of us are just… flailing.” Asha swallowed. “That’s not a compliment.” Connor’s eyes held hers. “Come with us.” Asha’s chest hurt. “Mum won’t let me.” Connor’s mouth tightened. “Then sneak.” Asha stared at him. The idea of climbing out of her bedroom window like a Victorian orphan made her want to laugh, but her body was too full of adrenaline for laughter to fit. Asha whispered, “Mina?” Connor nodded towards the gate. “She’s round the corner. Like a bat. Judging me.” Asha’s throat tightened. She glanced at the door. Mum’s voice downstairs, still talking. Asha imagined staying. Staying safe. Staying quiet. Then she imagined waking up to her whole life on someone’s story, edited into a villain montage with emojis. Her hands shook as she opened the window wider. “Okay,” she whispered. “Give me two minutes.” Connor nodded. “Bring a coat. And—” His mouth twisted. “Sorry. For earlier.” Asha swallowed. “Me too.” She climbed out onto the small flat roof over the shop front, the cold seeping through her socks. She lowered herself into the garden with more noise than she’d like. Connor caught her elbow, steadying her. His hand was warm. Mina appeared from the shadow by the gate. Hood up, eyes bright. “Took you long enough,” she murmured. Asha’s voice shook. “Theo?” Mina’s mouth tightened. “He’s not answering. His mum took his phone too. Or he’s ignoring us. Either way.” Connor exhaled. “We can’t go without him.” Mina’s eyes flashed. “We can’t not go because of him.” Asha felt the word *midnight* pressing down on her skull. A stupid time to be brave. A stupid time to be anything except asleep. But they were moving anyway, three figures slipping out of a garden into a town that looked normal and wasn’t. As they walked, Asha’s laptop notification buzzed in her room upstairs, unseen. Midnight was coming, with or without her. And she had the sick feeling that the “one chance” wasn’t Leah being dramatic. It was Leah being accurate.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical execution and character work within the darkly comic British YA framework. The writing successfully balances tension with authentic teenage voice and behavior, creating a compelling escalation toward the midnight confrontation. The character work is particularly strong. Asha's internal conflict between self-preservation and moral responsibility feels genuine, and her relationship with her mother rings true - the kitchen confrontation captures both parental authority and teenage desperation effectively. The mother's reaction (demanding the phone, printing screenshots, the mix of fury and protective instinct) feels authentic rather than convenient. Connor's appearance at the window maintains his established character as someone who uses charm and loyalty to navigate crisis, while Mina's terse presence ("Like a bat. Judging me") provides effective contrast. The dialogue consistently serves character and plot without feeling forced. Lines like "You didn't want *you* to get in trouble" and "You are a child, Asha. You don't sort things like this at midnight" capture the emotional stakes while maintaining naturalistic speech patterns. The text exchanges with Leah escalate tension effectively, particularly "i want you to stop hiding" which cuts through Asha's deflections. The chapter follows its outlined plan well, moving from parental confrontation through digital communication to the decision to meet Leah. The pacing builds appropriately toward midnight, and the stakes feel genuinely high - not just physical danger, but social and familial consequences that matter to teenagers. However, some elements feel slightly overwrought. The "chewing coins" metaphor and "swallowing glass" sensation, while evocative, border on purple prose for a realistic YA voice. The window escape sequence, while acknowledged as absurd by the characters themselves, still feels somewhat convenient as a plot device. The writing maintains the established tone well - dark comedy emerges naturally from situation rather than forced quips. Asha's observation about someone using an actual printer in 2025 provides levity without undermining tension. The chapter successfully builds dread while keeping characters grounded in recognizable teenage concerns about parents, phones, and social consequences. The ending effectively sets up the climactic confrontation while maintaining uncertainty about Theo's involvement and what exactly will happen at midnight. The final image of Asha's laptop notification going unseen adds an ominous note without being heavy-handed. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 7 — The Worst Version of You, On Someone Else’s Screen When Asha got home in the early hours—mud on her shoes, cold in her bones, Connor’s frantic “mate mate mate” still echoing in her head—her mum was waiting in the kitchen like a final boss. She didn’t shout. That was how Asha knew she’d crossed a line that didn’t lead back to normal. Mum sat at the table with Asha’s phone in front of her and a mug of tea that had gone skin-cold. Asha stopped in the doorway. “Mum—” Mum held up a hand. “Don’t.” Asha’s throat tightened. She could still taste canal air: damp stone, algae, old cigarettes. Her hair smelled like rain and panic. Mum said, very quietly, “Where were you.” Asha opened her mouth and felt the lie rise like a reflex. Library. Mina’s. Walk. Anywhere but— “I went out,” Asha said, voice shaking. Mum’s eyes were wet. That made Asha’s chest hurt more than anger would have. “I was on the phone to Mrs Kline,” Mum said. “And to your auntie. And I was sitting here like an idiot thinking, at least she’s upstairs, at least she’s safe, at least I can keep her in the house.” Asha swallowed. “I’m sorry.” Mum laughed, sharp and broken. “Sorry? Do you know what sorry is for? Spilled milk. Not… this.” Asha’s hands curled into fists. “I didn’t mean for any of this to happen.” Mum’s gaze snapped up. “But it did. And you made choices.” Asha’s stomach twisted. Choices. That word again. Like it was a thing you could measure. Mum picked up Asha’s phone and slid it across the table. “Read.” Asha’s breath caught. On the screen was an email from school, sent to parents at 01:17. Subject: Important: Safeguarding Concern The body was polished and bland: we are aware, we are investigating, we are supporting, please monitor your child’s internet use. The words were designed to contain. Below it, a WhatsApp message from Connor’s mum to Mum. Connor’s Mum: did u hear abt the video??? they say ash told them not to call ambulance?? is she ok?? x Asha’s vision blurred. Her name was now a rumour adults passed like a casserole dish. Mum’s voice was flat. “There is a meeting at school today. Ten o’clock. You are coming.” Asha’s throat tightened. “Mum, I have—” “Exams?” Mum snapped, finally. “Your exams will still be there. This will not go away because you have a maths paper.” Asha flinched. “Okay.” Mum stared at her for a long moment, then said, softer, “Go upstairs. Sleep. We’ll talk in the morning.” Asha went upstairs and lay in bed staring at the ceiling until the sky began to grey. She didn’t sleep so much as fall into a shallow, twitchy half-state where every time she closed her eyes she saw phone flash on Rowan’s face. At 08:03, her phone buzzed. Connor: you awake Asha: yeah Connor: you ok Asha stared at the words. *You ok* was a joke. A meaningless social tick. But Connor meant it as much as he could. Asha: no Connor: same Asha’s chest tightened. Connor: i told my dad last night Asha’s stomach dropped. She sat up, dizzy. Asha: what Connor: not all. but enough. he saw the stories. he was gonna find out anyway Asha typed with shaking fingers. Asha: what did he say There was a pause. Then: Connor: he said “hand your phone over” in that voice Asha swallowed. Connor: meeting at school. my mum’s crying. which is grim Asha stared at the chat. It felt like being trapped in a lift with the floor numbers flashing too fast. At 09:12, a new Instagram story popped up from an account called TowpathTruth (private, 0 posts yesterday, 6 posts today). Someone had followed half the year group overnight. Mina: have you seen this Asha clicked. The story was a screenshot of another message from last summer’s group chat. This one wasn’t even dramatic. It was just—cruel. Connor: lol he’s fine. he’s just being dramatic Under it: 🩸🩸🩸 Next slide: a still from the video—Rowan on the ground, people’s shoes visible around him, someone laughing. It wasn’t gore. It was worse: ordinary. The kind of clip people filmed and forgot. Until it became evidence. Next slide: a poll. “should they get expelled? yes/no” Asha’s throat tightened. She felt sick. The story wasn’t about justice; it was about attention. Votes. Engagement. Entertainment. Her phone buzzed again. Mina: i swear to god if that’s josh ward i’m putting him in a bin Asha: meeting at 10 Mina: i know. i’m coming. i’m not letting them make you the scapegoat. The words made Asha’s eyes sting. At 10:00, the school meeting room smelled of cheap coffee and panic. Asha sat beside her mum, who wore her shop jumper because she’d come straight from opening up, hair scraped back, jaw set. Across the table sat Mrs Kline, Mr Durnham, the Headteacher, and—unexpectedly—PC Hayes. Connor’s dad. Uniform off, but the posture remained. Connor sat next to his mum, shoulders hunched, eyes fixed on the table like if he didn’t look up, no one would see him. Mina sat alone, no parent in sight, chin raised like she’d come to court voluntarily. Theo wasn’t there. The Headteacher began with the kind of voice people used at funerals and awards ceremonies. “Thank you all for coming. I want to reassure you—” Mina muttered, “Here we go.” Asha’s mum shot her a look, not unkindly, more like *same, honestly.* Mrs Kline said, “We are concerned about the wellbeing of several students. There has been harassment. Threats. There are also serious allegations relating to last summer’s incident.” PC Hayes leaned forward. “I’m here because there’s potential criminality,” he said bluntly. He didn’t look at Connor. He looked at Asha. Asha’s skin went cold. Connor’s mum said, voice trembling, “My son didn’t do anything on purpose.” The Headteacher smiled tightly. “We are not here to apportion blame at this stage.” Mina laughed once. “You’re always at this stage.” Mr Durnham bristled. “Mina—” Mina’s eyes flashed. “No. Because you keep saying ‘allegations’ like Rowan wasn’t actually on the floor.” Asha’s breath caught. Rowan’s name in this room, spoken like a fact, not a rumour. It hit her like a wave. PC Hayes’s gaze sharpened. “Rowan Bennett,” he said. “The case was closed as an accident.” Asha’s stomach twisted. Closed. Filed. Put away. Like her own notes app. Mum’s hand found Asha’s knee under the table, gripping, grounding. PC Hayes continued, “If there is new evidence—video, messages—we need to see it.” Connor’s head jerked up. “No, you don’t,” he blurted. “It’s— it’s private.” Asha watched Connor’s dad look at him, and something in Connor seemed to fold. PC Hayes said, quieter, “Connor.” Connor’s eyes filled. He blinked hard. “I didn’t mean—” The Headteacher cleared her throat. “We also need to consider the impact of this on the school community.” Mina’s laugh was bitter. “There it is. Impact on the school.” Asha felt something inside her snap, small but clean. The school was still trying to contain. To protect itself. To manage optics. And if Asha let them, they’d pick the easiest person to blame: the girl whose message said don’t ring anyone. The girl who looked responsible enough to be guilty. She pulled her phone out. Mum’s grip tightened, then loosened, letting her choose. “I have it,” Asha said, voice shaking. Everyone turned to her. Asha’s heart hammered. She forced the words out before she could swallow them again. “I have the messages. I have the texts from Leah. I don’t have the video, but I know it exists. And I—” Her breath caught. “I delayed calling for help. I told them not to ring. That’s my message.” Mum made a small sound beside her, like pain. Connor stared at Asha like she’d slapped him. The Headteacher’s face went very still. Mrs Kline’s eyes softened. PC Hayes’s gaze sharpened. Asha continued, voice cracking. “And we… we agreed what to say afterwards. We deleted things. We tried to make it smaller.” Mina’s chin trembled once, then steadied. PC Hayes said, “You understand that’s serious.” Asha nodded, throat tight. “Yes.” Connor’s voice came out rough. “Why are you doing this?” Asha looked at him. “Because it’s already out,” she said, and her voice went sharp with something that wasn’t fear now. “And because I’m not letting Josh Ward and some anonymous account decide what the story is.” The Headteacher said, quickly, “Asha, perhaps we should—” “No,” Asha said. The word surprised her, how solid it sounded. “I’m giving a statement. Properly. Not… not through rumours.” Mina exhaled, a sound like relief and grief mixed. “Good.” Connor’s mum began to cry properly then, hands over her mouth. PC Hayes nodded once, brisk. “Alright,” he said. “We’ll do this correctly.” Asha felt sick. She felt lightheaded. She felt like she’d stepped off a cliff and only now noticed there was no ground. Outside the meeting room, the corridor was full of students pretending not to look. Eyes flicked. Whispers followed. Connor caught up with Asha near the stairs. His face was blotchy, eyes red, jaw tight. “What have you done?” he hissed. Asha’s throat tightened. “I told the truth.” Connor’s laugh was sharp and broken. “Your truth. You’ve just— you’ve just made it all about you.” Asha flinched. “No, I—” Connor stepped back. “You always do that,” he said, voice low. “You always decide what’s best and then act like it’s responsibility.” Asha’s chest hurt. “Connor—” He shook his head, eyes wet. “Don’t.” He turned and walked away into the crowd. Asha stood there, shaking, watching his back disappear, feeling the cost arrive in her body like a bruise. Her phone buzzed. A new message request from TowpathTruth. No words. Just: 🩸 One drop now. And for the first time, it didn’t feel like a threat. It felt like a receipt.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a strong execution of darkly comic British YA fiction that successfully navigates the complex emotional terrain of teenage guilt, institutional failure, and moral reckoning. The writing demonstrates sophisticated character work and authentic dialogue while maintaining narrative momentum toward its climactic revelation. The chapter's greatest strength lies in its nuanced characterization. Asha's internal conflict between self-preservation and moral responsibility feels genuinely adolescent - her decision to confess isn't heroic but pragmatic, driven by loss of control rather than noble intention. The mother's quiet devastation ("She didn't shout. That was how Asha knew she'd crossed a line that didn't lead back to normal") captures parental disappointment with devastating economy. Connor's betrayed reaction rings true to his character profile - his accusation that Asha "always decides what's best" reveals both his dependency on her leadership and his resentment of it. The institutional meeting scene effectively satirizes bureaucratic damage control while advancing plot. The adults' language ("we are investigating," "potential criminality," "impact on the school community") contrasts sharply with the teenagers' raw emotion, highlighting the gap between official responses and human cost. Mina's interjections ("You're always at this stage") provide necessary comic relief without undermining the scene's gravity. The social media elements feel authentic rather than forced. The TowpathTruth account and its engagement-driven "justice" captures how real trauma becomes digital entertainment. The progression from three blood emojis to one feels symbolically appropriate - the threat diminishing as truth emerges. However, some elements feel slightly mechanical. The timing of revelations occasionally prioritizes plot convenience over organic development. PC Hayes's presence, while justified by Connor's father's profession, creates convenient exposition opportunities that feel somewhat contrived. The chapter also relies heavily on phone buzzes and message notifications as scene transitions, which becomes repetitive. The dialogue generally succeeds in capturing authentic teenage speech patterns and emotional states. Asha's "Because it's already out" moment feels earned rather than speechified. Connor's final confrontation avoids melodrama while delivering genuine emotional impact. The writing maintains the established tone effectively - darkly comic without trivializing serious subject matter. The institutional satire never overwhelms the human story, and moments of levity (Mina's threats about bins) provide necessary breathing room. The chapter fulfills its structural purpose within the larger narrative, delivering the promised "public rupture" while maintaining character consistency. Asha's choice to confess aligns with her profile as someone who confuses "managing the narrative" with "being responsible," while Connor's reaction reflects his defensive loyalty and fear of consequences. Minor weaknesses include occasional over-explanation of emotional states and some dialogue tags that could be trimmed. The pacing occasionally rushes through emotional beats that could benefit from more space to breathe. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 8 — After The school’s email went out at 16:42, because that was the hour the school liked best for bad news: late enough that teachers could go home, early enough that parents would still be awake and furious. Subject: Update: Student Welfare and Online Content Asha read it three times and still couldn’t tell what it said, because it didn’t say anything. It thanked families for their patience. It reminded everyone about “appropriate online conduct.” It mentioned “support” and “counselling” and “working with external agencies.” It did not mention Rowan’s name. It did not mention what had happened last summer. It did not mention why a blood emoji had been stuck to every surface in Year Eleven like an infestation. It was, in other words, perfect. Mum read it once, snorted, and said, “They’ve written that so it can be used again next year.” Asha lay on her bed in her uniform, shoes kicked off, staring at the ceiling. Her phone was back in her possession now, but it didn’t feel like freedom. It felt like holding a live wire. Notifications stacked like plates. DMs from people who’d never spoken to her before. Missed calls from Connor that had stopped abruptly at lunchtime and never restarted. Mina was the only person who’d texted something that wasn’t a question or an accusation. Mina: i’m coming round later. don’t argue. Asha didn’t argue. She didn’t have the energy to be stubborn. Her mum moved around the flat with the purposeful anger of someone cleaning to avoid crying. She wiped the kitchen counter twice. She reorganised the tea bags. She told Asha she’d made dal even though Asha hadn’t asked. At seven, Mum sat on the edge of Asha’s bed and handed her a plate. Asha ate because the alternative was her body doing something dramatic in a way that would inconvenience everyone. After dinner, Mum said, “The police called.” Asha’s stomach dropped. “PC Hayes?” Mum nodded. “Not him. Another one. A woman. She asked if you’d be willing to make a formal statement.” Asha swallowed. “I already said I would.” Mum’s eyes were tired. “Do you understand what that means?” Asha stared at her hands. “It means… it’s real.” Mum exhaled. “It means it will follow you for a long time. It means people will be angry. It means you might be punished.” Asha’s throat tightened. “I know.” Mum’s voice softened. “Why did you do it then?” Asha opened her mouth. She could say: because it was right. She could say: because Leah forced me. She could say: because I was scared. The truth was all of them, tangled. “Because I’m sick of lying,” Asha whispered. “And because everyone’s already decided what happened without asking. I wanted… I wanted it to be the real version, not the TikTok version.” Mum’s face tightened with something like grief. “The real version is going to hurt.” Asha nodded. “It already did.” Mum sat for a moment longer, then stood. At the door she paused. “Mina’s good,” she said, as if remembering. “She’s always been good.” Asha’s throat tightened. “Yeah.” Mum left. Asha lay back and stared at the ceiling again. She could hear the shop fridge humming downstairs through the floorboards, steady and indifferent. It had hummed through last summer too. It would hum through whatever came next. At 20:13, there was a knock at the door. Asha heard Mum answer, heard Mina’s voice—low, blunt, familiar. Mina came into Asha’s room without asking, dropped her tote bag on the floor, and sat on the edge of the bed like she owned it. She looked exhausted, eyeliner slightly smudged for the first time Asha could remember. Asha tried for humour. “You look like you’ve fought a bear.” Mina snorted. “I fought a school. Bears are honest.” Asha’s laugh came out weak. Mina looked at her, and her expression softened in a way that made Asha’s eyes sting. “You did it,” Mina said. Asha’s throat tightened. “Yeah.” Mina nodded once, as if confirming something she’d already decided. “Connor’s furious.” Asha flinched. “I know.” Mina leaned back, arms folded. “He’s not wrong to be. But he’s also… Connor. He thinks if he can keep it contained, it doesn’t count.” Asha stared at her duvet. “I didn’t want to make him the villain.” Mina’s voice sharpened. “Then stop acting like you’re the only person who can decide what everyone is.” Asha looked up. Mina held her gaze, not cruelly, just… accurately. Asha swallowed. “Fine. I did it because I didn’t want to be the villain. I wanted it to be… a clean story.” Mina’s mouth twisted. “There are no clean stories. Only stories people wash and then sell.” Asha let out a shaky breath. “TowpathTruth is still posting.” Mina rolled her eyes. “Of course they are.” Asha reached for her phone, hesitated, then opened Instagram. TowpathTruth had added more slides since morning. Screenshots, captions, polls. People voting on what should happen to them like it was Love Island. Asha felt sick. “It’s not even— they don’t care about Rowan. They care about—” “Content,” Mina said, flat. “Welcome to the internet. It’s a graveyard with ads.” Asha scrolled and stopped. New story. Different account. leahb__ (private) Asha’s heart lurched. She hadn’t accepted Leah’s request. She hadn’t blocked her either. She’d just… existed in that tense middle space. Asha tapped. It wasn’t a screenshot. It wasn’t a threat. It was a black screen with white text, like someone had typed it into Notes and posted it raw. i shouldn’t have done it like this. i’m sorry for scaring you. but you don’t get to forget him. Then, a second slide: he has physio tomorrow. 9am. he hates the green building. he says it smells like soup. Asha stared. Her throat tightened. Mina leaned in, reading over Asha’s shoulder. Mina’s expression changed—just a flicker. Sadness, maybe. Or something like recognition. Asha whispered, “That’s… Rowan.” Mina nodded. “Yeah.” Asha’s hands shook. “So it was Leah.” Mina’s mouth tightened. “Probably. Or someone using her name. But…” She shrugged. “It sounds like her.” Asha stared at the screen until it dimmed. The soup smell. The green building. A detail so stupid and human it hurt more than any blood emoji. Mina said, “What did actually happen that night?” Asha’s breath caught. She’d said it to adults in a meeting, in careful, clipped phrases, but Mina was asking differently. Not for a statement. For truth between friends. Asha swallowed. “We were at that party,” she began, voice thin. “By the towpath. Someone had a speaker. Theo was filming everything because he films everything. Connor was… Connor.” Mina didn’t interrupt. She didn’t fill silence. She just watched. Asha continued, words stumbling. “Rowan was there because Leah was working and— and he wanted to seem older. He was trying to keep up.” Her throat tightened. “He climbed on the wall by the bridge. We were laughing. Not… not at him, just— you know. And then he slipped. Or—” Asha closed her eyes. The memory shifted, refusing to be neat. “Someone bumped him,” she whispered. “Like a joke. Like, ‘move over’.” Mina’s jaw clenched. Asha opened her eyes. “I don’t know if it was a shove. I don’t know if it was enough to count as… anything. But he went. He went down. He hit the concrete. And he made a sound and everyone went quiet for half a second and then—” She swallowed hard. “Connor said he was being dramatic. And I… I said don’t ring anyone.” Mina’s voice was hoarse. “Why?” Asha stared at her hands. “Because I thought if we called, we’d be in trouble. And if we were in trouble, it would be… the end.” Mina’s eyes glistened. “And if we didn’t call?” Asha’s breath caught. “I thought he’d get up. I thought… it would undo itself.” Mina let out a shaky breath. “It didn’t.” “No,” Asha whispered. “It didn’t.” For a moment, there was nothing but the hum of the fridge downstairs and the distant sound of a car passing on wet roads. Mina wiped her eye with the heel of her hand like she was annoyed at it. “You’re going to give your statement,” she said, more firmly, as if decision-making could be a raft. Asha nodded. “Yeah.” Mina’s voice tightened. “And when they try to make you the only villain, you don’t let them. You don’t let them do what they always do. Find one person and let everyone else sigh in relief.” Asha’s throat tightened. “Connor will hate me.” Mina’s expression hardened. “Connor’s not the most important person in this story.” The words stung because they were true. Asha nodded anyway, because she didn’t know what else to do. Mina stood, picked up her tote bag. “I have to go,” she said. “My mum will start ringing hospitals if I’m late.” Asha gave a weak laugh. “Fair.” At the door, Mina paused. “I’m not saying you’re forgiven,” she said, blunt. “I’m saying you’re here. Which is more than some people can manage.” Asha’s eyes stung. “Thanks,” she whispered. Mina left. Asha lay back on her bed and stared at her phone. The notifications didn’t stop. The world didn’t pause to let her breathe. Just after midnight, her phone buzzed. Asha’s body went rigid, every nerve lit. Not TowpathTruth. Not Leah. Not Connor. A notification from Photos. 1 year ago today. A thumbnail: blurred lights in darkness. A crowd. The red crown under the bridge, bright as fresh paint. Asha’s throat tightened until she could barely swallow. Her finger hovered. She could delete the memory. She could hide it. She could do what she always did. Instead, she stared at it, breathing through the panic, letting it exist. Her phone buzzed again. A message request. Unknown number. Asha’s heart hammered as she opened it. No emojis this time. Just: you did the right thing. Below it, a second line: i’m still angry. Asha’s eyes stung. She didn’t know whether it was Leah. She didn’t know whether it mattered. She typed, slowly, thumbs steadying. Asha: i’m sorry. Then, because apologies without truth were just decoration, she added: Asha: i won’t pretend it didn’t happen anymore. She sent it. The ticks didn’t turn blue. There was no reply. Outside, the town stayed dark and damp and ordinary. The shop fridge hummed. Somewhere, a fox screamed again, as if to remind her that the world was still full of raw, living noise. Asha turned her phone face down. This time, it wasn’t to ignore it. It was to let herself, for one moment, exist without watching the screen for blood.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter serves as a denouement to what appears to be a darkly comic British YA thriller, and it largely succeeds in its aims. The writing demonstrates strong character work, particularly in how it handles the aftermath of Asha's decision to tell the truth about the Rowan incident. The voice remains consistent with the established tone - observational, deflective, but with genuine emotional weight underneath. The chapter excels in several key areas. The dialogue feels authentically British and age-appropriate, with Mina's blunt observations ("Bears are honest," "It's a graveyard with ads") and the mother's weary pragmatism creating believable voices. The emotional beats land well, particularly the conversation between Asha and Mina where the full truth about Rowan's accident finally emerges. The detail about Rowan hating the "green building" because "it smells like soup" is a masterful touch - mundane yet heartbreaking, making him feel real rather than just a plot device. The structure works effectively, moving from the institutional response (the school's meaningless email) through personal consequences to a moment of genuine reckoning. The midnight notification callback is well-executed, transforming from threat to memory to a kind of acceptance. The writing avoids the trap of neat resolution while still providing emotional closure. However, there are some weaknesses. Certain metaphors feel slightly overwrought ("holding a live wire," "like plates" for notifications), though they don't quite cross into purple prose territory. The pacing occasionally drags in the middle section, and some of the social media elements feel slightly forced, particularly the TowpathTruth references which seem more expository than organic. The characterization remains strong and consistent with the established profiles. Asha's controlling nature, her guilt, and her tendency to intellectualize emotions all ring true. Mina's moral clarity and bluntness are well-maintained. The absent Connor's fury feels believable given his character. The chapter successfully follows its plan, dealing with fallout, institutional response, and the cost of truth-telling. It maintains the darkly comic tone while allowing genuine emotion to surface. The ending strikes an appropriate note - not redemptive, but honest about the ongoing nature of consequences. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is a substantial piece of darkly comic British YA fiction that successfully builds from the cryptic opening prompt of blood emojis sent at midnight. The story follows Asha and her friends as they grapple with the consequences of a past incident involving Rowan Bennett, whose fall from a bridge wall has left him with lasting injuries. The characterization is notably strong throughout. Asha emerges as a complex protagonist - someone who tries to control situations through management and containment, but whose attempts at responsibility often mask self-preservation. Her voice is authentic and her internal contradictions feel genuine. The supporting characters are well-differentiated: Connor uses humor as deflection, Mina cuts through pretense with sharp honesty, and Theo represents fragility and guilt. Even minor characters like the adults feel real rather than functional. The dialogue consistently captures authentic teenage speech patterns without feeling forced or overly stylized. Conversations flow naturally and reveal character through subtext. Lines like Mina's "Canal's got more security warnings than the nuclear code" or Connor's defensive "that hoodie was vintage. it had history. it had character" feel genuinely spoken rather than written. The pacing is expertly managed across eight chapters, building tension through the mystery of the anonymous messages while gradually revealing the truth about what happened to Rowan. The structure of moving from midnight texts to daylight consequences to eventual confession creates a satisfying arc. The author skillfully uses modern elements like social media, group chats, and viral content to drive the plot forward in ways that feel organic to the characters' world. The world-building effectively captures contemporary British teenage life - the details of school assemblies, corner shops, canal towpaths, and family dynamics above shops all ring true. The social media landscape is particularly well-rendered, showing how trauma becomes content and how stories get distorted through viral sharing. The emotional core of the story - guilt, responsibility, and the gap between intention and impact - is handled with genuine weight. The revelation that Asha's attempts to "manage" the situation actually made things worse creates real dramatic tension. Leah's grief and anger feel authentic rather than manipulative. However, there are some areas where the writing occasionally stumbles. Some metaphors feel slightly overwrought ("like she was holding a live wire" appears multiple times, and "the shop fridge hummed in its steady, unbothered way" anthropomorphizes unnecessarily). The piece sometimes tells us about characters' emotions rather than showing them through action, particularly in moments of high tension. The dark comedy promised in the prompt is present but subtle - it emerges through character voice and situational irony rather than forced jokes. This restraint serves the serious subject matter well. The resolution, while not complete, feels earned. Asha's decision to give a statement represents genuine character growth rather than a sudden transformation. The cost of this choice - Connor's anger, family disappointment, social consequences - is acknowledged rather than glossed over. The piece successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements while creating a substantial, emotionally resonant narrative that treats its serious themes with appropriate gravity. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Pacing: 16 World Building: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 80.9/100
+ Space Western — Cargo Unknown (Chapter Avg: 82.5 | Final: 61.6)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something&#x27;s... moving in that crate we picked up. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming ## Core premise spins (ways to interpret “something’s moving in that crate”) - **The “crate” is a coffin:** A cryo-casket that should be inert. Movement implies the passenger is awake… or something else is inside with them. - **Contraband livestock:** A breeder crate for a high-value alien “cattle” species (space ranching), except it’s pregnant, molting, or changing. - **Stowaway kid / refugee:** The crate holds a child or teen hiding from a company manhunt; the movement is fear, not monster-horror. - **Corporate bio-weapon:** Movement is a contained organism meant to be delivered to a frontier world—classic “it got loose” tension. - **A wanted outlaw:** The crate contains a famous gunslinger in hibernation (or restrained). The crew just “picked up” a bounty without realizing. - **A religious relic:** A “saint” in a crate, preserved. Movement suggests miracle… or fraud… or parasitic infestation. - **Ship is “moving”:** The crate is harmless, but it’s shifting because the ship is being subtly boarded or reeled in by an external force. - **The crate is a machine:** It contains a self-assembling automaton (a “steel rattler”) that’s waking up mid-transit. - **The crate contains eggs:** Small movements now; later a swarm. Space western version of “snake pit.” - **The crate is bait:** Someone expects the crew to open it so a tracker activates; movement is the tracker coming online. ## Space Western tone & setting ideas - **Frontier trade lanes:** Dusty asteroid towns, saloons in ring stations, marshal posts, company enclaves, and outlaw havens. - **Cattle drive in vacuum:** Hauling “vac-grazers” between domed ranch worlds; crew are space drovers. - **Telegraph analog:** “Beam-lines” or “heliograph” comm relays—messages are delayed, giving room for isolation and rumor. - **Law is local:** Company law vs. Marshal law vs. clan law. Captain navigates like a wagon master between jurisdictions. - **Aesthetic mix:** Revolvers + railguns; spurs on mag boots; poncho-like vacuum capes; whiskey in squeeze bulbs; harmonica in the mess. - **Moral western themes:** Debt, bounty, land grabs, found family, codes of honor, revenge, the price of survival, “civilization” arriving with a boot heel. ## Character possibilities (mix-and-match) - **Captain (protagonist):** - A former marshal turned independent hauler with a strict code. - A disgraced company pilot trying to rebuild reputation. - A soft-spoken, deadly ex-outlaw who “went straight.” - **First mate / speaker of the line:** Practical, superstitious, loyal; delivers the prompt line in a tense moment. - **Engineer:** Grease-stained genius; has a “don’t ask what’s in the crate” philosophy until it threatens the ship. - **Gunner / security:** Quick to violence; wants to space the crate; haunted by a past boarding. - **Doc / medic:** Empathetic; insists on checking for a living being; knows about biohazards. - **Passenger:** Mysterious drifter, preacher, bounty hunter, or company auditor whose presence complicates choices. - **Antagonist types:** - A company “claims agent” pursuing the crate. - A rival crew / pirate outfit that wants the cargo. - A frontier marshal who wants the crate seized as illegal. - A cult that believes the crate holds a messiah/curse. ## The “thing” in the crate (options with space-western flavor) - **A “rattler”**: A segmented, metallic burrower engineered to chew through hull plating (mining sabotage tool). - **A “star-wolf pup”**: A rare alien predator cub—valuable, imprintable, and dangerous when frightened. - **A “moon calf”**: Gentle but huge; when it wakes it thrashes, risking decompression. - **A human experiment**: Spliced outlaw with enhanced reflexes (company’s private lawman project). - **A living map**: An organism that carries navigational memory to a hidden motherlode; movement = it’s “pointing.” - **Swarm in hibernation**: One crate, thousands of dormant “rust mites” that eat circuitry. - **An AI in a body**: A corporate AI downloaded into wetware; it wakes and begins negotiating. ## Plot engines / conflicts to sustain 8 chapters (~8k words) - **Immediate shipboard tension:** The movement starts small; noises; clawing; temperature changes; instruments glitch. - **Ethical dilemma:** Open the crate (risk), deliver it (complicity), or dump it (breach contract / lose fuel money). - **External pressure:** A pursuer pings them, claiming salvage rights; or a marshal warns them they’re carrying illegal contraband. - **Resource constraints:** Low oxygen, failing coolant, damaged thrusters—classic frontier scarcity. - **Betrayal:** Someone aboard knows what’s inside and hid the truth (or was paid to). - **Stand-off western beat:** Negotiation at an outpost, saloon parley, hostage trade… but in docking bay shadows. - **Chase:** Through debris fields or canyons on a moon;
