A place with thick rock, not thin plating.” Doc nodded toward the platform’s core, where old mining boreholes had been cut into the asteroid it was anchored to. “The old tunnels. They were carved to extract ore. Dense.” Mara’s mind flashed to the creature sinking into Brine’s station floor like clay. To the crack of decking giving way. *It doesn’t mean to kill,* she thought. *It means to escape.* “Then we guide it there,” Mara said. They moved like thieves through dead corridors, Sparks carrying the generator, Jace humming softly every time the creature’s vibration spiked behind them. Mara kept her voice low, steady. Doc watched environmental readouts with grim focus. Ketch took rear, eyes flicking constantly toward the shadowed junctions. They reached an access shaft that dropped into the platform’s bore tunnels. The entrance was ringed with thick plating and old scorch marks. Beyond it, the tunnel walls were rough asteroid rock reinforced with metal ribs. The darkness inside felt absolute. Sparks set the generator down on a rock shelf and toggled it on. It thrummed, low and steady, a heartbeat you could feel through your boots. The creature’s vibration answered from behind, closer now—scrape-click, scrape-click. Mara stood at the tunnel mouth and let herself become still. “Easy,” she said into the darkness behind them. “Easy. This way.” A shape moved in the corridor gloom: mineral plates catching their lamps in dull flashes. The juvenile hull-borer emerged slowly, not charging. Its body flowed in segments, cautious now, tasting the floor with its wet underside. It paused at the tunnel entrance, vibration rising, then lowering as the generator’s hum reached it. It turned its glossy node toward Mara. For a heartbeat, she had the insane sense that it recognized her—not as captor or savior, but as a constant vibration in its brief, terrified life. Mara swallowed. “Go on,” she whispered. “There’s room.” The creature slid into the tunnel. As it moved past, the air filled with that mineral damp. The rock under it hissed faintly. Not dissolving—just reacting. Doc’s voice was tight. “If it begins to bore here—” “It can,” Mara said. “It’s rock. It can live in rock.” Behind them, a new sound echoed through the platform: boots. Human boots. Not their clanks—heavier, more confident, more numerous. Sparks cursed. “They found us.” The corporate team appeared at the corridor’s far end, suit lamps bright, weapons not yet raised. Lorne walked at their center, visor up inside helmet, eyes fixed on Mara. “Captain Vance,” Lorne called, voice carrying. “Step away from the organism.” Mara didn’t move. “It’s in rock now,” she said. “No habitat. No station. You can log it as ‘lost’ and leave.” Lorne’s face tightened. “That is not how this works.” “Make it,” Mara said. One of the techs lifted a dart gun. The creature inside the tunnel vibrated sharply, responding to the shift in air pressure, to the tension. Mara raised her hand. “Don’t,” she said to the tech, not to Lorne. “You fire at it in there, it’ll bore deeper. It’ll destabilize this whole platform.” Lorne hesitated. For the first time, procedure flickered. Not because they doubted the law—because they could see the physics. “Captain,” Lorne said, quieter, “you don’t understand what you’re doing. That organism is engineered. If it reproduces—” “It’s juvenile,” Doc cut in. “It’s alone.” Lorne’s eyes flashed to Doc, then back. “You can’t know that.” Mara’s jaw clenched. “And you can’t guarantee what your company will do with it once you have it.” Lorne’s gaze softened, almost imperceptibly. “My company will contain it.” Mara’s laugh came out raw. “Containment like you contained it in a crate on my ship?” The corridor went still. The techs shifted their weight. Ketch’s hand hovered near his holster, trembling just slightly now. Lorne’s voice dropped, honest in a way that hurt. “We contained it until you opened it.” Mara felt that like a slap because it was true in the way truths were always shared: someone else built the gun, but you pulled the trigger. She took a slow breath. “Then we’re both responsible,” she said. “So let’s be responsible where it doesn’t kill anyone.” Lorne stared at her a long moment, eyes tired. Then they lifted their comm hand and spoke into their team channel, low. “Stand down.” The tech with the dart gun lowered it, reluctant. Sparks exhaled a shaky breath. Jace’s shoulders dropped a fraction. Then the platform shuddered. Not from the creature. From docking clamps. A second corporate craft had latched onto the far side—reinforcements. The metal groaned, and the tunnel walls vibrated with it. The juvenile in the tunnel reacted instantly. Its thin hum spiked into frantic vibration. It turned inside the tunnel, plates clicking rapidly. “It’s panicking,” Doc said, voice tight. Mara’s chest clenched. “It’s going to bore.” And it did. The creature pressed its wet underside into the tunnel wall and began to sink, not straight down but sideways, deeper into rock. The hiss rose. Dust drifted. The rock softened, then gave. Sparks swore. “If it destabilizes the rib—” “Back!” Mara barked, grabbing Sparks’ arm and hauling her away from the tunnel mouth as the tunnel wall cracked, a spiderweb of stress lines racing along the reinforced rock. A chunk of metal rib sheared loose with a screech and slammed to the floor, denting the grating. A geyser of dust puffed out. Not vacuum—thank whatever gods still listened—just old rock shaken awake. Lorne shouted at their team, “Fall back!” The corporate techs retreated, boots clanging, discipline snapping back in the face of structural failure. Ketch grabbed Jace’s shoulder and pulled him clear just as another rib groaned overhead. Mara stood at the tunnel mouth, staring into the darkness where the juvenile had vanished. Her suit lamp caught only rough rock and a fresh, wet-sheened path leading deeper. “Go,” Doc urged, hand on her shoulder. “Captain—go.” Mara’s throat tightened. She wanted to follow it—stupid, impossible. She wanted to fix what she’d broken. She wanted the universe to have a clean option. Instead she did the only thing left. She reached to the hatch controls and slapped the manual seal. The heavy blast door began to slide, slow and reluctant, protesting with old hydraulics. Inside the tunnel, the creature’s vibration came once—sharp, then distant—like a farewell or a curse or nothing at all. The door sealed with a deep, final thud. Mara leaned her helmeted forehead against the metal for one heartbeat, and the cold of it bled through her suit like judgment. Sparks’ voice trembled in comms. “Mara…” Mara straightened. “We did what we could.” Behind them, Lorne stood amid their team, watching the sealed hatch, face pale. “You’ve just turned it loose in the belt,” Lorne said, voice flat. “In rock,” Mara corrected. “Not in people.” Lorne’s gaze met hers, and for a moment there was no company, no badge, no procedure—only two exhausted humans standing over a choice neither liked. “You’ll be flagged,” Lorne said quietly. “Every port. Every relay. They will call you a smuggler, an eco-terrorist, whatever makes it easier.” Mara nodded once. “Yeah.” Ketch’s voice came soft and broken through comms. “And Brine.” Mara felt that bruise again. “We warned him.” Lorne’s jaw tightened. “Warning isn’t restitution.” “No,” Mara agreed. “It’s just what you do when you can’t do enough.” For a long moment, nobody moved. The platform creaked around them, settling after strain. Somewhere deep in the asteroid, something alive burrowed into hard country where no one could own it easily. Lorne lifted their hand. Not a weapon. A comm. “My report will say the organism was lost to structural collapse,” they said, voice careful. “I can’t—” They swallowed. “I can’t absolve you. But I can… describe the conditions.” Sparks let out a disbelieving laugh. “That’s your mercy?” Lorne’s eyes flicked to her. “It’s what I have.” Mara held Lorne’s gaze. “Then take it.” Lorne nodded once, stiff. They turned, gestured for their team to withdraw. When the corporate lamps receded down the corridor, the platform felt darker. Quieter. More honest. Mara and her crew returned to the *Juniper* in silence. They undocked before the second craft could decide to be brave. The ship limped away on patched thrusters, hull scarred, systems complaining in tired beeps. In the hold, the crate sat empty, straps hanging loose like shed skin. The cold was already fading. The mineral smell lingered, stubborn as guilt. Mara stood in the doorway of the hold and listened to the ship’s hum. The *Juniper*’s vibration was familiar again—imperfect, alive. She felt the ache in her arms, the bruise on her hip, the weight of her name on a thousand screens to come. Jace came up behind her, quiet. “Captain,” he said, and didn’t finish, because sometimes you didn’t need the rest of the sentence. Mara nodded, not trusting her voice. She reached up and tucked a new pencil behind her ear—unbroken this time. A small act. A lie of control. Then she turned away from the empty crate, walked back toward the cockpit, and pointed her battered ship into the black where procedure thinned and choices got harder. She didn’t know if she’d done right. She only knew what she owed, and that she’d finally paid something other than money.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter serves as a strong conclusion to the space western narrative, effectively balancing action, character development, and thematic resolution. The writing demonstrates considerable craft in several key areas. The characterization remains consistent and nuanced throughout. Mara's internal conflict between pragmatism and conscience drives the narrative convincingly, while her crew members each respond authentically to the crisis according to their established personalities. Sparks' protective instincts toward the creature, Doc's clinical containment focus, Jace's quiet moral compass, and Ketch's guilt-driven loyalty all ring true to their profiles. The antagonist Lorne is particularly well-handled - neither villainous nor heroic, but a procedural professional caught between duty and humanity. The dialogue consistently carries subtext and reveals character. Lines like "Warning isn't restitution" and "It's what I have" when Lorne offers limited mercy feel authentic and weighted. The crew's banter maintains the established dynamic without forced humor, and Mara's sparse, decisive speech patterns remain consistent. The plot resolution avoids easy answers while providing emotional closure. The creature's exile to the asteroid tunnels represents a morally complex compromise - neither the clean "release" nor the corporate "containment" that simpler narratives might choose. This ambiguity serves the space western genre well, echoing frontier stories where justice is imperfect and survival comes at a cost. The action sequences are well-paced and grounded in realistic consequences. The platform's structural instability creates genuine tension without relying on melodramatic shootouts. The creature's panic response to the arriving reinforcements feels organic rather than convenient. However, some elements feel slightly overwrought. Phrases like "the cold of it bled through her suit like judgment" and "choices got harder" occasionally push toward purple prose without quite crossing the line. The metaphor of the empty crate's "straps hanging loose like shed skin" works but feels somewhat forced. The chapter successfully follows its outlined plan, delivering the promised confrontation on the mining platform and the morally complex resolution. The corporate pursuit feels appropriately procedural rather than cartoonish, and the final image of Mara pointing her ship "into the black where procedure thinned" effectively captures the frontier theme. The writing maintains the established tone throughout - working-class realism with moments of poetry that generally earn their place. The technical details feel authentic without overwhelming the narrative, and the world-building remains consistent with the established universe. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is an ambitious space western that successfully delivers on its premise across eight substantial chapters. The story follows Captain Mara Vance and her crew aboard the *Juniper* as they discover their sealed cargo contains a living, corrosive organism, leading to a complex moral dilemma involving corporate recovery agents and civilian safety. The strongest elements are the world-building and character work. The author creates a convincing frontier space setting with excellent details like the *Juniper's* patched hull, Outpost Brine's improvised construction, and the economic desperation that drives characters to take dangerous jobs. The ship feels lived-in and authentic, with specific technical details that ground the science fiction elements. Character development is particularly strong for Mara, who emerges as a complex protagonist wrestling with responsibility and past trauma as a former law enforcement officer. Her internal conflict between doing what's legally required versus what's morally right drives the narrative effectively. The supporting cast is well-differentiated, especially Sparks (the engineer) with her distinctive voice and technical expertise, and Ketch's confession about his corporate debt adds meaningful tension. The pacing is generally well-managed across the long narrative, building tension effectively from the initial discovery through the creature's escape and final containment. The author maintains suspense while allowing for character moments and world-building. However, there are notable weaknesses. The dialogue occasionally becomes stilted, particularly in exposition-heavy moments where characters explain technical details or moral positions rather than speaking naturally. Some metaphors feel forced, like "the ship shook like a wet dog shedding water" or "anger came easy—clean, hot." The writing sometimes veers toward purple prose with overwrought descriptions that don't serve the narrative. The creature itself remains somewhat underdeveloped as both a scientific concept and a character element. While its behavior is consistent, the story would benefit from clearer stakes regarding what it actually represents beyond a generic "bioweapon." The ending feels somewhat rushed, with the moral resolution coming through Lorne's convenient decision to file a false report rather than through the characters' actions having clear consequences. This undermines some of the story's thematic weight about responsibility and choice. The space western genre elements are present but not fully integrated—the frontier setting works well, but the "western" aspects feel more cosmetic than structural to the plot or themes. Overall, this is solid genre fiction with strong world-building and character work, but it's held back by inconsistent prose quality and some underdeveloped thematic elements. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 17 Pacing: 15 World Building: 18 Compelling Plot: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't-Show: 11 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 11 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Unearned Transformations: 14 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 61.6/100
+ Possession Horror — Different Eyes (Chapter Avg: 80.7 | Final: 85.5)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Possession Horror Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: I caught her staring at me again. She thought I'd been sleeping.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Possession Horror Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: I caught her staring at me again. She thought I&#x27;d been sleeping. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming ## Core prompt angles (possession + “she thought I’d been sleeping”) - **Domestic slow-burn possession:** Partner/family member gradually taken over; narrator pretends to sleep to observe escalating behavior (staring, whispering, nocturnal rituals). - **Patient/caregiver setting:** Narrator is bedridden (injury/illness) and dependent; caretaker “she” is possessed and uses the narrator’s immobility against them. - **Sleep paralysis ambiguity:** Narrator *can’t* move; “she” thinks they’re asleep because they’re frozen. Twist: narrator isn’t sure if it’s possession or their own neurological condition. - **Shared body possession:** “She” is narrator’s own body at night—an alter/tenant driving them while they “sleep.” Staring is from mirror/reflection or via phone camera. - **New mother/child angle:** “She” is daughter/son’s imaginary friend, or the mother is possessed postpartum; staring becomes predatory. - **Roommate / urban isolation:** Cheap apartment, new roommate who “sleepwalks.” Building has history (mass suicide/occult group). Night staring is the first sign. - **Religious/folk possession:** A saint icon, relic, or folk charm is brought in; it invites something. Staring is a “recognition” moment for the entity. - **Tech-mediated possession:** Smart home cameras catch “she” staring; voice assistants respond in unknown languages. Entity uses devices to “watch back.” - **Reversal:** Narrator is the possessed one; “she” is watching to see if the narrator is awake because the entity can’t manifest if observed. Or she’s trying to keep narrator asleep to protect them. ## Character brainstorm - **Narrator (POV):** - Skeptical, detail-oriented (helps build creeping dread through observation). - Vulnerable: insomnia, injury, grief, substance withdrawal, postpartum, recent trauma. - Guilty secret: caused an accident, stole an artifact, lied about a death, etc. - **“She” (focus of the prompt):** - Romantic partner (intimacy heightens violation). - Sister/friend/roommate (more plausible denial, slower recognition). - Caregiver/nurse (power imbalance, confinement). - Could be: normally warm and grounded; possession makes her “too still,” wrong rhythm. - **Secondary cast:** - Neighbor who hears things in the walls; becomes unreliable ally. - Religious figure (priest, imam, folk healer) with ambiguous motives. - Therapist/sleep specialist who offers clinical explanations that fail. - Police / social worker: helps ground the story before it goes supernatural. - **The entity:** - Hungry parasite that learns to mimic “her.” - Ancestral spirit attached to family heirloom; wants continuation. - A “Watcher” that needs eye contact/recognition to cross fully. - Something that can only act when people sleep; hates being seen. - A thing bound to the house, using her as a key. ## Setting options - **Small house with a basement/crawlspace** (classic possession staging; physical “below” mirrors hidden truth). - **Apartment with thin walls** (sound cues; paranoia; limited escape). - **Hospital/home hospice** (constant “sleeping,” medical monitors, dim lighting). - **Rural winter** (isolation, limited help; long nights). - **Coastal town** (folk horror; tides, driftwood, salt rituals). - **Renovation site** (uncovered objects, old letters, sealed rooms). ## Tone + stylistic notes - **Intimate, claustrophobic, observational.** The horror is in small deviations: breath timing, blink rate, the way she holds her jaw. - **Escalation through repetition.** The staring happens nightly, evolves into touch, words, tests, threats. - **Unreliable perception.** Sleep deprivation blurs lines; readers doubt narrator until evidence lands. - **Body horror (light to moderate).** Subtle: dilated pupils, bruises in patterns, cracked lips that don’t heal, voice dissonance. - **Possession rules reveal gradually.** Avoid info-dumping; show through consequences. ## Plot beats / escalation ideas across 8 chapters (wide net) - **Ch1:** Inciting incident: narrator catches her staring; pretends asleep; she whispers something not meant for humans. Morning: she’s normal. - **Ch2:** Pattern: narrator tests (fake snore, sudden movement). She reacts too fast/too slow. First missing time. - **Ch3:** Physical evidence: scratches on doorframe, dirt under nails, salt line broken. Narrator finds hidden object (hair bundle, old coin, tooth). - **Ch4:** Social friction: narrator confronts; she denies, gaslights, or genuinely doesn’t remember. Friend/doctor suggests sleep disorder. Narrator begins recording. - **Ch5:** Recordings show impossible behavior: she stares for hours without blinking, speaks in layered voices, stands over narrator with a bowl/needle. - **Ch6:** Entity’s goal hinted: she tries to get narrator to “accept” it—drink something, say a name, open basement door, look into her eyes. - **Ch7:** Attempted escape/help: priest/healer arrives; ritual partly works but backfires. Twist: entity isn’t in her alone; it’s in the house or in narrator. - **Ch8:** Climactic confrontation at night: narrator pretends asleep one last time; learns the final rule (recognition binds). Choice ending: sacrifice, containment, or tragic merging. ## Possession “rules” brainstorm (choose later) - **Rule of observation:** Entity can’t fully act if directly seen/acknowledged; thus it assumes you’re asleep. The moment you admit you’re awake, it accelerates. - **Rule of invitation:** It needs consent—spoken, written, or via eye contact. Staring is to force consent without words. - **Rule of substitution:** Each night it takes a little more (voice, mannerisms, memories). Eventually “she” is a perfect copy with a missing warmth. - **Rule of anchoring object:** A locket, ring, or old photograph holds it; destroying it frees it into the nearest body. - **Rule of cycles:** Happens at a specific hour (3:33), tied to tides/moon/ventilation system. - **Rule of contagion:** Anyone who watches the recording becomes marked. ## Twist / endings brainstorm - **Tragic:** Narrator wins but loses her (she’s gone), left with an empty body or a shell. - **Bittersweet:** They trap the entity in narrator voluntarily; narrator isolates to protect others. - **Ambiguous:** Morning normalcy returns; last line shows narrator staring at someone else, implying transfer. - **Reverse possession:** Narrator was the vessel all along; “she” was watching to keep the entity contained. - **Cycle continues:** They move houses; staring returns in a new place. ## Pacing considerations over 8 x ~1000 words - **Ch1-2:** Tight, scene-driven, minimal exposition; hook + unease. - **Ch3-4:** Investigative middle; evidence + interpersonal conflict. - **Ch5-6:** Supernatural confirmation; rules/goal emerge; danger rises. - **Ch7:** “All is lost” + twist; stakes widen. - **Ch8:** Focused climax; one big set-piece; ending that lingers. --- # Reflection A possession story works best here when the staring is not just creepy behavior but a *mechanism*: the entity is assessing whether the narrator is conscious, testing boundaries, or trying to force a threshold moment (consent/recognition). The prompt’s intimacy—someone believing you’re asleep—naturally creates a surveillance reversal: the watcher becomes the watched. That’s a strong engine for escalating dread across chapters because it’s repeatable, each time with a new wrinkle. The domestic partner/caregiver route seems most compelling for an 8-chapter short story because it provides both emotional stakes (love, trust, dependency) and practical stakes (shared home, shared bed, limited ability to flee without consequences). A hospital or immobilized narrator intensifies vulnerability, but it can reduce mobility and variety of scenes unless the story leans into institutional horror. An apartment/roommate setting offers plausibility and isolation, but the emotional punch may be lower than a spouse/partner unless their bond is carefully built early. Ambiguity (sleep disorder vs possession) is useful for the first half to keep tension and maintain plausibility; however, by ~chapter 5 the story likely needs hard evidence to avoid reader frustration. Recordings are a natural tool, but they’re also a common trope; to keep them fresh, the recordings should reveal *behavior with a clear purpose* rather than just “she stands and stares.” For example: arranging objects, practicing a phrase, tracing symbols on the narrator’s skin, or reacting to the narrator’s feigned breathing patterns. For possession “rules,” the consent/recognition angle pairs elegantly with staring. It also lets the narrator’s strategy (pretending to sleep) matter: staying “asleep” denies the entity the final step, but also leaves the narrator passive and endangered. The story can build toward the moment the narrator must choose: keep pretending (survive another night) or reveal wakefulness to disrupt/control the ritual (risk immediate escalation). That choice can anchor the climax. Twists should be handled carefully. A “narrator was possessed all along” twist can feel like a rug-pull unless seeded with fair clues (missing time, odd injuries, inconsistencies in narration). A better mid-story twist might be that the entity is not merely in “her” but *using her as a door*—meaning attempts to “save” her could unleash it. That preserves emotional conflict: saving her may doom them both. A tragic or ambiguous ending seems tonally appropriate for possession horror; a clean victory can undercut the lingering dread promised by the prompt’s intimacy. Finally, pacing across eight chapters should avoid “same scene, repeated” syndrome. The staring incidents should evolve: first observation, then interaction, then evidence, then confrontation, then ritual attempt, then inversion (entity anticipates narrator’s tricks). Each chapter should either (1) reveal a new capability/goal of the entity, or (2) deepen the relational stakes between narrator and “she,” ideally both.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention - **Premise choice:** Domestic possession horror centered on intimacy and surveillance reversal: the narrator repeatedly catches his partner, Mara, staring at him at night because she believes he’s asleep. The staring is not incidental—it’s part of a possession “threshold” that requires the victim’s *recognition* (a form of consent) to complete. - **Setting choice:** A small rented house with a sealed/half-finished basement and a recent renovation discovery (a concealed niche containing a charm bundle). Limited cast, claustrophobic spaces; night scenes in the bedroom and basement, day scenes in kitchen/yard/doctor’s office for contrast. - **POV + voice:** Close first-person, present-leaning past (mostly past tense with sharp sensory immediacy). Observational, restrained, increasingly fragmented as sleep deprivation worsens. The narrator is rational and careful, trying to “measure” reality (breathing patterns, timestamps, recordings). - **Tone:** Slow-burn dread that escalates into overt supernatural horror by the midpoint. Emotional undertow: the narrator loves Mara and is terrified of losing her, but also terrified of what she might do. - **Structure goal:** Each chapter advances in at least one of three ways: (1) the entity’s behavior escalates with a new tactic; (2) the narrator gains new evidence/learns a rule; (3) the relationship erodes under secrecy, denial, and fear. - **Possession rules (committed):** 1. The thing acts most freely when it believes you’re asleep/unobserving. 2. It is trying to secure a final step: **direct acknowledgment** (eye contact + spoken confirmation of a name/phrase). Once acknowledged, it can “seat” itself permanently. 3. It is anchored to a **found object** from the house (a charm bundle / “kept” thing). Attempts to destroy it risk releasing it fully. - **What I’m aiming for:** - Repetition with variation: nightly “staring” scenes that evolve from eerie to purposeful to violent. - Concrete, unsettling details (blink timing, whispered consonants, damp footprints, salt lines, odd bruises) rather than gore-first shocks. - A climax built on a choice: keep pretending (temporary safety) vs. confront (risk immediate completion). - **What I’ll avoid:** - Overlong ambiguity past the midpoint—by chapters 4–5 the story will deliver credible proof. - Convenient experts who solve it cleanly. Any “helper” (folk healer) complicates as much as they clarify. - A twist that invalidates earlier events (“it was all a dream”). Sleep deprivation will add uncertainty, but the supernatural will be real. # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1 — “She Thought I’d Been Sleeping” - Open in bed: narrator wakes slightly, catches Mara sitting upright, head angled, staring at him in the dark. - He pretends to sleep; notes wrongness (stillness, breathing out of sync, her eyes too reflective). - Mara whispers something like rehearsal—broken syllables, as if tasting a name. - Morning contrast: she’s warm, normal, affectionate; doesn’t recall being up. - Seed the house-renovation detail: they moved recently; a wall patch, dusty smell; Mara mentions a “weird little bundle” they found and tossed in a drawer. - End beat: narrator resolves to test it—if it happens again, he’ll be ready. ## Chapter 2 — “Tests” - Second night: narrator fakes deeper sleep, changes breathing. Mara appears sooner, as if responding to a cue. - She leans closer, watching his mouth rather than his eyes; her pupils track his exhale. - Narrator twitches intentionally; Mara freezes, then resumes with unnatural smoothness. - Daytime: narrator checks Mara for sleepwalking history; she brushes it off, defensive. - First tangible sign: narrator finds a faint damp print near the bedroom door / dirt under Mara’s nails, which she can’t explain. - Closing: he sets up a phone recording (audio + low-light video), feeling guilty and desperate. ## Chapter 3 — “The House Keeps Things” - Footage is incomplete—mysterious gaps, corrupted frames, but audio catches a layered murmur and a soft knock from below (basement). - Narrator explores basement: finds a sealed niche behind insulation; signs something was recently disturbed. - He finds the “bundle” in their junk drawer: twine, hair, tiny animal bones/teeth, a coin/button—folk-charm vibe. - Mara reacts oddly when he shows it: a micro-flinch, then anger; insists they shouldn’t “mess with it.” - That night: staring returns; this time Mara’s hand traces the narrator’s forearm in repeating shapes (like letters). - End: narrator wakes to discover the traced pattern bruised into his skin, as if pressed from inside. ## Chapter 4 — “Denial in Daylight” - Narrator confronts Mara with bruises + partial audio. She’s shaken but insists it’s him scratching himself, or a bad dream. - A daytime appointment: sleep specialist / GP suggests parasomnia, stress, new-house anxiety; recommends sleep meds. - Narrator refuses meds (fear of being more helpless). Conflict: Mara suggests he take them, too quickly. - Narrator begins practical defenses: salt line at bedroom threshold, a bell on basement door, camera facing the bed. - Night: the camera captures Mara standing over him for a long time, head slowly turning toward the camera—then the file corrupts exactly at that moment. - End: narrator notices salt line smeared from *inside* the room outward, as if something crossed while already “in.” ## Chapter 5 — “Proof” - Narrator stays awake all night, pretending to sleep with eyes barely slitted; sees Mara “switch”—a subtle slackening, then an alertness that isn’t hers. - She speaks clearly now, practicing a phrase: “Say you see me. Say my name.” - He realizes the staring is a *waiting game*—it watches for the instant he acknowledges it. - Day: narrator confides in a neighbor (older, superstitious) who mentions the house’s prior tenant and “keeping bundles” to bind a thing. - Neighbor recommends a local folk healer (not a neat solution, but a direction). - End: Mara catches narrator researching; her face goes blank for a second, and she asks—in a voice slightly off—whether he’s “afraid to look at her.” ## Chapter 6 — “The Threshold” - Folk healer visit: reads the bundle, the house, and Mara’s symptoms. Explains rule: these things need *recognition*; the bundle is an anchor/lock, not just a curse. - Plan: a controlled night ritual—circle, iron/salt, mirrors covered—intended to force the entity to reveal itself without letting it be acknowledged. - Night set-piece: Mara goes rigid, then performs deliberate actions: tries to reposition narrator’s face toward hers; tries to get him to speak. - Entity adapts: mimics Mara’s emotional voice, begging/accusing, trying to lure an instinctive response (“Please, look at me.”). - The healer falters when the entity uses personal memories the healer shouldn’t know. - End: ritual partially “works”—Mara convulses, and for a moment something seems to peel away—then snaps back worse, as if angered. ## Chapter 7 — “All the Ways to Wake Up” - Aftermath: Mara is exhausted, frightened, with missing time. Narrator is torn—he saw “something,” but it’s still wearing her. - Entity’s escalation: daytime bleed-through—Mara stares blankly in sunlight, pauses mid-sentence, repeats the same phrase under her breath. - Narrator decides to remove the anchor: retrieve the bundle and leave the house. The healer warns: destroying it may release the thing; moving it may move the problem. - Attempted escape: packing, car loaded, tension high. At the threshold (front door), Mara stops, eyes fixed, and says, “You can’t take what the house kept.” - Basement bell rings although no one touched it; basement door opens a crack. - End twist: the entity isn’t only in Mara—it’s in the house’s “kept” spaces. Mara is becoming its *mouth*, but the house is its body. ## Chapter 8 — “Recognition” - Final night in the house (or forced return): power goes out; phones die; the house becomes a closed system. - Narrator’s last strategy: he pretends to sleep one final time, but this time he’s prepared—mirror angled, voice recorder rolling, salt/iron placed. - The entity uses Mara’s face inches from his, staring, unblinking, waiting him out. It offers a bargain: “Say you see me, and she stops hurting.” - Climax choice: narrator speaks—not the entity’s name, but **Mara’s** name, anchoring her identity, breaking the forced recognition. Or he refuses speech entirely and uses the bundle as a “lock,” returning it to the niche to rebind the house-thing. - Resolution direction (tragic-ambiguous): the immediate danger abates; Mara survives but is altered—gaps, coldness, a sense of being “watched from behind her eyes.” - Final image mirrors the opener: later, narrator wakes and catches Mara staring again—except now her expression suggests she knows he’s awake, and she’s waiting for him to admit it.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
## How a human might approach this prompt A human writer often starts from *the feeling* embedded in the line: “I caught her staring at me again. She thought I’d been sleeping.” That implies (a) intimacy, (b) repetition, (c) secrecy, and (d) a power imbalance—someone is observed while vulnerable. A human might: - **Latch onto a specific lived context** (a real bed, a real kind of darkness, a real relationship dynamic) and let the horror grow from believable domestic texture rather than from “plot mechanics.” - **Make the narrator complicit** in a small way—choosing not to confront, choosing to watch, choosing to test—because humans do that. The dread comes from the fact that *you can imagine yourself making those choices*. - **Let scenes breathe**: longer silences, mundane interruptions, contradictions in memory, social embarrassment. Horror thrives on what people avoid saying. - **Accept messiness**: not every clue is neat; not every conversation advances the plot; motivations can be muddy. Humans often write to discover, not to execute. - **Pick one or two signature images** and return to them with variation (e.g., the sound of her swallowing in the dark; the way her eyes “find” him). Not eight different “cool horror moments,” but a few deeply felt motifs. In other words: a human might be less concerned with “delivering a rule set” and more concerned with “what would I do at 3:12 a.m. if the person I love was sitting up, staring, like they were waiting for permission to become someone else?” --- ## Telltale LLM approaches (general) and why they may not serve this piece ### Common LLM writing patterns 1. **Over-structured escalation** - Every chapter “must” escalate, reveal, twist. This can feel engineered rather than inevitable. - For this prompt, the scariest thing is the *stillness* and the *uncertainty*—too much constant escalation can blunt that. 2. **“Trope completion” behavior** - LLMs tend to hit a checklist: camera footage, corrupted files, priest/healer, salt lines, 3 a.m. witching hour, etc. - Some of these are fine, but stacking too many reads like a genre-sampler rather than a specific nightmare. 3. **Explanatory compulsion** - LLMs often clarify rules and motivations to avoid ambiguity. - Possession horror benefits from partial comprehension. The reader should feel the narrator’s desperation to understand without fully succeeding. 4. **Safety and neutrality** - Characters behave “reasonably,” conflicts are clean, no one is petty, no one is weirdly in denial in an unflattering way. - Human relationships under stress get ugly: avoidance, misdirection, manipulative reassurance, resentment about chores, libido changes, shame. 5. **Polished prose syndrome** - LLMs can overwrite: too many metaphors, too many “writerly” sentences, uniform rhythm. - This prompt wants *plain, intimate, exact language*—the kind people use when recounting something they can’t explain. 6. **Tidy thematic wrapping** - The ending tends to resolve the “problem” or state the theme explicitly. - For this piece, a bow reduces dread. The best ending likely *echoes* the opener and suggests continuation. 7. **Generic character placeholders** - “Skeptical narrator,” “possessed partner,” “folk healer.” - Humans usually latch onto specificity: the exact job, the shared in-joke, the way someone says “goodnight,” a particular mug, a particular scar. --- ## Deep dive critique of the current intention & plan (where it risks LLM tropes) ### 1) “Rule-based possession” may turn into a system, not a haunting The plan commits to clear rules: observation-limits, recognition-consent, anchor object. That’s coherent—but it risks feeling like a game mechanic: - Entity wants “eye contact + spoken confirmation.” - Anchor object acts as “lock.” - Ritual sequence in Ch6. **Pitfall:** Readers may start anticipating solutions (“don’t look, don’t speak, hide the object”) rather than feeling trapped in a lived situation. Human horror often feels like: “Even the correct choice has a cost,” not “Solve the puzzle.” **Humanizing direction:** Make “rules” *inferred*, contested, and inconsistent. Characters misinterpret. The entity sometimes violates the apparent rule in small ways that feel like it’s learning. ### 2) Familiar genre props cluster together (salt line, corrupted video, folk healer) Salt lines + corrupted footage + folk healer + hidden charm bundle + basement niche + “house keeps things” is a dense concentration of known horror moves. **Pitfall:** Even if executed well, the reader may experience it as a set of expected beats rather than a singular story. **Humanizing direction:** Keep one “genre prop” and make it personal/odd. If you keep the charm bundle, maybe drop the corrupted video cliché—or invert it (video is perfectly clear, which is worse). Or the “healer” is not mystical—maybe a building historian, a hoarder-cleanout specialist, a sleep tech, a midwife—someone real, with their own angle. ### 3) The relationship risks being underwritten (Mara as a vehicle for plot) The plan emphasizes the entity’s tactics, narrator’s tests, and the house lore. Mara’s interiority may become inaccessible (because possession), leaving her as an instrument. **Pitfall:** Without strong pre-possession characterization, the reader doesn’t feel the tragedy—only the creep factor. **Humanizing direction:** Early chapters need lived-in intimacy: a fight about something dumb, shared rituals, their specific way of making up, a memory that later gets “worn” by the entity. Also: Mara’s daytime perspective should be messy—fear, shame, anger at being surveilled, maybe relief that the narrator is “handling it,” then guilt. ### 4) The narrator’s behavior could feel too competent and “plot-serving” He tests breathing, sets cameras, lays salt, consults experts. That’s efficient. **Pitfall:** Humans often do irrational things first: avoid, deny, bargain, try to laugh it off, sleep on the couch, drink more, pick a fight, google in private at work, call their mom, etc. Competence can reduce vulnerability. **Humanizing direction:** Build in contradictory choices: - He doesn’t record the first time because it feels like betrayal. - He tries to initiate intimacy to “prove” she’s herself. - He takes the sleep meds once (big mistake). - He lies to friends about why he’s tired. - He becomes obsessed, cruel, or controlling in a way that’s understandable but unsettling. ### 5) The mid-story “proof” beat may flatten the dread Ch5 confirms the entity and its objective. After that, the story becomes a fight against a defined thing with defined rules. **Pitfall:** Many possession stories are scariest *before* certainty. Once confirmed, the vibe shifts from uncanny to procedural. **Humanizing direction:** Even when “proof” arrives, keep it psychologically ambiguous in *meaning* if not in *fact*. For example, the footage is clear, but what it implies is unclear; or it proves Mara is doing it, but not *why*. ### 6) The house-as-body twist is familiar and may over-explain Ch7 twist: the entity is in the house; Mara is its mouth. That’s effective but known. **Pitfall:** If the story explains this too cleanly, it moves toward lore exposition. **Humanizing direction:** Let the “house wants” remain impressionistic: drafts that feel like breath, doors that “listen,” an acoustical quality. Make the house’s agency felt without naming it. ### 7) The climax “say Mara’s name vs entity’s name” risks sentimentality It’s a strong cinematic move—identity asserted by naming. **Pitfall:** It can feel like a neat thematic bow (“love conquers possession”), even if the ending is ambiguous. **Humanizing direction:** Make the choice uglier: - Saying Mara’s name might *hurt her* (it pulls her back into consciousness during torment). - Refusing recognition might mean letting the entity keep using her. - Saving her might require doing something morally repellent (locking her in, restraining her, calling police, institutionalizing). ### 8) Symmetry with opener is good—but it can feel “designed” Ending mirrors opening: she’s staring again, but now she knows he’s awake. **Pitfall:** Too perfect an echo can feel like a workshop move rather than a real aftermath. **Humanizing direction:** Keep echo but roughen it: the repetition is imperfect, interrupted by something mundane; the narrator’s emotional reaction is not poetic but exhausted, resentful, numb. --- ## Brainstorm: ways to make it feel more human (without rewriting yet) ### A) Intensify specificity (anti-generic texture) - Give them **distinct routines**: she always tucks the duvet under his feet; he always sets the coffee timer; she hums when brushing teeth. The entity imitates imperfectly. - Use **non-horror objects** as anchors: a thrift-store quilt, a white-noise machine, a baby monitor, a cracked phone screen. - Make the discovered “bundle” not obviously occult. Something plausibly trash: a child’s craft, an old rosary knotted with hair, a sealed jar of coins. ### B) Make the relationship dynamic do real work - Add an existing fault line: fertility stress, money, jealousy, caregiver burnout, grief. The entity exploits it. - Include a moment where the narrator wonders, shamefully, whether this is “just Mara” and he’s seeing what he wants to see—fear can turn into suspicion and then cruelty. - Have Mara *accuse him* of controlling behavior (recording, salt lines). That argument can be as scary as the supernatural. ### C) Trade some “mechanics” for human dread - Instead of formal rules, lean on **habit loops**: the entity learns his tells; he learns hers; it becomes a terrible intimacy. - Replace the folk-healer exposition with **piecemeal information**: a neighbor’s offhand remark, an old invoice found in the basement, a voice on a recording that says something barely comprehensible. ### D) Make the narrator’s vulnerability more than “tired” - Sleep deprivation can cause microsleeps, memory gaps, emotional volatility. Let the narrator do things he regrets. - Give him a job situation that amplifies stakes (driving, surgery, machinery) so insomnia becomes dangerous in daylight too. - Consider medication/alcohol as coping—messy, real, shameful. ### E) Subvert one or two expected beats - **Video isn’t corrupted**; it’s clear and banal, which makes it harder to convince anyone because it looks like ordinary sleepwalking—except for one impossible detail. - **Salt doesn’t fail mysteriously**; it works, but it makes Mara bruise/burn, creating moral conflict. - **Healer is wrong** in a crucial way; their “rule” accelerates the possession. - **Basement isn’t the locus**; it’s the attic, or a vent, or the space behind the headboard—closer, more intimate. ### F) Give Mara moments of agency that aren’t plot devices - A daytime note in her handwriting she doesn’t remember writing: not exposition, but fear. - She sets up her own recording because she doesn’t trust herself. - She asks to be restrained at night—then begs to be released (is it her or not?). ### G) Sharpen the “staring” into something uniquely unsettling Rather than generic “unblinking,” make it *behaviorally precise*: - She stares at the narrator’s **lips** as if waiting for speech. - She stares at his **closed eyelids**, like she’s learning how to wear them. - She stares at the **space above his head**, reacting to something he can’t see. - She stares with **tiny mimicry errors**: blinking slightly late, smiling without cheeks, tracking breaths a half-second behind. ### H) Let social reality intrude (and fail) - A friend stays over and sees nothing—except they wake with muddy feet. - Police wellness check becomes humiliating and dangerous. - Work performance review, missed family event, landlord visit—mundane pressures that increase the trap feeling. ### I) Endings that feel “human aftermath” rather than “horror punchline” - They don’t “win”; they adapt: separate bedrooms, taped eyelids (disturbing), rigid routines. - They relocate, but the narrator realizes the possession has rewired *their trust*, which is irreversible. - Mara is back, mostly—but there’s a new rule in their relationship: no one pretends to sleep anymore. --- ## Targeted “LLM-to-human” checklist for this project If you want the eventual prose to read human, aim for: - **Fewer explained concepts, more observed contradictions.** - **More interpersonal mess** (betrayal of recording her, fights, apologies that don’t land). - **One or two fresh images** repeated with variation rather than many different scary set-pieces. - **Uneven pacing on purpose:** one chapter might be mostly an argument or a failed attempt to be normal. - **Moral discomfort:** the narrator’s “solutions” should cost something real (trust, dignity, Mara’s safety). If you want, I can next produce a list of concrete scene ideas per chapter that inject this kind of human mess and specificity—still without rewriting the plan, just additions/options.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention - **Core commitment to the prompt:** The story is built around repeated, escalating instances of the narrator waking to find his partner, Mara, **staring at him because she believes he’s asleep**. Each recurrence changes slightly—new purpose, new proximity, new “test”—so the prompt line remains the spine of the piece, not just an opening hook. - **Approach:** Human, intimate domestic horror rather than “lore puzzle.” The possession is real, but knowledge about it remains partial, contested, and costly. The horror comes as much from **betrayal, caregiving strain, and secrecy** as from supernatural phenomena. - **Setting:** A rented older house mid-renovation, chosen for its mundane stressors (money, dust, drafts, landlord visits) and intimate spaces (hallway, bedroom, basement steps). The house isn’t a sentient monster in an explained way; it’s a place with “kept” cavities, bad airflow, and history that leaks through sensation and behavior. - **Characters (tight cast):** - **Narrator (Eli):** Tired, practical, avoidant of conflict; loving but capable of control when frightened. His choices will sometimes be wrong or ugly (surveillance, restraint, silence). - **Mara:** Normally warm, opinionated, bodily present (touchy, expressive). Under possession she becomes “wrong” in small specific ways (timing, mimicry errors), and in daylight she is frightened, ashamed, and angry about what Eli is doing to “handle” her. - **Optional minor:** A neighbor (not a guru, just a person with local memory) and/or a sleep-clinic nurse (grounding realism). No clean “expert solution.” - **Possession concept (kept impressionistic):** - It operates best when it believes the narrator is asleep/unwitnessing. - It fixates on **recognition**—not a neat magic phrase, but the human act of meeting a gaze and responding. It wants Eli to *answer it as Mara*. - An object discovered during renovation (not obviously occult at first) is an “anchor,” but removing/destroying it isn’t a clear win—any action has a price. - **Style:** Close first-person with sensory specificity, plainspoken but sharp. Avoid ornate metaphor. Let scenes breathe: arguments, quiet mornings, humiliating practicalities. Repeat a few motifs (breath-counting, the mattress dip, her pupils tracking his mouth, house sounds) instead of piling on genre props. - **What to aim for:** - Escalation through **intimacy and adaptation** (the entity learns Eli’s tells; Eli learns Mara’s “errors”). - Relationship realism: denial, fights, apologies that don’t fix things, the shame of not being believed, the guilt of watching someone you love like a threat. - A climax that forces a **morally compromising choice**, not a clever solve. - **What to avoid:** - Checklist horror (salt lines, corrupted footage, tidy rules, exposition-heavy rituals). - Over-explaining the entity or the house. - A sentimental “love saves her” wrap-up. The ending should echo the prompt’s dread and leave a residue. --- # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1 — The Second Time I Saw It - Open with the prompt moment: Eli jolts awake and catches Mara **staring** from her side of the bed—upright, too still, gaze fixed not on his eyes but on his **mouth**, as if waiting for sound. - He pretends to sleep out of reflex (fear + not wanting to accuse her). He listens to her breathing: it doesn’t match the posture. - Small, specific wrongness: she blinks slightly late; her lips part as if testing the shape of his name without speaking it. - Morning: Mara is herself—complains about renovation dust, kisses him, jokes about his snoring. Eli considers telling her, can’t. The silence becomes the first betrayal. - Seed the mundane stress: they’re over budget, living among tools and half-painted trim; Mara found “something wrapped” in the wall and put it in a kitchen drawer because it was “gross.” - End: That night, Eli lies awake longer than usual, telling himself he’s being stupid—then feels the mattress shift again. ## Chapter 2 — Pretending - The staring repeats. Eli experiments without fully admitting he’s experimenting: changes his breathing, swallows on purpose. Mara’s gaze tracks these micro-signals with unnerving precision. - She whispers a soft, almost tender “Hey,” like checking if he’ll answer. Eli stays still. The silence feels like a decision. - Daylight conflict seed: Mara notices he’s exhausted and distant; assumes it’s money stress. Eli almost confesses, then asks indirectly about sleepwalking. Mara bristles—she hates being treated like a problem. - A mundane but eerie discovery: fine plaster dust on Mara’s bare feet though she swears she didn’t go downstairs; a smear on the bedroom doorframe at mouth height, like someone leaned there. - End: Eli, ashamed, sets his phone on the dresser—not to “catch her,” he tells himself, but to prove to himself he isn’t losing it. ## Chapter 3 — Evidence That Doesn’t Help - The recording isn’t a horror-movie jackpot. It shows mostly darkness, an audio track of long quiet minutes, the faint sound of someone sitting up… and then a low murmur too close to the mic to be across the room. - The audio catches a phrase fragment that could be Mara’s voice but isn’t shaped like her: something like **“answer me”** or **“say it back.”** - Eli’s reaction is human and messy: relief (he’s not imagining it), then immediate dread because proof doesn’t tell him what to do. - He confronts Mara clumsily. She’s horrified at first—then offended when she realizes he recorded her. The fight is about trust, not demons. She demands he delete it. He lies and says he did. - That night, after an uneasy “truce,” Mara’s staring is closer. She rests her hand on his cheek—too careful, like learning skin. Eli’s body wants to lean into it. He doesn’t. - End: In the morning, Eli finds a faint thumbprint bruise along his jawline, exactly where she held him. ## Chapter 4 — Daylight Leaks - Mara begins noticing gaps: waking sore, hands raw, a bruise on her own wrist she can’t explain. She’s frightened but too proud to admit vulnerability; she asks Eli if he’s been sleeping at all. - Eli considers sleep meds from a clinic (grounded scene: nurse asks routine questions; Eli lies to sound sane). He doesn’t take them—fear of being helpless. - A neighbor interaction: casual, not mystical. The neighbor mentions the previous tenant was “a wall-fixer,” always patching things, and that this house “holds drafts like it holds grudges.” Just enough to suggest history without explanation. - Mara, trying to regain control, proposes practical steps (lock the basement door, stop leaving tools out). She wants normal solutions. Eli wants certainty. - Night: Eli pretends to sleep and feels Mara’s hair fall forward as she leans in. She doesn’t stare at his face this time—she stares at his **closed eyelids**, like she’s studying how to wear them. - End: She whispers, right at his ear, “I know when you’re listening.” Eli almost answers by mistake. ## Chapter 5 — The Thing It Wants - The possession becomes purposeful. The nightly routine includes prompts: gentle attempts to elicit response (“Eli?” “Babe?”), then a shift—voice flattening, choosing simpler words, less Mara-like. - Eli learns the entity is not hunting violence first; it’s hunting **interaction**. It wants him to confirm it, to treat it as a person in the room. - Daytime: Mara’s shame surfaces. She asks, small-voiced, whether she’s doing something to him at night. She can’t hold the vulnerability long—anger returns when Eli hesitates. - Eli shows her a piece of audio (not all of it). She listens, face changing, and says, “That isn’t me.” Then immediately: “Why didn’t you wake me?” - That night, the entity tries a new tactic: it uses Mara’s real emotional tone—apology, pleading—because it has learned what Eli can’t resist. Eli realizes love is the lever. - End: He wakes to find Mara on the floor by the bed, awake and confused, as if she has “come to” mid-gesture. She looks at him and asks, terrified, “What did I say?” ## Chapter 6 — The Kept Thing - They finally look at what was found in the wall: not a dramatic occult bundle, but a **small wrapped packet** of hair, a button, and a folded note so old the ink has bled. The note is mostly illegible—only a few words recur: **KEEP / DO NOT ANSWER / SLEEP** (or similarly fragmentary). - Mara wants to throw it out immediately. Eli wants to keep it because it’s the only concrete thing they have. Another fight: control vs fear. - Mara confesses something personal that makes the possession sharper: she’s been feeling watched in the house even before the staring started; she thought it was anxiety and didn’t want to be “that person.” - Night escalation: the entity uses the packet as a focal point—Mara’s sleep-self carries it into the bedroom, sets it on Eli’s chest like an offering, then stares as if waiting for him to acknowledge the exchange. - Eli experiences a near-failure: he almost speaks, almost asks “Mara?” out loud. He clamps down hard, biting his own tongue (grounded physicality). - End: In the morning there’s blood on his pillow. Mara sees it and breaks—fear overtakes pride. She asks him not to leave her alone in the house. ## Chapter 7 — Ugly Measures - They attempt a “normal” fix: sleep in separate rooms, lights on, door wedges, maybe Mara straps her own wrist to the bedframe with a scarf (her idea, then her shame). It’s desperate, not theatrical. - Eli’s behavior turns controlling: he hides keys, he moves the packet, he watches her too closely in daylight. Mara resents him—rightfully—while also needing him. Their relationship becomes another cage. - The entity adapts: it doesn’t need the shared bed anymore. It uses the house’s ordinary noises to keep Eli in a state between waking and sleep—pipes, settling wood, a rhythmic knock that matches his pulse. - A pivotal scene: Eli wakes on the couch to find Mara standing in the doorway, staring again. She says, calmly, “You can hear me.” It’s not a question. - Eli makes the worst, most human choice: he speaks to her—just a “Mara, stop”—out of exhaustion and love and anger. The moment he answers, her face changes: relief, possession’s satisfaction, like a lock turning. - End: Morning arrives with Mara “fine,” too fine—too bright, too present. She remembers nothing. Eli realizes his response may have moved them closer to something irreversible. ## Chapter 8 — Recognition - Final night set-piece built from intimacy, not spectacle. Eli decides he will not repeat the mistake: he will not answer, no matter what voice he hears. But he also cannot keep living like this. - Mara (or what wears her) sits up and stares for a long time—patient, intimate, as if it has all night and all their life. It speaks with careful simplicity: “Look at me.” Then: “Say it.” - Eli tries to avoid eye contact, but the room is small, the bed smaller. He sees enough: Mara’s pupils tracking his mouth; the slight lag in blinking; the way her smile doesn’t reach the muscles it should. - The moral-choice climax: - Option A (bleak containment): Eli returns the packet to the wall cavity (re-sealing the “kept” place) while Mara watches, and he accepts that their life will be defined by keeping—by secrecy, by never answering at night. - Option B (costly rupture): Eli wakes Mara fully—shaking her, turning on lights, forcing confrontation—risking that the entity can act in wakefulness now that he answered once, but refusing the intimate trap. This may involve calling for help/police/hospital, destroying trust to save her body. - Resolution aims for residue: not a clean win. Mara survives, but their intimacy is altered. Sleep becomes a contested space. - Final image echoes the prompt with a rough edge: weeks later, Eli wakes and catches Mara staring—except now she’s already crying, or already smiling, and she says something mundane (“Are you awake?”) that lands like a blade because he no longer knows who is asking.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Eli Rourke (narrator) **Background** - 32. Grew up in a small town where problems were handled quietly and practically—fix it yourself, don’t make a scene. Father was a competent, withholding man; mother a chronic worrier who apologized as a reflex. - Works as an **audio editor** for podcasts/ads (mostly remote). This matters: he’s good at hearing tiny inconsistencies, isolating frequencies, looping a sound until it confesses what it is. He trusts recordings more than people’s memories—including his own. - Moved into the rental with Mara after a rushed decision: her previous lease ended; their old place got sold. The move felt like “momentum” rather than choice, and he still resents that he didn’t push back. **Personality** - Observant, conflict-avoidant, and quietly stubborn. He tries to be the calm one, but his calm is sometimes just delay. - Has a private streak: he’d rather Google something at 2 a.m. than ask a friend for help at noon. - Humor style: dry, underplayed. When anxious, he makes small jokes that land wrong and then he doubles down instead of apologizing. **Idiosyncrasies (grounding details)** - Counts things when stressed: breaths, steps to the bathroom, seconds between the fridge cycling. He tells himself it’s “just focus,” but it’s a compulsion. - Keeps old receipts in a drawer “in case.” Mara teases him about it; he pretends not to care, but he does. - Sleeps with one foot outside the blanket unless it’s very cold; says he runs hot. Mara calls it “your escape hatch.” - When thinking, he rubs his thumbnail along the edge of his bottom lip until it goes raw. **Flaws** - Avoids direct confrontation until he’s cornered—then can become controlling fast (recording Mara, hiding keys, moving objects without asking). - Can treat emotions like problems to solve, which makes Mara feel unseen. - Pride: he hates being the “hysterical” one. He edits his own story in real time so it sounds reasonable. **Physicality** - Medium height, slight runner’s build that’s gone softer since the move. Looks more tired than he is at first glance—deep-set eyes, quick shadows under them. - Dresses for comfort and invisibility: dark tees, worn hoodie, sneakers he keeps meaning to replace. - Movement: quiet, economical. He closes doors without latching them (a habit from recording at home). In tense scenes his body gets still—like he’s trying not to disturb air. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Primary motive: protect Mara without humiliating her; protect himself without admitting he’s afraid. Those motives conflict. - Allegiance: fundamentally to Mara, but his fear tempts him toward allegiance to *control* and *certainty*. - Relationship with Mara: two years together, living together for eight months. They’re affectionate and physically comfortable—touch on the passing, shared coffee tastes, a shorthand language—until stress makes Eli retreat into quiet observation. - Relationship with the house: sees it as a to-do list (patch, paint, fix), then as a witness, then as an accomplice. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “If I can hear it clearly, I can name it. If I can name it, it stops being… whatever this is. That’s how it works. That’s how it has to work.” - *Dialogue:* “I’m not saying you did it on purpose. I’m saying it happened. There’s a difference. Mara—please, don’t make me sound insane just because you don’t remember.” --- # Mara Sayegh **Background** - 30. Raised by a mother who handled stress with competence and sarcasm; father drifted in and out. Learned early to be the one who *moves things forward*. - Works as a **project coordinator** for a construction-related firm (or events/logistics—anything deadline-driven). She’s used to chaos, used to being the person who remembers the missing piece. - She’s the one who pushed to take the rental quickly—because that’s how she survives uncertainty: make a decision, deal with consequences later. **Personality** - Warm, tactile, blunt in a way that usually feels honest, not mean. She likes clarity. She hates tiptoeing. - Proud and allergic to pity. If she’s struggling, she’d rather make a joke than ask for comfort. - Protective of her autonomy. The idea of being “managed” by Eli (or anyone) hits a nerve, even when she’s scared. **Idiosyncrasies (grounding details)** - Has “systems” for everything: keys always in the same bowl; shoes lined up; spice jars turned label-out. The rental house disrupts her—she can’t get it to behave. - Eats the same breakfast for months (yogurt, honey, almonds), then abruptly can’t stand it and switches without explanation. - When she’s thinking, she presses her tongue to the inside of her cheek; Eli can tell she’s about to argue when she does it. - Keeps a playlist called “Get It Done” that she swears isn’t cheesy. It is. **Flaws** - Control as comfort: when afraid, she gets directive, dismissive, or sharp. She can bulldoze rather than listen. - Shame response: if she feels exposed or accused, she swings to anger quickly. - Difficulty resting: she doesn’t know how to “do nothing” without feeling guilty, so she pushes through tiredness until she breaks. **Physicality** - Dark hair she wears up messily at home; when stressed she twists it tighter and tighter until she gets a headache. - Expressive face and hands; talks with her palms. Makes intense eye contact normally—so when the possession turns her gaze into something unhuman, it’s especially violating. - Stance: planted, confident. Even in pajamas she carries herself like she’s mid-task. When frightened, she goes very still before she reacts. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Primary motive: keep their life intact—job, relationship, sense of self. She wants a solution that doesn’t require her to be “the problem.” - Allegiance: to Eli and to her own dignity. She refuses to be reduced to a case study, even by the person she loves. - Relationship with Eli: she loves his steadiness, but sometimes experiences it as avoidance. She wants him to *show up*—emotionally, verbally—not just observe. - Relationship with the house: she wants it to be a home she can organize and “tame.” The house resisting that—through mess, drafts, noises—feels personal long before it turns supernatural. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “Don’t look at me like I’m fragile. I can be scared and still be me. I can be scared and still be in charge of my own body.” - *Dialogue:* “You recorded me. While I was asleep. Do you understand how that sounds? I’m not even mad about the weird part—I’m mad you didn’t trust me enough to wake me.” --- # The Presence (the “answer-me” thing) **Background / nature (kept partial, character-facing rather than encyclopedic)** - Not a demon-with-a-name in the story’s language; more like a **hunger for acknowledgement** that has learned to wear human habits. - It has been “kept” in the house’s cavities—sealed spaces, patched walls, places where things get hidden rather than thrown away. It’s less an architect of evil and more a parasite of intimacy. - It’s patient. It doesn’t rush; it iterates. It learns what works. **Personality (as it presents)** - Mimicry with errors. It can produce warmth but doesn’t understand it; it performs tenderness like a costume. - Curious, not playful. Its curiosity is invasive—medical, predatory, almost bureaucratic: *confirm the status, confirm the response*. - When thwarted, it doesn’t explode theatrically; it gets simpler and more direct. **Idiosyncrasies (grounding details in behavior)** - Fixates on thresholds: the moment before speech, the moment before waking, the half-second after a breath changes. - Looks at mouths and eyelids more than eyes, like it’s studying the machinery of being human. - Uses short phrases. Repeats them to sand down resistance: “Hey.” “Look.” “Say it.” It doesn’t improvise well at first; later it borrows Mara’s emotional cadences. **Flaws / limitations** - Needs interaction; it can’t complete itself in solitude. If no one answers, it stalls—becoming more desperate, more present, risking exposure. - Overlearns: when it finds a lever (love, guilt, shame) it pulls it too hard, too often, which creates patterns Eli can anticipate. - It underestimates the ugliness humans will do to avoid giving in (biting tongues, destroying trust, restraining someone they love). **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: to be recognized as real in a way that grants it purchase—an “I see you” that makes it harder to deny, harder to expel. It wants a place in the living world that isn’t just hiding. - Allegiance: to itself only. It uses Mara’s body because it’s available and intimate, and because Eli’s love makes him susceptible. - Relationship to Mara: instrument and battleground. It exploits her normal directness (eye contact, blunt speech) but cannot replicate her fully. - Relationship to Eli: a lockpick. It studies his restraint and aims to convert it into speech. **Voice samples** - *As it sounds through Mara (dialogue):* “You can hear me. Don’t pretend. It’s rude.” - *As a near-thought Eli senses in its pauses (implied interior):* “Answer. Confirm. Let me in the part of you that speaks without thinking.”

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I caught her staring at me again. She thought I’d been sleeping. For a moment my mind tried to fit it into something ordinary—Mara checking the time, Mara listening for the house settling, Mara wondering if I’d stopped breathing the way she did when she had nightmares and woke with her hand on my chest. The shape of her in the dark was familiar enough to let me lie there without moving. The part of me that wanted it to be nothing grabbed hold of that familiarity like a rope. Then she leaned forward and the mattress gave that small, specific dip it only makes when someone shifts their weight toward you, and I felt the air change along my upper lip the way you feel a hand hover close without touching. Her eyes weren’t on my eyes. They were on my mouth. In the slice of streetlight bleeding through the blinds, I could see the wet shine at her lower lash line. Not tears. Just the natural gloss of an eye kept too open. I waited for her to blink. She didn’t. I waited for her to breathe like she always did in sleep, soft and through her nose with a faint hitch on the exhale. Her breathing, if that’s what it was, came in shallow sips. Like someone trying not to make a sound. My throat tightened. I swallowed. The swallow sounded loud in my own head, the way it does when you’re paying attention on purpose. Her gaze tracked the motion, down and up again, following the bulge of my throat with an attention that felt wrong, like a finger pressed to a bruise. If I opened my eyes fully and met her stare—if I said her name—I didn’t know what would happen. That thought arrived complete, as if it had been waiting right behind my teeth. So I did the coward’s thing. I stayed still and let my eyelids rest in the soft, heavy half-lid they fell into when I was tired. I let my breathing go slow, even, a little exaggerated. I gave her the performance she wanted. The sheets under my fingers were damp from sweat; the house ran warm at night even though the radiator clanked and complained. The smell of plaster dust had gotten into everything since we started sanding the trim in the hall. It clung to fabric and skin. It should have been comforting, that familiar construction smell, the smell of work you can see the end of. Mara’s face hovered above mine, close enough that I could make out the faint shadow where she’d missed a spot shaving under her jaw. A detail so normal my brain tried to latch onto it. She didn’t have makeup on; she never did at night. Her hair was loose, falling forward in a dark curtain. Her lips parted. Not in a smile. Not in a yawn. Just enough to show a sliver of teeth, the way someone does when they’re about to speak but aren’t sure the words will come out right. “Hey,” she whispered. It wasn’t her daytime hey, bright and quick like a knock on a door. It was a testing sound, gentle in a way that felt studied. My heart started to beat hard, slow, like it was pushing against something thick. I kept my breathing steady. In for four, out for six. An old trick from the one year I’d convinced myself running would make my life make sense. She waited. I could feel the waiting, the weight of it, like a hand held open over my face. The pressure in the room changed. My ears caught the house’s small noises—the distant click of the fridge cycling, the faint ticking of a pipe cooling, a car passing wet tires on the street. Mara’s eyes did something subtle. They didn’t move much, but they narrowed the tiniest degree, as if focusing. And again, that focus wasn’t on the place where my eyes were hiding. It was on my mouth, on the softness of it, the potential. I felt my tongue press against my front teeth. The urge to say, What? The urge to say, Mara? The urge to laugh and ruin it, to turn it into a joke, to make it normal with a word. She shifted, just a fraction, and her hand came up. I could see it in the dim light—pale against the sheet, fingers long, nails bitten down the way they always were when she had too much on her plate. Her hand hovered over my face. Hovered. Not touching. She was close enough now that I could smell her breath. It wasn’t bad. It was faintly sweet, the ghost of the mint gum she chewed before bed. But underneath it there was something stale, like the air when you open a cabinet that hasn’t been used in a while. Her fingertips brushed the corner of my mouth. It was so light I could have convinced myself it was an accident, a sleep twitch. But it wasn’t a twitch. It was deliberate. Two fingers, the pads dragging gently along the line where lip meets skin, like she was tracing the edge of something. My skin prickled. Every muscle in me wanted to pull back. I didn’t. “Eli,” she whispered. My name, but not in the way she said it when she was waking me up for work. Not in the way she said it when she was half-asleep and affectionate. This was careful. Trying it on. I could hear the sound of my blood in my ears. The room felt too small. The space between her face and mine felt like a corridor narrowing. Her hand slid down from my mouth to my chin, then paused, holding my jaw with a pressure that wasn’t cruel but wasn’t absent either. Like checking the weight of a thing. I kept my eyes down. The urge to flinch came in waves. She let go. After a long second, she sat back. The mattress shifted again. The air moved as she pulled away. I waited for her to lie back down, for the sheets to rustle in that familiar pattern, for her breath to resume its sleepy rhythm. Instead she sat there, upright, still. Just looking. At my face, my mouth, the rise and fall of my chest. Watching the lie of my sleep the way you watch a stove to see if the flame catches. I don’t know how long it went on. A minute can feel like ten when you’re counting. When I realized my hands were clenched under the blanket, I forced my fingers to relax one by one. My palm was slick with sweat. Eventually she lay down. She didn’t sigh, didn’t settle into the mattress the way she always did with a small sound of comfort, like letting herself go. She lowered herself carefully, as if not to wake me. Her hair fell back across her pillow. And then her breathing changed, like a switch had been flipped, and she was asleep. The next morning she was in the kitchen before I was fully awake, barefoot on the cold tile, humming tunelessly as she loaded the dishwasher. Her hair was in a messy knot. She wore my old university sweatshirt, the one with paint specks on the sleeve, and she moved with that brisk purpose that made me feel like she was always a step ahead of the day. “Morning,” she called without looking up. “Coffee’s on. Don’t complain, I used the good grounds this time.” My throat felt rough. When I spoke my voice came out flat. “Morning.” Mara turned, leaned her hip against the counter, and smiled. In daylight her face was all familiar angles and warmth. She had a faint crease between her eyebrows from squinting at her phone. There was a tiny nick on her thumb where she’d caught herself on the box cutter yesterday. “You look like you got hit by a truck,” she said, not unkindly. “Did you sleep at all?” I watched her hands as she spoke.
