Mara sits in her car in damp scrubs, shaking now that it’s over. - Final echo of the prompt: not a quip, but a bitter fact—Mara (or Tess) thinks it: they picked a woman whose whole job is noticing what people miss, staying calm when others scream, and doing what needs doing. **They fucked with the wrong babysitter.**
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Mara Vance **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - Late 20s. EMT for 5–6 years. Babysits on the side because her paycheck disappears into rent, student loans from an unfinished nursing program, and her mom’s periodic “emergencies.” - Grew up in a house where you didn’t get comfort, you got *handled*: problems were managed, not talked about. She learned to “be useful” as a way of earning safety. - Personality: steadiness with a thin vein of impatience. In crisis she’s lucid and almost gentle; outside crisis she can be blunt, prickly, and tired of people’s performative politeness. - Idiosyncrasies: - Counts respirations without thinking—at red lights, in line at the store, listening to someone talk. - Checks exits in any room. Not paranoid, just habituated. - Keeps her hair tie on her wrist like it’s part of her body; when it’s missing she touches her wrist, annoyed. - Uses medical language as a shield when she’s scared (“You’re hyperventilating” instead of “It’s going to be okay.”). - Flaws (meant to cost her): - **Over-responsibility**: she takes ownership of outcomes that aren’t hers; it makes her brave but also reckless. - **Pride**: she hates being dismissed as “just” anything; she’ll escalate rather than beg. - **Avoidance of vulnerability**: she can talk to a bleeding stranger better than she can ask a friend for help. - Makes one key error under pressure: delays moving the kids because she wants to believe the hiding spot will work—because she wants *one thing* to be easy. **Physicality** - Average height, compact build from lifting stretchers. Strong hands with faint scars and perpetually dry knuckles from sanitizer. - Hair usually yanked back; a few strands always escape and stick to sweat. Under-eye shadows from night shifts. - Moves with purposeful economy—no wasted steps. When she’s listening, her face goes still; when she’s deciding, her jaw tightens once. - Touch is careful: she doesn’t “pet” kids, she anchors them with a hand on a shoulder, a fingertip on a wrist to feel pulse. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Primary motive: keep Rowan and Lily alive through the night, then keep them from being used again. Her sense of “care duty” becomes identity-level. - Secondary motive (quieter, more personal): she refuses to be made into a disposable witness. She’s seen how systems label people—“hysterical,” “unreliable”—and she won’t let that be the story. - Allegiances: to Tess (earned trust), to the kids (chosen), to her own code (don’t leave people behind). - Relationship stance toward the parents: initially professional and mildly judgmental; after the attack, complicated—she may resent their secrecy while still protecting their children. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “Breathe in with me. You don’t get to fall apart yet. You can fall apart later. Later is a real place if you keep moving.” - *Dialogue:* “I’m not your employee. I’m not your problem to tidy up. I’m the person between you and those kids—and you’re going to have to go through me to get cute.” --- # Rowan Hale **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - 11 years old, old enough to understand danger but young enough to personalize it. Raised in a high-control, high-image house: praise when he performs, distance when he complicates. - Personality: observant, dry humor as armor, desperate to be “helpful” so adults won’t get angry. He’s the kid who watches faces more than cartoons. - Idiosyncrasies: - Collects little facts (codes, routines, the way his dad taps his ring) and stores them like evidence. - When scared, he narrates quietly under his breath—like commentary—because it makes him feel in control. - Chews the inside of his cheek until it’s raw. - Flaws: - **Freeze response**: when the moment comes, he can go blank. - **Loyalty conflict**: he withholds the office-code clue at first because admitting he knows feels like betraying his father. - Can lash out verbally when ashamed—sharp, unfair words that he regrets immediately. **Physicality** - Thin limbs, slightly too-tall for his clothes—growth-spurt stage. T-shirt collars stretched from fidgeting. - Big eyes that track movement; shoulders hunch when adults speak sharply. - Hands always doing something: picking at a cuticle, twisting a hoodie string, tapping rhythms on his thigh. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: keep Lily safe; prove he’s not “useless”; avoid being blamed. He wants adults to say, sincerely, “You did good.” - Allegiances: primarily to Lily; secondarily to his dad (habitual loyalty), which fractures under pressure; gradually transfers trust to Mara because she tells him the truth in manageable pieces. - Relationship to Lily: protective but impatient; he’s half-sibling, half-mini-parent. - Relationship to Mara: starts skeptical (“you’re not family”) → becomes dependent → ends with a fierce, complicated gratitude. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “Don’t cry. If you cry, she’ll look at you like you’re another problem. Problems get left.” - *Dialogue:* “He’s not—he’s not a bad dad. He just… he just doesn’t like mess. And I’m—” (swallows) “I’m kind of a mess.” --- # Lily Hale **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - 6 years old. Asthma that’s mostly controlled but spikes with cold air, panic, and dust—i.e., exactly tonight. - Personality: bright, stubbornly affectionate, unexpectedly brave in short bursts. She senses adult fear and tries to “fix it” with closeness. - Idiosyncrasies: - Names objects when she’s nervous (the flashlight becomes “Spark,” the inhaler is “Blue Rocket”). - Hums when told to be quiet—then clamps her own mouth with both hands, offended at herself. - Has a “story rule”: the hero has to be scared first, otherwise it’s fake. - Flaws: - Loud at the worst times—can’t modulate fear quietly. - Takes things literally; a careless line can haunt her. - When she can’t breathe, she spirals into “I’m bad/I’m in trouble,” which worsens the attack. **Physicality** - Small, quick, hair in a messy ponytail that falls out. Knees always bruised. - Wide mouth, expressive eyebrows. Hands always reaching for someone’s sleeve. - When she’s wheezing, her whole body becomes effort—shoulders lifting, eyes glassy, chest tight. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: safety through proximity—she wants to be held, counted, reassured. She also wants Rowan not to be mad at her. - Allegiances: whoever is calmest in the room. That becomes Mara. - Relationship to Rowan: adores him and also needles him; she’s used to him being her barometer. - Relationship to Mara: fast attachment—Mara becomes “the grown-up who knows what to do.” **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “If I’m good, it will stop. If I’m very, very good, the air will come back.” - *Dialogue:* (whisper-shout) “Mara. Mara. I can be quiet. I can. Tell me what kind of quiet. Like mouse quiet or like statue quiet?” --- # Tess Donnelly **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - Early 30s, paramedic. Worked with Mara long enough to know when Mara’s “fine voice” means disaster. - Background: grew up in a big family where everyone yelled and loved at the same volume. She’s comfortable with conflict and has a pragmatic ethics: do what works, then process later. - Personality: bluntly warm, fast humor, but not frivolous. She’s the person who will break rules for the right reason—and then lecture you about it. - Idiosyncrasies: - Keeps cough drops and spare socks in every pocket like a magician. - Talks to equipment (“Come on, sweetheart”) and to cars (“Don’t you die on me here”). - When thinking, she braids and re-braids her hair. - Flaws: - **Overconfidence in her read of people**; she can underestimate how deep corruption goes. - **Protectiveness that turns controlling**—she can push Mara too hard to “be smart,” when Mara needs empathy. - Sometimes uses jokes to bulldoze pain instead of naming it. **Physicality** - Solid, capable build; looks like she can lift anything because she can. Freckles, weathered hands. - Carries herself wide—claims space. Makes direct eye contact; doesn’t fidget. - Facial expressions are readable: disgust, amusement, tenderness all show quickly. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: keep Mara alive and out of prison; keep the kids safe because she can’t stand the idea of them being harmed while adults posture. - Allegiances: Mara first. The job/department second (and only insofar as it serves people). - Relationship with Mara: work-wife energy without romance—shared gallows humor, mutual respect, occasional tension because Tess will call Mara out. - Relationship to authority: skeptical but functional; she knows how to speak “official” when needed, and hates having to. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “I’ve seen blood dry on a child’s shirt. I don’t need the rest of the story to know what side I’m on.” - *Dialogue:* “Listen to me—don’t do the lone-wolf thing. That’s not bravery, that’s pride with a nicer name.” --- # Bennett Crowley **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - Late 40s to 50s. Local power broker: developer, investor, civic board member—always photographed shaking hands. He’s made a life out of being the guy who “gets things done.” - Background: came from modest means and never got over it; now he treats respectability like armor and debt like a leash for others. - Personality: courteous, patient, contemptuous beneath the polish. He doesn’t yell unless he’s losing; his cruelty is managerial. - Idiosyncrasies: - Always smells faintly of expensive soap and coffee—cleanliness as dominance. - Calls people by their first name too often, like it’s a claim (“Mara. Mara. Let’s be reasonable.”). - Straightens objects when upset—aligns a pen, squares a napkin. - Flaws: - **Underestimation**: he genuinely believes “help” can’t bite him. - **Image addiction**: he can’t resist correcting narratives in public, which creates the opening Mara needs. - When cornered, he becomes petulant—his entitlement shows. **Physicality** - Fit in a “time and money” way: tailored suit, good posture, careful grooming. - Hands are soft but his grip is practiced; he touches shoulders like a pastor, not a friend. - Smile arrives before warmth—teeth first, eyes later (if at all). **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: retrieve/erase the ledger and personal proof tied to a death; keep his network intact; keep his name clean. He doesn’t think in terms of guilt—only risk. - Allegiances: to himself, to the machine he built. He sees people as assets and liabilities. - Relationship with the Hales: “partner” with leverage; he likely bankrolled their lifestyle, making them dependent. He feels ownership. - Relationship with law enforcement: transactional. He doesn’t think of it as corruption; he thinks of it as “community stability.” **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “A babysitter is a logistical detail. Logistics do not get to ruin men like me.” - *Dialogue:* “You’ve had a frightening night, Mara. I don’t blame you for improvising. But now the adults will handle it—hand me what you took, and you can go back to your little life.” --- # Rook (intruder / crew lead) **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - Mid 30s. Not a mastermind—an implementer. Ex-security or ex-something adjacent; he learned procedures and the comfort of orders. - Personality: controlled, pragmatic, emotionally flat in the moment. He’s the kind of man who says “nothing personal” and means it. - Idiosyncrasies: - Counts with his fingers inside his pocket—steps, minutes, rooms. - Doesn’t run unless forced; walks like he owns the clock. - Avoids stepping on toys as if it’s superstition—tiny respect for the domestic, or fear of it. - Flaws: - **Rigidity**: when the plan breaks, he becomes meaner instead of smarter. - **Moral compartmentalization**: he can tell himself kids are “variables” until one looks him in the face. **Physicality** - Lean, efficient, dressed for movement. Voice low. Breath quiet. - Eyes don’t linger—he scans like a camera. - Moves with minimal sound; hands always already in position. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: finish the job, get paid, keep his crew alive. He doesn’t care about Crowley beyond payment. - Allegiances: to the job, then to self-preservation. - Relationship with Cal: tolerates him because Cal is useful muscle; dislikes his messiness. - Relationship with Denny: uses him; may sacrifice him if needed. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “The sitter is noise. Noise can be managed.” - *Dialogue:* “I don’t want to hurt you. Don’t make me spend time.” --- # Cal Mercer (intruder / cruel one) **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - Late 20s to early 30s. History of petty violence; the crew is the biggest structure he’s ever had. He enjoys the feeling of being allowed to be himself. - Personality: mocking, impatient, thrives on fear reactions. He’s the guy who turns a robbery into a trauma because it amuses him. - Idiosyncrasies: - Touches personal items (photo frames, hairbrushes) to assert power. - Hums tunelessly when he’s excited—like a child with a secret. - Fixates on Mara’s “calm voice” and tries to crack it. - Flaws: - **Sadism as distraction**: he gets sloppy when he’s enjoying himself. - **Ego**: he must “win” socially, not just physically—this is what gets him hurt. **Physicality** - Heavier than Rook, loud in a house—floorboards betray him. - Big hands, nicked knuckles. Moves too fast, too close. - Smells like cigarettes masked with cheap cologne. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: money, yes—but also domination. He wants Mara to beg. - Allegiances: shallow. He’ll turn on anyone if it serves his moment. - Relationship with Rook: resents being controlled; pushes boundaries. - Relationship with Denny: bullies him, calls him names. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “Look at her. Acting like she’s in charge. I can fix that.” - *Dialogue:* “You’re brave, huh? Little miss scrubs. Say please. I like ‘please.’” --- # Denny Shaw (intruder / nervous one) **Background / personality / idiosyncrasies / flaws** - Early 20s. New to this level of crime; joined because rent, debt, a baby at home—something that makes him pathetic and dangerous at once. - Personality: jittery, talkative, tries to be liked. He tells jokes that land wrong. He’s the one who keeps saying “this wasn’t supposed to—” - Idiosyncrasies: - Apologizes reflexively even while holding a weapon (“Sorry—move, sorry”). - Talks to himself when alone (“Okay, okay, okay”). - Can’t stop looking at the kids’ things—backpack, shoes—because it’s making it real. - Flaws: - **Panic**: he startles easily; he’ll do something irreversible if cornered. - **Need for approval**: he’ll obey Rook even when he knows it’s wrong. **Physicality** - Wiry, hollow-cheeked, like he doesn’t sleep. Acne scars or razor burn. - Hands shake unless he grips something hard; jaw clenched tight. - Eyes dart; he flinches at sudden sound. **Motives / allegiances / relationships** - Motive: get paid and get out; prove he’s not a screw-up. He tells himself it’s “just stealing,” not violence—until it isn’t. - Allegiances: to Rook (fear), to survival (stronger), and faintly to his own conscience (weak but present). - Relationship with Mara: she terrifies him because she looks at him like a patient making bad choices, not like a victim. - Potential relationship thread: he might give up key info not out of heroism but out of collapsing self-control. **Voice samples** - *Internal:* “I’m not a bad guy. I’m not. Bad guys don’t feel sick.” - *Dialogue:* “Lady—Mara—just… just tell them to stay quiet, okay? I don’t want— I don’t want that part.”

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 1 — The House Rules Mara Vance parked under a streetlamp that buzzed like an insect trapped in glass. Rain stitched the windshield in diagonal lines. The wipers made a tired, rhythmic complaint, and the engine ticked as it cooled, like it was counting down to something. The Hale house sat back from the curb the way money always did—respectfully distant, behind a low hedge and a walkway that looked too clean to be walked on. Warm light spilled through the front windows, but it didn’t soften anything. It just showed you what they wanted you to see. Mara checked her phone. 8:01 p.m. She sat for another two beats, watching the rain, feeling her own pulse through the thin skin at her wrist, where her hair tie lived like a bracelet. She’d come straight from shift. Her scrubs were hidden under a hoodie, the name patch tucked out of sight, but she still smelled faintly of antiseptic and other people’s fear. She’d meant to go home, shower, maybe eat cereal out of the box, then collapse. Instead she’d said yes to a last-minute babysitting gig because her bank app had flashed red numbers at her like a warning sign. She forced herself out of the car. The porch was wide enough for a small party. There was a seasonal wreath on the door—something with pine cones and a ribbon. No leaves in the gutters, no spiderwebs in the corners. The kind of tidy that had effort behind it. Mara rang the bell. A chime sounded somewhere inside like a polite xylophone. The door opened almost immediately. A woman in a dark blouse and gold hoops smiled too fast, as if someone had pressed play. “Mara? Thank God. Come in.” Warm air washed over her, smelling of lemon cleaner and something floral that didn’t belong to any actual plant. The foyer was pale wood, pale walls, pale everything. A family photo on a console table: mom, dad, two kids in coordinated outfits, all teeth. “I’m Dana,” the woman said. She reached out, then seemed to remember she didn’t need to touch Mara to complete the greeting, and withdrew her hand halfway. “Sorry. Hi. Thank you for doing this last minute.” “No problem,” Mara said. Her voice came out the way it always did when she was tired: flat, calm, like she had a hand on the back of someone’s neck keeping them from bolting. Dana looked past her to the driveway. “You’re alone? Good. Mark is… he’s in the kitchen.” Mara stepped inside and let the door click shut behind her. Instinctively, she noted the deadbolt, the chain, the smart lock keypad beside it. The kind of lock you bought because you liked the idea of safety more than you liked practicing it. Dana walked briskly, heels clicking softly on the wood. She called over her shoulder, “Rowan! Lily! Mara’s here!” Mara’s eyes flicked to the corners as she followed: a hallway to the left, stairs up on the right, a living room opening off the foyer with a couch arranged like nobody actually sat on it. No clutter. No piles. No shoes. A man stood at the kitchen island, fastening a watch onto his wrist with jerky fingers. He was tall, clean-shaven, in a crisp shirt that looked uncomfortable. He had the kind of face that read as “competent” from a distance and “tired of you” up close. “Mara,” he said. Not a question. He didn’t smile. He nodded like he was approving a delivery. “Mark,” Dana supplied quickly. “This is Mark.” “Hi,” Mara said. Mark’s eyes moved over her in a single sweep, taking inventory. Hoodie, jeans, damp hair, bag slung over one shoulder. He seemed to decide she wasn’t a threat to anything he cared about. His attention shifted away before it had properly landed. “Kids are—” Dana began. “Here!” a child’s voice announced, too loud for the size of the room. A boy appeared in the doorway with the posture of someone trying to look grown. Eleven, maybe. Thin in the limbs, hair in that in-between state where it couldn’t decide whether it wanted to lay flat or stand up. He had a book in his hand like a prop. Behind him came a girl—small, six-ish, with a ponytail that was already falling apart and a stuffed rabbit tucked under her arm. She looked up at Mara with the unfiltered curiosity of someone who hadn’t learned to pretend not to stare. “Mara,” Dana said, laying a hand on each child’s shoulder as if presenting them. “This is Rowan, and this is Lily.” Rowan’s gaze flicked to Mara’s bag. “Do you have, like, a taser in there?” “Rowan,” Dana snapped, but her voice wobbled on the edge of a laugh that didn’t arrive. Mara blinked once. “No taser.” Rowan nodded as if that answered a deeper question. Lily stepped forward and held out her rabbit. “This is Pickles. He doesn’t like strangers.” “Hi, Pickles,” Mara said, crouching slightly so she wasn’t towering. She didn’t touch the rabbit. Kids had their own rules about objects, and breaking them could turn a smooth night into a long one. “I’m Mara.” Lily studied Mara’s face with seriousness. “Do you know stories?” “I know some,” Mara said. “Do you?” “I know one about a dog that turns into a rocket,” Lily said, solemn as a judge. “That sounds advanced,” Mara said. Dana exhaled. “Okay. Great. So.” She clapped her hands softly once, as if gathering the moment into order. “We’re just going to go over the basics. Bedtime is eight-thirty for Lily, nine for Rowan—” “It’s not,” Rowan said. Dana’s eyes flashed. “It is tonight.” Rowan opened his mouth again, then shut it. He chewed the inside of his cheek. Mara saw it the way she saw people pick at scabs in the back of ambulances: automatic, unconscious, a self-soothing that left damage. Dana pointed to a door in the kitchen wall. “Inhaler is in that drawer. Lily’s asthma is mild, but—just in case. She’s been fine.” Mara’s attention sharpened a fraction. “Where’s her spacer?” Dana frowned like the word was unexpectedly technical in her home. “It’s… with it. I think.” “Okay,” Mara said. She didn’t correct Dana. People hated being corrected in their own kitchens. “Also,” Mark cut in, sliding his phone into his pocket, “no screens after bedtime. And—” He hesitated, eyes shifting toward a hallway that led away from the kitchen. “And you won’t need to go into my office.” Dana’s smile flickered. “Mark—” “You won’t,” Mark said, more firmly, and looked directly at Mara for the first time like it mattered. “It’s locked. I keep… work stuff in there. So just—don’t. If you need anything, call us.” Mara held his gaze. People made strange requests all the time. No one wanted a stranger poking through their life. But there was something in the way he said it—like the office was a wound you didn’t touch. “Fine,” Mara said. “I’m not here to do a home inspection.” Mark’s mouth tightened like that had been close to a joke and he didn’t appreciate the attempt. Dana rushed in. “The baby monitor still works, even though—” She laughed lightly. “Even though Lily is not a baby. We just… it helps. You can use it if you want. It’s on the counter.” Mara glanced at the monitor unit. White plastic, slightly yellowed, the kind of device that remembered sleepless nights. The screen was off, but the little green light winked patiently. “Okay,” Mara said. Dana continued, voice quick, spilling details in a way that felt like she was trying to outrun her own thoughts. “We’ll be at the Riverside Hotel—there’s a work dinner. It’ll go late, but the kids will be asleep. The number on the fridge is my cell, and Mark’s is—” “I have it,” Mark said. He picked up his keys. They jingled too loudly. Rowan watched his father with a particular expression Mara recognized from kids in emergency rooms: the look that said, *Are you going to come back?* without using those words. Lily tugged Dana’s sleeve. “Do we have to do teeth?” “Yes,” Dana said automatically, then looked at Mara. “She’ll try to—” “I won’t,” Lily said, offended. Then she grinned. “Maybe.” Mara stood and shifted her bag to the floor near her foot. It was a habit: keep it close, keep it yours. “What’s the bedtime routine?” “Story,” Lily said immediately. “And then you have to say the magic quiet words.” Mara raised an eyebrow. “What are the magic quiet words?” Lily leaned in like she was sharing classified information. “No more talking. Only sleeping.” “Solid,” Mara said. Dana let out a breath that sounded like relief and guilt braided together. “Thank you,” she said again, softer this time. Mark didn’t say thank you. He was already halfway to the foyer, calling back, “We won’t be long.” Dana followed, pausing only to smooth Lily’s hair and kiss the top of Rowan’s head. Rowan didn’t lean into it, but he didn’t pull away either. Mara walked them to the door because that’s what babysitters did: they were the handoff point, the hinge between adult world and kid world. The rain had intensified. Dana fumbled with her umbrella, laughing too brightly. Mark’s phone lit up in his hand; he glanced at it and went a shade paler, then stuffed it away when he saw Mara looking. “Back soon,” Dana said, and opened the door. Wind pushed rain into the foyer in cold spray. The porch light flickered once, then steadied. The door shut. Locks clicked. The house settled into a quiet that wasn’t restful so much as expectant. Mara stood with the kids behind her for a moment, listening to Mark and Dana’s footsteps fade down the porch steps, the car doors, the engine turning over. When the taillights disappeared down the wet street, Rowan spoke. “If someone comes in,” he said, voice carefully casual, “do you have to let them?” Mara turned to look at him. In the kitchen light, his face had lost its performance. He looked young. “No,” Mara said. “Why would someone come in?” Rowan’s eyes darted toward the hallway that led deeper into the house. He swallowed. “Just… asking.” “Okay,” Mara said, and let it be okay, because kids didn’t tell you the truth all at once. “Let’s do teeth.” Upstairs, the kids’ bathroom smelled like bubblegum toothpaste and damp towels. Lily dragged a stool to the sink with a scrape. Rowan brushed with the intensity of someone trying to scrub a thought away. Mara leaned against the doorframe and watched them through the mirror. In the reflection, she looked like what she was: a stranger in someone else’s home, temporarily responsible for what mattered most. Downstairs, somewhere in the quiet, the baby monitor’s green light blinked. Lily climbed into bed with Pickles tucked under her chin. “Story,” she reminded. Mara sat on the edge of the bed and opened the book Lily thrust at her. It was about a dog. Of course it was. The illustrations were bright, the sentences simple. Mara read them anyway, giving each line the weight it deserved, because that was what you did with children: you made small things feel safe. Rowan hovered in the doorway, pretending he was too old to listen while not leaving. Halfway through the story, the lights in the bedroom flickered. Once. Twice. Then steadied again. Mara paused mid-sentence, eyes lifting from the page. “What?” Lily whispered, suddenly alert. “Storm,” Mara said, and kept her voice even. “Sometimes the power blips.” Rowan’s face went tight. He looked toward the window. Rain hammered the glass. The backyard was a blur of dark shapes and the pale swing set. The motion light by the side gate was off. Mara finished the page. Lily’s breathing was slow. Rowan’s was not. She closed the book and said, “Magic quiet words?” Lily, obedient, whispered, “No more talking. Only sleeping.” Mara stood. As she backed out, she touched Rowan’s shoulder lightly—an anchor, not a cuddle. “Your room?” Rowan nodded and retreated down the hall. Mara waited until both doors were shut, then moved quietly down the stairs. In the kitchen, she picked up the baby monitor and turned the screen on. Static. A faint hiss. Then the grainy view of Lily’s room, empty except for a small lump under blankets. Mara set the monitor down and walked to the back door. She didn’t open it. She just pressed her palm to the glass. Cold seeped into her skin. Outside, the side gate latch was visible from here. It was a simple metal hook. It hung open. Mara stared at it for a full three seconds, feeling her heart shift gears. Then, faint under the rain, came a sound that didn’t belong to the storm. Metal. Softly struck. Again, more deliberate. A knock from the front of the house. One. Two. Then a third, perfectly spaced, like someone who had all night.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter demonstrates strong craft in establishing atmosphere, character, and tension. The writing follows the chapter plan faithfully, introducing Mara as a tired EMT taking a babysitting gig, establishing the Hale family dynamics, and building toward the threatening conclusion with the open gate and deliberate knocking. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Mara emerges as a competent, observant professional whose EMT background naturally informs her perceptions - she notices the inhaler location, reads body language, and maintains calm authority. The children feel authentic: Rowan's performative maturity masking anxiety, Lily's age-appropriate mix of innocence and perceptiveness. The parents' nervous energy and Mark's suspicious behavior around the office create effective unease without being heavy-handed. The prose style is lean and purposeful, avoiding unnecessary flourishes while maintaining atmospheric tension. Descriptions serve multiple functions - the "too clean" house exterior suggests artificiality, the baby monitor becomes both practical detail and surveillance metaphor, the flickering lights build dread. The writing demonstrates restraint, letting implications carry weight rather than over-explaining. Dialogue feels natural and reveals character efficiently. Rowan's question about "having to let someone in" plants crucial information while staying true to how an anxious child might probe for reassurance. Lily's interactions capture authentic six-year-old speech patterns and concerns. The pacing builds tension methodically through accumulating details: the parents' odd behavior, the locked office, the open gate, culminating in the measured knocking that promises violence. The chapter establishes stakes (vulnerable children), introduces the protagonist's capabilities, and ends on a genuine cliffhanger. Minor weaknesses include some slightly predictable beats (the flickering lights, the storm as pathetic fallacy) and occasional phrases that edge toward overwrought ("rain stitched the windshield"). However, these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. The chapter succeeds in its primary goals: establishing character, building dread, and setting up the siege scenario promised in the plan. It demonstrates professional-level craft in balancing exposition with tension, creating believable characters, and maintaining forward momentum. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 2 — Just the Sitter The knocks came again—polite, patient. The kind of knock that assumed it would be answered because doors were for answering and people were for complying. Mara didn’t move toward the foyer. She went up the stairs two at a time without making it sound like she was running. At the top landing she paused long enough to listen. The house held its breath around the rain. No footsteps. No voices. She opened Rowan’s door without knocking. Rowan was sitting on the edge of his bed, fully dressed, sneakers on. A backpack lay open beside him like a mouth. He looked up fast, guilty and relieved at once. “Shoes,” Mara whispered. “Coats.” Rowan’s face tightened. “What—” Mara lifted one finger. “Not now.” She crossed the hall and cracked Lily’s door. Lily was half-asleep, hair stuck to her cheek, Pickles clutched in a fist. Mara didn’t say Lily’s name. Names could make a kid sit up and ask questions and be loud. Mara crouched by the bed and spoke in a voice that belonged in dark rooms. “Hey, Lily. We’re playing a quiet game.” Lily blinked. “I—” “Mouse quiet,” Mara said, and Lily’s eyes widened as if she’d been handed a mission. Mara got her out of bed in one smooth motion, scooping the child’s hoodie off the chair. Lily’s feet found the floor, and she stood there swaying, awake now in the wrong way. “What’s the game?” Lily whispered, too loud. Mara’s hand came gently over Lily’s mouth, not pressing, just a reminder. “It’s a listening game. You win if you don’t talk.” Lily nodded fiercely against Mara’s palm. In Rowan’s room, Mara grabbed the backpack and zipped it without looking. “Inhaler,” she whispered to Rowan. Rowan pointed with two fingers, quick. “Bathroom drawer. Mom said—” Mara left him there and slid into the bathroom. Her eyes went to the drawer Dana had pointed out earlier. She yanked it open. A jumbled mess: hair ties, band-aids, little hotel soaps. Then the inhaler, blue plastic, and a spacer with cartoon stickers. Good. Downstairs: another knock. Not angry yet. That was what made Mara’s stomach tighten. Anger could be sloppy. This felt planned. She herded the kids into the hallway closet opposite the bathroom. It was a linen closet, tall shelves, towels stacked in crisp, folded columns. Dana’s version of chaos control. Rowan stepped in first, then Lily. Mara pushed extra towels forward, making a soft cave behind them. She gave Rowan the inhaler and spacer like handing him a fragile weapon. “Okay,” Mara whispered. “New rule. If I say ‘blue,’ you run. Down the stairs, out the back. Do you know the back door?” Rowan nodded, eyes too bright. “Good. You hold Lily’s hand. You don’t let go.” Lily’s mouth trembled. “Blue is my inhaler.” Mara almost smiled. Almost. “Exactly. So you’ll remember.” She closed the closet door until it was barely latched, enough to look like it belonged shut. Then she stood in the hallway and listened again, forcing herself to breathe slow. She pictured the oxygen in her own lungs like a measured supply. Panic was a fire; it ate air. At the top of the stairs she could see the foyer. The front windows turned the rain outside into moving glass. The front door was a dark rectangle waiting. Knock. Knock. This time, the door handle jiggled. Mara didn’t move. The jiggle stopped. A pause. Then came the sound of something thin sliding against metal—credit card or lock pick, probing. Smart locks didn’t care about cards, but the chain and latch did. Mara watched the handle, every muscle drawn tight. A new sound: a faint, high whine, like a tool spinning up. Mara’s brain offered her a list. Drill. Saw. Something meant for a job done quickly. She backed up one step, then another, so she wasn’t directly in the line of the door if it came open. Her heel brushed the edge of the console table. The family photo rattled softly. She caught it before it could fall, fingers closing on the frame. The glass was cold. The tool noise rose. Metal complained. A smell—hot plastic, hot metal—reached her even from here. Then the porch light flickered again, and the whole house dipped into darkness for a half second and came back. Not enough to reset anything, but enough to make her skin prickle. Downstairs, the smart lock keypad’s little blue light died and stayed dead. Mara stared at it. Power out. At least partially. The tool noise stopped. A single, quiet click. The front door swung inward. Three men stepped into the Hale house like they had been invited. They wore dark hoodies and cheap black gloves. Not ski masks—just caps pulled low and cloth gaiters over their mouths, like they were going to a protest or a cold football game. Their eyes were visible, and that made them worse. The first one—tall, lean—paused just inside and scanned the foyer with a slow, practiced motion. His gaze flicked to the living room, the stairs, the kitchen entry. He didn’t look surprised by the darkness. He expected it. He owned it. The second was slighter, twitchy. He glanced back at the door like he was already measuring escape routes. The third moved like he wanted to touch everything. His attention went to the family photo, to the wreath, to the neat shoes lined up by the wall. Mara stayed still on the stairs. From this angle, she was in shadow. The men hadn’t looked up yet. People often didn’t look up until the thing above them fell. “Door’s easy,” the twitchy one muttered. His voice was young, strained. “Told you.” “Shut up,” the lean one said, calm. He spoke as if he had all the air in the house and could afford to waste some. The third man picked up one of the shoes by the wall—a tiny sneaker, Lily’s—and squeezed it. He made a low noise through his gaiter, like amusement. “Hey,” Mara said, voice low and level, and watched all three heads snap up. The twitchy one startled hard, stepping back like she’d struck him. The third—shoe in hand—grinned behind his covering, eyes narrowing. The lean one just looked at her, eyes steady. “There’s a woman,” the third said, delighted, like he’d found an unexpected toy. Mara didn’t descend the stairs. She didn’t offer more of herself. “You’re in the wrong house.” Lean man’s gaze traveled over her. Hoodie. Jeans. Damp hair. No uniform. No visible weapon. His eyes assessed and dismissed in the same breath. “No,” he said. “We’re in the right one.” Mara kept her hands visible. Not surrender, just control. “Whatever you want, take it and go. Kids are asleep. You don’t need to make noise.” Twitchy one laughed, too high. “Kids are—” “Denny,” lean man said, and the twitchy one shut up. The third man leaned on the banister like he lived here. “She talking to us like she’s the homeowner.” Mara felt the line he was baiting and refused to step over it. “I’m the adult here tonight.” The third man’s eyes lit up. “She said adult.” Lean man didn’t react. He pointed toward the hallway that led to Mark’s office. “Where’s the office?” Mara held his gaze. “Locked.” “Everything’s locked,” the third man said. He set Lily’s sneaker back down with exaggerated care. “That’s why we’re here.” The lean man took two steps forward, and the air changed. He didn’t hurry. He didn’t need to. Mara stepped down one stair, then another, matching his movement without giving up her position too fast. “Listen,” she said. “You don’t want this to get complicated.” The third man chuckled. “It’s just the sitter,” he said casually, like he was ordering food. “She gonna call the cops.” Mara’s phone was in her hoodie pocket. She could feel its weight like a stone. She’d already tried it once at the top of the stairs—no bars. She hadn’t told herself that yet, but her body knew. Lean man’s eyes flicked to her pocket. “No need.” Mara’s pulse lifted. “What are you here for?” Lean man’s gaze moved past her, up the stairs toward the dark hallway. “Not you.” That was supposed to soothe her. It didn’t. It made her skin crawl. Mara forced her voice to stay even. “If you’re not here for me, then leave me alone.” The third man—Cal, Mara decided, because he had the face of a Cal—tilted his head. “You got a name?” Mara didn’t answer. Cal took a step toward the stairs, eyes bright. “I’m gonna go say hi to the kids.” “No,” Mara said, and the word came out sharper than she intended. Lean man lifted his hand, a small stop gesture. Not for Mara. For Cal. “Stay on task.” Cal’s grin faltered. His eyes went to lean man with resentment, then back to Mara. “Task. Right. Task is take what we came for. But sometimes you get extras.” Mara’s stomach went cold. She backed down another stair, putting herself between them and the hallway. “There’s nothing in this house worth that.” Lean man watched her, then nodded once, as if confirming a suspicion. “There is,” he said. He reached into his pocket and pulled out something small and black—a device. He pressed a button. A soft pop sounded somewhere in the house. Like a fuse blowing. The baby monitor’s green light in the kitchen winked off. Mara’s mouth went dry. He wasn’t just cutting power. He was cutting senses. Denny, the twitchy one, glanced toward the kitchen. “That work?” “It will,” lean man said. His voice didn’t change. Mara’s mind moved fast, flipping through options like drawers. Back door: side gate open. Rain. Dark. Kids in closet upstairs. Hide until they leave: they knew about the office. They would search. They would find. Call for help: no service. Landline? Did they even have one? If they did, these men would have cut it. Mara’s fingers flexed. She kept her face still. Cal started up the stairs, slow, savoring it. Lean man didn’t stop him this time. Maybe the plan allowed it. Maybe he didn’t care. Maybe he wanted Mara to run. Mara moved. She didn’t launch herself at Cal on the stairs. That was what people expected from heroes in movies. Mara stepped backward into the kitchen, keeping her eyes on them, and grabbed the first thing her hand landed on: a heavy ceramic utensil crock full of metal spoons, ladles, and one long carving knife. She lifted it with both hands. Cal laughed. “Oh, she’s got a pot.” Mara swung the crock down hard onto the edge of the island. Ceramic shattered. Metal clattered across the countertop and floor like sudden rain. Cal’s laugh stopped. Mara snatched the long knife—not for stabbing, not yet, but because holding something changed how close people wanted to get. She backed toward the pantry door, eyes never leaving the men. Lean man’s gaze flicked to the knife, then to the stairs, then back. “Put it down,” he said, like he was giving her a chance to be reasonable. Mara’s voice was quiet. “No.” Denny’s eyes were wide. “Man, come on. We don’t—” Cal turned and looked at Denny as if seeing him for the first time. “Shut up.” Mara’s grip tightened until her knuckles ached. She wanted to be calm. She wanted to be the woman who read bedtime stories and counted breaths. But the house had shifted. It wasn’t a home tonight. It was a place where predators came to do work. Lean man stepped into the kitchen. “We came for something,” he said. “You can make this easy. Tell me the office.” Mara shook her head once. Cal, on the stairs, called down softly, “I can smell them.” Mara’s stomach lurched. The closet. The towels. Lily’s shampoo. Their warmth in a narrow space. She swallowed. “If you go upstairs,” she said, and her voice changed despite her effort, hardening, “you’ll have to go through me.” Cal’s eyes shone. “Just the sitter,” he repeated, like a prayer. The lean man stared at Mara for a long beat. Then he nodded toward the hallway. “Fine,” he said. “We’ll do it ourselves.” He moved toward the office hall, slow, careful. Cal stayed on the stairs, watching Mara like she was entertainment. Denny hovered by the door, shifting his weight, breathing fast through his covering. He kept looking from Mara to the stairs to the rain outside as if waiting for the world to intervene. It didn’t. Mara took one step toward the hallway, then stopped. If she chased lean man, Cal would go up. If she went up, lean man would reach the office. If she froze, they’d pick the house apart like a carcass. She made a decision that tasted like metal. She turned her head slightly, eyes still on Cal, and raised her voice just enough for the closet to hear. “Blue,” she said. It was a soft word. Almost nothing. Upstairs, a floorboard creaked. Then another. Cal’s head snapped toward the sound. His grin widened. Mara moved before he could. She hurled the knife—not at his body, but at the stair rail beside his hand. The blade struck wood with a thunk and stuck, vibrating. Cal jerked his hand back, more surprised than hurt. Mara was already running up the stairs. Not to fight him. To get to the kids before he did.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively executes a tense home invasion scenario with strong adherence to both the writing plan and character profiles. The pacing builds methodically from the polite knocks to the violent confrontation, maintaining suspense throughout. The characterization is particularly strong. Mara's EMT background manifests naturally in her calm assessment of situations, her focus on breathing and oxygen management, and her practical approach to crisis ("Panic was a fire; it ate air"). The children behave authentically - Rowan's guilty preparedness and Lily's literal interpretation of instructions feel genuine rather than convenient. The three intruders are well-differentiated: the lean leader's controlled menace, Cal's sadistic enjoyment, and Denny's nervous energy all come through clearly in their dialogue and actions. The dialogue serves multiple functions effectively. Lines like "It's just the sitter" establish the central thematic tension while revealing character attitudes. The exchanges feel natural and advance both plot and character development. Mara's interactions with the children demonstrate her competence without making her seem superhuman. The writing maintains tension through specific, grounded details rather than overwrought description. The smart lock's failure, the ceramic crock shattering, and the knife sticking in the stair rail are all concrete, believable elements that serve the story. The author avoids purple prose while still creating atmosphere through selective sensory details. The chapter follows its outlined plan closely, hitting the key beats: the polite knocks, the three distinct intruders, Mara's practical response, and the escalation to violence. The "blue" code word payoff works well, and the chapter ends on the promised cliffhanger with Mara racing upstairs. Some minor weaknesses include occasional slightly awkward phrasing ("eyes steady" could be more specific) and a few moments where the prose becomes slightly self-conscious about its own cleverness. The metaphor of panic as fire eating air works but borders on being too neat. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise well-executed chapter. The emotional stakes feel genuine throughout. Mara's protective instincts, the children's fear, and the intruders' casual menace all register authentically. The violence, when it comes, feels earned rather than gratuitous. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 3 — The Thin Parts of Walls Mara hit the top landing and nearly collided with Rowan. Rowan had Lily’s hand in a death grip. Lily’s cheeks were wet, but she wasn’t making a sound; her mouth was pressed into Pickles’ fur like she could swallow her fear. “Good,” Mara whispered, not praise exactly—an assessment. “Back. Bathroom. Now.” Rowan started to protest, then saw Mara’s face and didn’t. They slid into the bathroom, and Mara shut the door most of the way, leaving it open a crack to listen. She could hear the men below—shoes on wood, a low voice, the soft laugh that didn’t belong. Cal’s laugh. Mara’s mind tried to build a map of the house with moving pieces. Lean man—Rook—heading toward the office hall. Denny near the door. Cal coming up, because of course he was. Cal wanted to take the stairs like a stage. Mara grabbed the baby monitor unit off the bathroom counter. It was a parent’s comforting lie until it wasn’t. She thumbed it on. Static, then a hiss, then nothing—dead. Whatever device Rook had used downstairs had killed it. “Okay,” she whispered, more to herself than to the kids. “Old school.” She pushed Rowan and Lily into the shower stall, behind the curtain. She yanked the curtain closed and pointed at the floor. “Sit. Both of you. Low.” Rowan obeyed, jaw tight. Lily’s eyes were huge. Mara leaned close. “No talking. If you have to cough, you cough into Pickles. If you have to cry, you cry into Pickles. Pickles is brave.” Lily nodded, pressing the rabbit’s head over her mouth like a mask. Mara backed out of the bathroom and pulled the door mostly shut again. She took three silent steps down the hall toward the linen closet and the attic access panel above it. At the corner, she paused and listened. Footsteps on the stairs. Slow, deliberate. A hand sliding along the banister like it was a pet. Cal’s voice floated up. “Maraaa,” he called, sing-song and intimate. “Where’d you go?” Mara’s skin crawled. He had asked her name and she hadn’t answered. He shouldn’t have it. But people like Cal didn’t need information; they used whatever stuck. She reached up and eased open the attic panel. Dust fell in a soft puff. She pulled down the ladder a few inches, just enough to creak once—then stopped, cursing herself silently. The footsteps paused. Mara froze, hand on the ladder, breath held. Silence expanded, full and thick. Then Cal laughed again, quieter. “I hear you,” he said. “House talks.” Mara lowered the ladder all the way anyway. Sometimes you couldn’t undo a sound; you just had to make it part of a different story. She climbed quickly into the attic, not caring about grace. The space above was unfinished—pink insulation, dark beams, the smell of old wood and mouse droppings. She moved on her knees, palms pressing into gritty dust. Her cuticles stung. She found the thin strip of plywood that served as a walkway over the joists and crawled toward the center of the house, toward where the attic would be above Mark’s office. Below, Cal’s footsteps reached the top landing. A pause. A door clicked open—Rowan’s room, maybe. Drawers opened. Something tossed. Cal was making a point of rummaging. Of owning. Mara inched forward until she found a vent opening—a gap around a duct where she could see down into the hallway through a sliver between ceiling and wall. The house had thin parts. You could watch through them if you knew where to look. Cal stood in the hallway beneath her, head tilted, listening. His hood was up, but she could see the shape of his face, the gleam of his eyes when he glanced toward the bathroom door. He stepped closer to it, slow. Mara’s muscles coiled. Downstairs, another voice—Rook—called up once, a short command. “Cal. Don’t.” Cal didn’t answer. He reached for the bathroom doorknob with exaggerated gentleness. Mara had no weapon now. The knife was downstairs, stuck in the banister. She scanned the attic around her, frantic and focused. There: an old metal hanger, twisted, abandoned. A length of thin rope used for holiday lights. A box with “XMAS” written in Sharpie, lid half open. Her hand closed on the hanger. She straightened it as much as she could, metal biting into her palms. Not lethal. Not impressive. But metal was metal, and surprise was leverage. Below, Cal turned the knob. Mara couldn’t drop down on him from the attic like an action hero. She could do something else. She could make noise somewhere else. Make him turn away from the bathroom. She found the attic access over Rowan’s room—another panel farther down—and shoved it open hard. The panel fell with a clap, and the folded ladder inside thunked against its frame. Cal jerked back from the bathroom door, head snapping toward the sound. “What the—” Mara shoved the ladder down another inch to make it creak louder, then froze. Cal moved toward Rowan’s room, drawn to the disturbance. Mara crawled back along the plywood, heart hammering. She had bought a few seconds. Seconds were currency. She dropped down the hallway ladder quietly—barely. The rung squeaked once. She winced, but Cal was farther away now, moving toward Rowan’s room. Mara landed on the carpet in the linen closet area and closed the attic panel softly, palms shaking. She padded to the bathroom door and slipped inside. Rowan and Lily sat in the shower like she’d left them, knees tucked, Pickles between them. Lily’s chest rose too fast. Mara crouched and put two fingers to Lily’s wrist. Tiny pulse, fast and fluttery. “Breathe with me,” she whispered. “In through your nose. Out through your mouth.” Lily tried, but her inhale hit a hitch. A faint whistle. Rowan’s eyes darted to the inhaler in his hand. “She’s—” “I know,” Mara whispered. She took the inhaler and spacer and fitted them quickly. Hands steady, brain shouting. “Lily. Lips on. Good. One puff.” She pressed. Lily sucked in, eyes squeezed shut, a tiny panic tremor running through her. “Good,” Mara said. “Again, slow.” Footsteps in the hall—Cal, returning. The boards creaked in a rhythm that made Mara want to crawl out of her own skin. Mara glanced at Rowan. “Hold this,” she whispered, handing him the spacer. “Count for her. One, two, three…” Rowan’s lips moved silently as he counted, eyes fixed on Lily like she was the only real thing left. Mara stood and listened at the bathroom door crack. Cal’s voice drifted through, lower now. “They moved,” he murmured. “She moved them. That’s cute.” Rook’s voice from downstairs, impatient. “Stop playing. Find the office. You’re wasting time.” Cal made a soft clicking sound with his tongue. “Time’s the only thing we got.” Mara’s fingers closed on the bathroom towel rack. It was bolted into the wall. Metal bar, sturdy. Not a weapon, but something to hold onto. She thought: back door. Rain. Side gate open. If they ran, where would they go? Neighbor houses lined up like sleeping animals. Lights off. Locked doors. People who might not answer. She heard a new sound downstairs—metal on metal, heavier. Rook working on something. The office door. Mara’s stomach sank. Rook wasn’t upstairs. He was doing the job. Cal, though, was here. Guard dog and predator. Mara opened the bathroom door a crack wider and looked out. Cal stood at the top of the stairs, one hand on the banister where the knife still trembled in wood. He looked up the hall, sniffing like a dog. He turned his head sharply and locked eyes with Mara through the crack. For a split second, neither of them moved. Then Cal’s eyes crinkled with pleasure. “There you are,” he said softly. Mara’s mouth went dry. She stepped out into the hallway, leaving the bathroom door mostly shut behind her. She put herself between Cal and the kids, body angled, hands visible. Cal took a step toward her. “You’re brave,” he said, voice almost admiring. “Or stupid. Sometimes it’s the same thing.” “Go downstairs,” Mara said. Her voice sounded too calm. She hated that it sounded like a command, because commands invited defiance. Cal’s gaze flicked to the bathroom door. “Kids in there?” “No,” Mara lied. Cal smiled. “You’re a terrible liar.” Behind Mara, a tiny cough—Lily, failing at being quiet. Cal’s head snapped toward the sound. His grin widened. “Oh.” Mara moved without thinking. She swung the towel rack like a baton, ripping it off the wall. Screws tore out with a crack. The sudden noise echoed down the hallway like a gunshot in a church. Cal flinched, more surprised than hurt, and Mara used the moment to shove him—hard—back toward the stairwell. Cal stumbled one step, then caught himself, laughing, exhilarated. “That’s it,” he breathed. “That’s the good part.” Mara’s hand throbbed where the metal had bitten into her palm. She backed toward the bathroom door, keeping her body between Cal and it. Cal advanced again, slow. “You can’t win,” he said, as if explaining a rule. Mara didn’t answer because she didn’t have a speech. She had two kids behind her and a house that was turning into a trap. Downstairs, Rook’s voice rose, sharp. “Denny! Phone. Now.” Denny’s voice answered, panicked. “It’s dead, man—there’s no—” Rook cursed. Cal paused, distracted for half a second by the change in tone. Mara took it. She slammed the bathroom door shut and threw the little lock on it. Rowan looked up at her, eyes wide. Lily’s breathing was still tight, but the inhaler was starting to do its work. “We’re not staying here,” Mara whispered. Her voice finally cracked at the edges. “We’re moving. Quiet feet.” Rowan swallowed. “Where?” Mara’s eyes flicked to the attic access again. Then to the window at the end of the hall—the one that looked out over the roof of the porch. “Anywhere that isn’t predictable,” she whispered. From the other side of the bathroom door, Cal’s knuckles rapped gently. Tap. Tap. Tap. Like he was being polite. “Open up,” he said, almost kindly. “We can do this easy.” Mara stared at the door, then at the children. Her brain, exhausted and furious, offered her a single clear thought: *He thinks you’re just the sitter.* She grabbed the inhaler, shoved it into Rowan’s hands, and lifted the bathroom window lock. Outside, the rain waited.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong technical craft and adherence to its planning documents. The writing maintains the established voice and character dynamics while escalating tension through a well-structured cat-and-mouse sequence. The characterization is particularly strong. Mara's EMT background manifests naturally through her medical assessment of Lily's breathing and her practical problem-solving approach. Her protective instincts feel genuine rather than heroic posturing. The children behave authentically - Rowan's silent counting and death-grip on Lily's hand, Lily's struggle to stay quiet while fighting an asthma attack. Cal emerges as genuinely menacing through specific details like his sing-song voice and deliberate touching of personal items. The domestic setting is used effectively as both constraint and resource. The attic crawlspace, baby monitor, towel rack, and inhaler all serve plot functions while maintaining believability. The house itself becomes a character through details like creaking boards and thin walls that allow surveillance. Dialogue serves character and tension well. Cal's "Maraaa" and "That's it, that's the good part" establish his predatory nature without overstatement. Mara's clipped medical language ("Breathe with me. In through your nose") shows her defaulting to professional mode under stress, consistent with her character profile. The pacing builds effectively from initial positioning through escalating encounters to the window escape setup. Each beat serves both immediate tension and larger story momentum. The author avoids common thriller pitfalls like having characters make obviously stupid decisions or providing convenient solutions. However, some elements feel slightly mechanical. The attic misdirection sequence, while functional, reads more like puzzle-solving than organic desperation. A few descriptive phrases ("silence expanded, full and thick") edge toward purple without quite crossing the line. The ending line about Cal thinking she's "just the sitter" feels slightly forced as a callback to the premise. The medical elements are handled with appropriate specificity - the inhaler and spacer use, pulse checking, and breathing assessment all ring true. This grounds the fantastic elements in believable expertise. Overall, this is solid genre writing that executes its plan competently while maintaining character consistency and building genuine tension. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 4 — The Office Door The bathroom window stuck the way cheap promises did. Mara dug her fingers under the sash and shoved. The wood resisted, swollen with rain, then gave with a wet squeal that felt impossibly loud. Cold air punched in, carrying the metallic smell of storm and the dark, green stink of wet leaves. Rowan climbed onto the toilet seat without being told. Lily followed, knees trembling. Mara went last, one hand on the window frame, one on Lily’s waistband like a leash. Behind them, the bathroom door shuddered once. Cal didn’t kick it yet. He didn’t need to. He was enjoying the thought of time. “Mouse quiet,” Mara whispered. Lily nodded and pressed Pickles to her face. Rowan’s jaw worked. They edged out onto the small, slick roof over the porch. Shingles glistened. Water streamed toward the gutters in narrow rivers. The drop to the ground was only eight feet, but it looked like a different world down there—open, exposed, lit by the neighbor’s motion light that kept flaring on and off in the rain. Mara crouched, keeping her center low. “Stay on your hands and knees,” she whispered. “Crawl. Don’t stand.” Rowan did as told, but Lily’s palms slid on the wet shingles. She made a small, terrified sound. Mara caught her elbow. “Look at me,” she breathed. “You’re doing it.” Lily’s eyes found Mara’s. For a moment, the panic receded—replaced by the fierce, stubborn focus of a child trying to win a game. They crawled along the roofline toward the side where the gutters met the tree. If they could get to the thick branch that hung close, they could drop from there into the shrubbery and run. Mara’s brain kept counting: breaths, steps, angles. She could hear muffled voices through the house—Rook downstairs, Cal at the bathroom door. Then Cal’s voice rose suddenly, delighted. “She went out the window!” A crash as the bathroom door gave way—wood splintering, a triumphant laugh. Mara’s blood ran cold. “Faster,” she whispered, and immediately hated the word. Faster meant slipping. Faster meant Lily falling. Rowan scooted ahead, surprisingly steady. He reached the tree branch first and looked back, rain plastered to his hair. “I can—” he started. “No,” Mara whispered. “You go first.” Rowan hesitated, and in that hesitation Mara saw what he was really doing: waiting for permission to leave the house. Waiting for an adult to say it was okay to run. Mara met his eyes. “Go,” she said, firm. “Now.” Rowan swung one leg over the branch, then the other, and lowered himself down. His sneaker slipped, and his breath hitched, but he caught himself and dropped into the bushes with a soft whoof. Lily crawled to the branch and froze, staring at the drop like it was an ocean. Her small fingers clenched around Pickles. “I can’t,” she whispered, voice thick with tears. “Yes you can,” Mara whispered back, close enough for Lily to feel her breath. “I’m right here. Put Pickles on your back. Use both hands.” Lily obeyed, fumbling. Mara guided her fingers around the branch, feeling how cold and slick it was. From inside, a window slid open hard. Cal’s silhouette appeared in the bathroom window, black against the interior light. He leaned out, rain hitting his hood, and grinned like this was a carnival ride. “Hi!” he called, too loud, waving. “Don’t fall!” Mara’s body flooded with something hot and savage. She wanted to throw herself at him just to make him stop talking. Instead she stayed with Lily. “Look at me,” she whispered. “Not him. Look at me.” Lily’s eyes, watery and wide, found Mara again. Mara guided her down, inch by inch. Lily’s feet searched for purchase, found air. Rowan’s voice rose from below, cracked. “Lily! I got you!” Lily let go and dropped. Rowan caught her awkwardly, both of them falling into the bushes. A small yelp—then silence. Mara swung her leg over the branch and started down. A hand shot out from the bathroom window—Cal’s. He grabbed a fistful of Mara’s hoodie and yanked. The fabric tightened around her throat. Mara’s breath cut off, a harsh choke. Her hands scrabbled for purchase on the branch. Cal laughed, close now, rain in his teeth. “Gotcha.” Mara’s fingers found the hair tie on her wrist. She ripped it off and looped it around her fingers for grip, then twisted her torso, using her body weight like a lever. She couldn’t overpower him. She could make it inconvenient to hold on. She drove her elbow backward, hard, into his wrist. Bone. Tendon. The kind of pain she knew intimately. Cal hissed and loosened his grip just enough. Mara tore free, losing balance. For a split second she was weightless, rain cold on her face, the world tilted wrong. Then she dropped. She hit the bushes, shoulder-first, pain exploding bright. A sharp sting in her palm where something thorny tore skin. She rolled onto wet grass, gasping like she’d been underwater. Rowan was crouched over Lily, arms around her. Lily was crying silently, shaking. Pickles lay facedown in the mud. Mara pushed herself up, shoulder screaming. “Move,” she whispered. “Now.” They ran along the side of the house, staying low, cutting through wet hedges. The side gate stood open, swinging slightly in the wind like a beckoning hand. Mara’s mind flashed back to the latch hanging open earlier. Not a mistake. An invitation. They slipped through and into the backyard. Motion lights snapped on, bleaching the rain-slick yard in harsh white. Mara froze for a fraction of a second, feeling exposed. Then she forced herself forward. Light didn’t mean seen. It meant time. Rowan tugged Lily along. Lily wheezed once—high, tight. Mara’s stomach clenched. “Inhaler,” she whispered without looking. Rowan shoved it into Mara’s hand. Mara shoved it back. “You do it,” she whispered. “You know how.” Rowan’s eyes widened. “I—” “You do,” Mara said. “Now.” Rowan fit the spacer to the inhaler with shaking hands. Lily took it, breathing hard, and Rowan counted under his breath like he’d been born to it. One, two, three. Behind them, the back door of the house burst open. Cal stepped into the yard, rain plastering his clothes. He lifted his arms wide like he was greeting an audience. “There they are.” Mara’s heart thudded. She scanned the fence line. Neighbor’s yard. Another fence. A shed. A slippery trampoline. Nothing that looked like safety. Cal took one step, then another. He wasn’t rushing. He wanted them to run themselves into exhaustion. Mara’s gaze flicked to the house, to the dark rectangle of Mark’s office window on the first floor. Somewhere inside, Rook was still doing the job. The office. The safe. If they ran far enough, the men would get what they came for and vanish. They’d leave the kids alive, maybe—if that was true. If Cal didn’t get bored. Mara tasted metal in her mouth. She’d seen what “maybe” did to people. Maybe was a coin flip with children’s lives on it. She took Rowan’s shoulder. “Stay here,” she whispered. “Behind the shed. Keep her breathing. If I say blue, you go.” Rowan’s face twisted. “Where are you going?” Mara didn’t have time to make it gentle. “Back in.” Rowan grabbed her sleeve, desperate. “No—Mara, don’t—” Mara leaned close, voice fierce and quiet. “Listen to me. I’m not leaving you. I’m stopping them.” Rowan’s grip loosened. He looked like he wanted to argue, but something in Mara’s tone—something that wasn’t negotiation—made him let go. Mara turned and sprinted toward the house, low and fast. Cal saw her pivot and laughed, delighted. “Oh, she’s coming back.” He started toward her. Mara cut left toward the patio and grabbed the long-handled grill tongs off a hook as she ran. Not a weapon, not really, but her hands wanted something. She yanked open the basement bulkhead door—unlocked, of course, because nothing in this house was meant for real danger—and plunged into darkness. The basement smelled of cardboard and laundry detergent. Water dripped steadily into a floor drain. She moved by memory and feel, fingers sliding along walls, heart hammering. Above, footsteps thudded on the patio. Cal’s voice called down, playful. “Basement? Really?” Mara didn’t answer. She found the stairs up from the basement to the kitchen and climbed them quietly. In the kitchen, the shattered ceramic still littered the floor. The knife was gone from the banister—pulled free, or fallen, or taken. Mara’s stomach tightened. Voices came from the hallway—Rook and Denny. Low, urgent. Mara crouched and peeked around the kitchen corner. Rook stood near the office door, shoulder braced against it while Denny fiddled with something at the lock—tools, maybe. Rook’s posture was all business. Denny’s hands shook. “This is taking too long,” Rook snapped. “I’m trying,” Denny hissed. “It’s— it’s not like my lock at home, man.” Rook made a small, sharp sound of disgust. “Crowley said tonight. He said—” Mara’s mind snagged on the name. Crowley. The way Rook said it—like it was an order, not a person. A creak upstairs. Then Cal’s voice floated down the stairwell, sing-song. “Mara? You in the walls? Come on out. Let me see you.” Rook’s head turned slightly toward the stairs. Annoyance flickered across his eyes. “Cal,” he called, controlled. “Stop. Watch the door.” Cal didn’t answer. Denny’s tool slipped, metal scraping. He swore under his breath, voice small. “This is—this is stupid.” Mara’s gaze went to the office door. Solid wood. A keypad lock. A deadbolt. Mark’s insistence: you won’t need to go in there. There was a narrow transom window above it—decorative, frosted. Too small for a man, but big enough for a hand. Big enough for a tool. Mara’s pulse beat behind her eyes. She looked down at the grill tongs in her hand. Useless. Her shoulder throbbed from the fall. Her palm stung where thorns had torn skin. She saw the hall closet door slightly ajar. Inside: a step ladder. Mara moved without thinking, crossing the kitchen in two silent steps, sliding into the closet. She pulled the ladder out an inch at a time, careful to keep the hinges from squealing. She set it in the hallway just out of sight from Rook’s angle. Then she waited, breathing shallow, listening for the next mistake. The house was full of thin parts. One of them was the space between Rook’s certainty and his impatience. Above, Cal’s footsteps started down the stairs, slow. Mara’s throat went tight. She had seconds. She stepped into the hallway and spoke, loud enough to carry, keeping her voice flat. “Hey.” Rook and Denny both snapped around. Mara lifted the tongs like they were a gun. It was almost laughable. Denny’s eyes went huge anyway. “Just the sitter,” Cal said from halfway down the stairs, amused. Rook stared at Mara with irritation, as if she was a delay in a schedule. “Where are the kids?” Mara didn’t answer. She pointed the tongs at Denny’s hands. “Drop it.” Denny hesitated, looking to Rook for permission. His breathing was fast, panicked. Mara saw the tremor in his fingers. She saw how close he was to doing something stupid. Rook’s eyes narrowed. “You think you’re in control?” he said. Mara’s voice stayed even, because if it cracked she’d lose them. “I think you have a job,” she said. “And I think your friend upstairs is making it messy.” Rook’s gaze flicked toward the stairs where Cal was descending, smiling. “Cal,” Rook said sharply. Cal’s smile widened. “What?” Rook’s jaw clenched. The smallest fracture. Mara moved. She kicked the ladder forward with her foot, sending it scraping across the hall, and in the same motion she lunged toward the office door and rammed the tongs up into the transom window frame. The tongs bit into the soft wood around the frosted glass. She twisted hard. Glass cracked with a brittle scream. Denny shouted, startled. Cal laughed. Rook swore and surged toward her. Mara jerked the tongs down, ripping the broken glass out and reaching through the jagged opening with her injured hand. Pain lanced up her arm as shards bit her skin. Her fingers found the interior thumbturn of the deadbolt. She turned it. The lock clicked. The office door swung inward. Rook grabbed her hoodie from behind and yanked her back, hard, slamming her into the hallway wall. Her shoulder exploded with pain. Stars burst behind her eyes. But the door was open. Mara tasted blood where she’d bitten her cheek. Inside the office, a small green light blinked on a safe in the closet. And the house, suddenly, felt like it had handed her its throat.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter delivers a tense, well-executed sequence that successfully advances both plot and character development. The writing demonstrates strong technical craft in several key areas. The action sequences are particularly well-handled, with clear spatial awareness and believable physical details. The roof escape feels genuinely dangerous without being overwrought, and Mara's improvised break-in through the transom window is both clever and grounded in her EMT background. The pacing builds effectively from the initial bathroom window escape through to the final confrontation at the office door. Character work remains consistent and nuanced. Mara's protective instincts and medical training shine through naturally - her immediate focus on Lily's inhaler, her clinical assessment of injuries, and her ability to read the antagonists' dynamics all feel authentic to her established profile. The children behave believably under extreme stress, with Rowan's conflicted loyalty and Lily's fear-driven responses ringing true. Cal's sadistic playfulness ("Hi! Don't fall!") effectively establishes him as genuinely menacing without cartoonish excess. The dialogue serves multiple functions efficiently. Mara's terse commands ("Mouse quiet," "Look at me") convey both urgency and her caretaking nature. The antagonists' brief exchanges reveal their hierarchy and growing tension without exposition dumps. Particularly effective is Rook's irritation with Cal's unprofessionalism, which Mara exploits tactically. The writing maintains its established voice well - close third person anchored in Mara's sensory experience. Descriptions like "Cold air punched in, carrying the metallic smell of storm" and "pain exploding bright" feel immediate without being overwrought. The prose stays lean and purposeful throughout. However, there are some minor weaknesses. A few metaphors feel slightly strained ("The bathroom window stuck the way cheap promises did"), though they don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. Some action beats could be clearer - the exact mechanics of Mara's escape from Cal's grip on the roof require careful reading to follow. The chapter successfully fulfills its planned function of moving the protagonists toward the office/safe while maintaining tension and character consistency. The ending creates a strong hook while feeling earned rather than contrived. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 5 — Oxygen The office smelled like toner and expensive cologne trying to be harmless. Mara hit the wall, slid half a step, then forced her legs to hold. Rook’s fist twisted in her hoodie, bunching fabric tight under her collarbone. His other hand came up with something dark—gun, she realized, stupidly late. Not raised yet. Just present. A fact. Cal leaned in the doorway behind them, rain dripping from his hood onto the hardwood. He looked delighted, as if Mara had opened the office like a gift for him. Denny stood a few feet back, breathing fast, staring at the broken transom window with horror. “Jesus—” Mara’s right hand—cut and stinging—was still inside the jagged glass frame. Blood ran down her wrist, warm against cold skin. Rook’s eyes flicked from her hand to the safe light. “You opened it,” he said, almost accusing. “You shouldn’t have been able to open it.” Mara swallowed. Her mouth tasted like copper. “Neither should you.” Rook stared at her with a tight, controlled fury. “Where are the kids?” Mara didn’t answer. She couldn’t risk her voice slipping toward the shed. She couldn’t risk Cal hearing a lie and deciding to test it. Cal stepped closer, peering into the office with a child’s fascination. “Oh, this is the special room,” he murmured. “Daddy’s secrets.” Rook’s grip tightened. “Move,” he said to Mara. He shoved her forward through the doorway. Mara stumbled into the office and caught herself on the edge of the desk. Pain flared through her shoulder like an electric arc. She fought the urge to gasp. Noise was weakness, and weakness was invitation. Rook followed, gun now visible at his side. Denny hovered in the hall. Cal stayed in the doorway like a bouncer to a nightclub. “Open it,” Rook said, nodding at the closet safe. Mara’s mind ran through time and distance: upstairs to the kids, down to the back door, the yard lit by motion lights, Rowan’s small hands fitting the spacer to the inhaler. Lily’s wheeze. The shed’s dark corner. Her lungs felt suddenly too small. She forced herself to inhale slowly. “I don’t know the code,” she said. Rook’s gaze bored into her. “Try,” he said. She walked to the closet. The safe was waist-high, bolted to the floor. A keypad with numbers worn slightly from use. Mark’s fingers, tapping without thinking. Rowan’s face when he’d confessed. *Dad taps his ring… three quick… then pause…* Mara’s hands shook as she reached for the keypad. Blood smeared the plastic. Rook’s voice came close to her ear, low. “You know what happens if you waste time.” Mara’s fingers hovered. She didn’t have a plan. She had a pattern and a kid’s half-remembered shame. She tapped: three quick numbers, then a pause. Another set. The safe beeped—angry. Rook shifted, impatience thickening the air. “Again.” Mara tried another permutation, heart pounding. Beep. Cal sighed theatrically. “Let me,” he said, stepping forward. Rook snapped his gaze at him. “No.” Cal’s eyes narrowed, offended. He backed up a half-step, but his smile was gone now. “Fine,” he said softly. “Just saying.” Mara’s fingers hovered again. She could hear, faintly, through the house—the sound of something upstairs. A floorboard. Or her own imagination. She couldn’t tell anymore. She tapped again. This time, when she hit the last digit, the safe gave a softer tone. A click. The door swung slightly open under its own weight. For a fraction of a second, nobody moved. Then Rook shoved Mara aside and yanked the safe door wide. Inside: stacks of cash bound with rubber bands. A small flash drive in a plastic sleeve. And, tucked beneath them, a thin black notebook with a rubber band around it. Not a corporate binder. A cheap thing you’d buy at a pharmacy. The kind people used for grocery lists, phone numbers, sins. Rook’s hand went in fast for the drive. Mara’s eyes went to the notebook instead.
