Great. I like luck.” “You’re dripping,” Eira added. He looked down as if surprised to find his own body. Rain ran off his sleeves onto the worn wood floor. “Right. Sorry. I can—” He fumbled with his coat collar. “I can take it off.” “Don’t,” Eira said. “It’ll drip on the books. Drip on the floor. Drip in my life.” His smile flickered again. “Your life?” “It’s a small shop,” Eira said. “Everything gets into everything.” He held her gaze like he was used to people softening if he did. She didn’t soften. She didn’t harden either. She simply stayed where she was. He cleared his throat. “I promise I’m not here to… drip in your life.” A beat. Then: “That sounded better in my head.” “It often does,” Eira said. Outside, a shape moved past the window too slowly, the way people move when they want you to notice. The man’s eyes snapped to the glass. Eira followed his look. A figure in a black jacket. Phone held low, angled up. Another figure behind him, hood up, scanning. Eira sighed, quietly, like she was putting down a book she hadn’t enjoyed. “You’ve brought friends.” He flinched. “They’re not my friends.” “They’re your… what. Fans.” He laughed again, but it didn’t have any sparkle left. “No.” “Paparazzi,” Eira said, because there was no point in pretending. His jaw tightened, and for the first time she saw something under the charm: fear, sharp and boyish, like he’d been caught without a costume. “They saw me on the street,” he said. “I thought— I just needed a minute.” Eira tilted her head. “Why are you in Abermorfa?” He blinked. “Is that— is that where I am?” “It is,” Eira said. “Unless you’re so famous you’re in two places at once.” A reluctant grin tugged at his mouth. “I’m not that famous.” “You are,” Eira said, flatly. He watched her, waiting for whatever came next. The gushing. The recognition. The fluttering. The hand to the mouth. When it didn’t arrive, something in him shifted. Not anger. More like… curiosity, edged with offence. “Do you—” he began, then stopped, as if the question might be humiliating. “Do you know who I am?” Eira reached under the counter, pulled out a mop bucket, and set it beside her feet with a thud. “I know you’re wet.” His mouth opened. Closed. Then he laughed for real, a short burst that sounded startled. “Okay,” he said. “Fair.” He moved further in, careful now, like someone stepping into a church. He looked at the shelves to give himself something to do, something to be other than a famous man cornered. Eira watched him scan titles. His gaze caught on a display of local history and Welsh-language poetry, slid away, returned, embarrassed. “You want something,” Eira said. “Or you want to hide.” He turned his head. “Both?” “Pick one,” Eira said. He leaned a shoulder against a shelf without noticing, making it tremble slightly. He straightened immediately when he felt it, like the shelf had rebuked him. “I’m not—” he started, then let out a breath. “I’m not here to cause trouble.” “You are trouble,” Eira said. Not unkind. Just accurate. He pressed his lips together, smile thinning. “That’s… a bit harsh.” Eira shrugged. “People with cameras outside my door are usually trouble.” He glanced again at the window. The man outside lifted his phone a fraction higher. Eira stepped away from the counter and walked to the door. The bell gave a small, traitorous jingle as she moved beneath it. The figures outside shifted, alert. Eira snapped the *CLOSED* sign over, even though it was a lie. She slid the bolt across with a satisfying clack. When she turned, he was staring at her as if she’d just performed a magic trick. “You—” he said. “You’re closing?” “I’m closing,” Eira said. “Temporarily. Until your— not friends— go away.” His throat bobbed. “You don’t have to do that.” “I know,” Eira said. For a moment his charm didn’t know what to do with gratitude that wasn’t worship. It hovered. Then he put the smile back on, like a mask chosen carefully. “I really appreciate it,” he said, voice low. “I’ll make it up to you.” Eira stopped in front of him, close enough that she could smell rain, expensive soap, and the faint metallic tang of nerves. “No.” His smile stiffened. “No?” “No making it up. No paying me. No buying a rare first edition and calling it fate.” Eira nodded at the shelves. “This is not that kind of place.” He blinked, a little thrown. “Is it… a kind of place?” “It’s a bookshop,” Eira repeated, as if that settled it. He looked down at his hands, then back up, eyes searching again, softer now. “Okay. Right. Bookshop.” Outside, a fist knocked on the glass. A muffled voice: “Hello? Anyone in there?” Callum—because she would not call him by the name he’d chosen for strangers—went still, every muscle pulling inward. Eira raised her voice just enough to carry. “We’re closed.” A pause. The voice again, more insistent. “We saw someone come in. Just want a quick word.” Eira stepped closer to the window but stayed out of the line of sight. She angled her body like a shield without theatrics. “There’s no one here,” she said, and it surprised her how easily it came. Behind her, he whispered, “Thank you.” She didn’t look at him. “Don’t thank me yet.” The voice outside, skeptical: “We can wait.” “You’ll get wet,” Eira called back. A laugh from outside, sour. “We’ve been wetter.” Eira rolled her eyes and turned away from the door. She walked past him toward the back of the shop. He followed immediately, too close, like a shadow that didn’t know where to go without a body. “Stop,” Eira said, and he stopped so fast he nearly bumped a table. She gestured toward a narrow corridor behind the counter. “Back room.” His gaze darted down it. “Are you sure?” “No,” Eira said. “But I’m doing it anyway.” He hesitated, then stepped into the corridor. Eira followed, flicked on the light. The back room was cramped: stacks of boxes, a kettle, a chair with a ripped cushion, and the faint smell of paper that had lived through too many winters. He stood in the middle like he couldn’t believe a room could be this unglamorous. Eira pointed at the chair. “Sit.” He obeyed, then immediately looked up at her as if waiting for direction, permission, absolution. “What’s your name?” he asked suddenly. Eira stared. “Eira.” “No,” he said. “I mean— yes. Sorry. That’s—” He exhaled, frustrated with himself. “I mean… can I call you Eira? Or is there a ‘Mrs Morgan’ situation?” “It’s Eira,” she said. “And there is no situation.” He nodded too quickly. “Okay. Eira.” He said it like it mattered to get it right. Eira leaned back against a stack of boxes, arms folded again because she didn’t know what else to do with them. “Your turn,” she said. His smile returned out of reflex, then faltered, as if he’d realised smiling wouldn’t save him in here. “Callum,” he said. Eira waited. He held her gaze. “Callum.” A beat passed where she could have said *I know.* Where she could have let him have it—her recognition, her opinion, the little sugar rush he was clearly starving for. She didn’t. “Right,” Eira said instead. “Callum. You have—” she glanced at her watch, “—five minutes.” His shoulders dropped, relief and disbelief mixing. “Five minutes and then what?” “Then you leave,” Eira said. He looked up at her, rainwater still darkening his lashes. His voice softened, losing the practiced edges. “And if they’re still out there?” Eira’s answer came too fast, too honest. “Then we’ll see.” His mouth parted slightly. The charm didn’t rush back in time. For once, he looked like someone caught in the act of feeling. Outside, the knock came again, harder. Eira pushed off the boxes and reached for the kettle. “Tea?” Callum blinked. “Tea.” Eira filled it with water at the tiny sink. “You drink tea?” He huffed a laugh, weak. “I’m British. It’s in the contract.” Eira flicked the switch. The kettle began to whine. Callum watched her hands. “You’re not… asking me anything.” Eira didn’t look up. “Like what.” “Like why I’m here,” he said. “What I’m doing. If I’m—” He swallowed. “If I’m okay.” Eira took two mugs down from a shelf. One was chipped. She gave him the chipped one. “I don’t care what you’re doing,” she said. “I care what you do in my shop.” His fingers closed around the mug, careful. “And what am I doing in your shop?” Eira met his eyes over the steam beginning to curl from the kettle spout. She could feel her own heart being stupid in her chest, reacting to the closeness, the vulnerability, the ridiculousness of him sitting there like a boy in detention. “You’re hiding,” she said. “And making it my problem.” His smile flickered—half apology, half something else. “I can be… less of a problem.” Eira snorted. “Can you.” The kettle clicked off, loud in the small room. Outside, the rain kept falling, steady as attention. The shop, the town, the world—pressed close. Eira poured boiling water into both mugs. Callum’s voice came quiet, rough around the edges. “Thank you.” This time, Eira looked at him. Really looked. “Don’t,” she said, softer than she meant. “Not like that.” His brows knit. “Like what?” Eira held his gaze a moment too long. “Like I’ve saved you,” she said. “I’ve given you five minutes. That’s all.” Callum’s smile slipped sideways, not charming—real. “Five minutes is… more than I’ve had all day.” Eira’s throat tightened, annoyed with herself. She pushed the mug toward him across the cluttered table. “Drink your tea,” she said. “And keep your head down.” Callum wrapped both hands around the chipped mug as if it was warm enough to make him disappear. “Yes, ma’am,” he said, and tried to make it a joke. It almost worked.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong craft in several key areas while maintaining consistent quality throughout. The writing successfully establishes the meet-cute scenario with genuine tension and chemistry, avoiding many common romance pitfalls. The character work is particularly strong. Callum emerges as a convincingly fragile performer - his charm feels practiced and desperate rather than effortless, which aligns perfectly with the character profile. His dialogue shifts believably between polished deflection ("I like luck") and genuine vulnerability ("Five minutes is... more than I've had all day"). Eira is equally well-realized, with her dry competence masking attraction. Her voice is distinct and consistent - practical, unimpressed, but not cruel. The line "You are trouble. Not unkind. Just accurate" perfectly captures her character. The dialogue drives the scene effectively, with each character maintaining distinct speech patterns. Callum's tendency to over-explain and seek approval comes through naturally ("That sounded better in my head"), while Eira's clipped responses and refusal to be charmed feel authentic rather than artificially withholding. The subtext is well-handled - their attraction builds through proximity and small kindnesses rather than explicit acknowledgment. The Welsh setting feels lived-in rather than touristic. Details like the town name "Abermorfa" and Eira's practical knowledge of local dynamics ground the story without over-explaining. The paparazzi threat creates genuine stakes without feeling melodramatic. The pacing works well, building from Callum's frantic entrance to the quieter intimacy of the back room. The author resists rushing toward romantic beats, instead focusing on the characters learning each other's boundaries. Some minor weaknesses: occasional phrases border on overwrought ("rain drummed against the glass," "voice low, rough around the edges"), though they don't cross into purple prose. A few moments of internal narration could be more subtle - "annoyed with herself" tells us what we could infer from behavior. The chapter faithfully follows both the prompt requirements and the detailed plan. The meet-cute unfolds naturally, the chemistry builds through resistance rather than immediate attraction, and both characters remain true to their established personalities. The Welsh setting serves the story rather than decorating it. Overall, this is accomplished writing that establishes compelling characters and genuine romantic tension while avoiding genre clichés. The dialogue feels natural, the conflict has real stakes, and the emotional beats are earned rather than forced. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 2: Terms “You’re going to burn your hands,” Eira said. Callum looked down as if noticing them for the first time—both palms cupped around the mug like a prayer. “It’s fine.” “It’s not fine,” she said. “It’s boiling. I didn’t do that for your benefit. It’s physics.” He smiled, tentative. “You’re very comforting.” “I’m very busy,” Eira replied, and moved past him to shove a pile of invoices into a drawer that didn’t want them. The back room was warmer now, kettle heat and radiator heat combining with damp coats. Callum’s coat hung on the back of the ripped chair, dripping onto a folded tea towel Eira had sacrificed with a sigh. Outside the door, the shop was silent in that tense way a shop gets when it’s closed unexpectedly: the world paused with its nose pressed to the glass. A knock sounded again—fainter now, as if the person was pacing and trying to sound casual. Callum’s shoulders rose. Eira lifted a finger. “No.” He froze. “No what?” “No panicking in my shop,” she said. “You can do that elsewhere.” His lips parted, then he closed them. He nodded, small and obedient, which annoyed her more than the panic. Eira took her own mug—un-chipped, because she had standards—and leaned against the counter. “How long do they usually… do that?” she asked, nodding towards the front. Callum’s eyes flicked to the door. “Depends.” “On what.” “On whether I give them something,” he said, too quickly. Eira’s gaze sharpened. “Give them something.” He had the decency to look faintly ashamed. “A picture. A reaction. A… story.” “A story,” Eira repeated. He shrugged one shoulder, attempting casual. “They sell stories.” “And you provide them,” Eira said. His jaw tightened. The charming expression tried to return and failed halfway, like a light bulb flickering. “I don’t,” he said. “Not— I mean, I can’t stop them. I can’t—” He exhaled through his nose. “I can’t make them stop.” “No,” Eira agreed. “But you can choose not to feed them.” Callum’s fingers tightened around the mug. “It’s not that simple.” “It often is,” Eira said. He looked up at her like he couldn’t decide whether she was naive or cruel. “You’ve never had five strangers follow you down a street shouting your name.” Eira felt something hot and unhelpful flare in her chest. “No. I’ve had five strangers know my business without ever speaking to me.” Callum blinked. Eira hated that she’d said it. She hated that it sounded like a speech. She turned away and started moving boxes as if the solution to emotion was cardboard. Callum watched her shift a box labeled *CHILDREN’S — RETURNS*. “Sorry,” he said, and then, as if he couldn’t help himself: “What business?” “None,” Eira said. “Right.” His voice softened. “None.” The knock came again, then footsteps. A car door. Muffled voices. The squeak of tyres in wet gravel. Callum lifted his head like a dog hearing a distant whistle. Eira held up her hand. “Wait.” They did. For a long minute. The shop remained quiet. Callum let out a breath he’d been hoarding. “I think they’re—” Eira cut him off. “Not yet.” He looked at her. “How do you know?” “I’ve lived here my whole life,” she said. “If they leave, they make a show of leaving.” His mouth twitched. “That’s… depressing.” “It’s efficient,” Eira corrected. The silence stretched. The kettle clicked as it cooled. Callum shifted in his chair. “So. Five minutes?” Eira glanced at her watch. She didn’t want to admit she’d stopped counting. “Ten,” she said, and then, to herself, “Idiot.” Callum’s eyes widened with grateful delight—too much delight for ten minutes. “Thank you.” Eira pointed at him again. “Stop doing that.” He pressed his lips together. “Sorry.” “That too.” He looked honestly baffled. “What am I allowed to do?” Eira stared at him. The question was ridiculous; so was he, sitting in her back room like an overgrown schoolboy in a drenched designer jumper, asking for rules because without rules he didn’t know what face to wear. “Drink your tea,” she said. “Quietly.” Callum nodded solemnly and took a careful sip. His phone buzzed on the table. He flinched so hard the mug rattled. He grabbed the phone, then hesitated, eyes flicking up to her like a child caught with sweets. Eira raised her eyebrows. Callum turned the screen so she could see the caller ID without handing it over. *MARA — PUBLICITY*. Eira gave a short laugh she didn’t mean to. “Of course her name is Mara.” “It’s not her real name,” Callum said automatically. “That’s worse,” Eira replied. The phone buzzed again. Then again, insistent. Callum swallowed. “I should answer.” Eira crossed her arms. “If you answer, you do it away from the front window.” “I’m not— I won’t—” He stood too fast, chair legs scraping. “Where?” Eira jerked her head toward the corridor. “Upstairs.” Callum blinked. “Upstairs?” Eira instantly regretted giving him any new information about her building. “There’s a flat. It’s mine. It’s not for you.” His smile appeared, sly and grateful. “But it exists.” Eira’s eyes narrowed. “It exists for me. Not for your friends with cameras.” Callum lifted both hands like surrender, phone still buzzing between his fingers. “Understood.” Eira led him down the narrow passage and up the creaking stairs behind a door marked *STAFF ONLY*. She didn’t like how he filled the space behind her. She didn’t like how aware she was of him doing it. Upstairs smelled of old carpet, radiator dust, and the ghost of last night’s curry. Eira pushed the door open with her hip. Callum stepped in and paused, looking around as if he’d entered a stranger’s mind. There were books everywhere, of course—stacks beside the sofa, along the windowsill, piled on a chair like a second occupant. A throw blanket folded with aggressive neatness. A single plant leaning as if exhausted. “You live here,” Callum said, softly. Eira shot him a look. “Obviously.” “It’s…” He searched for a word that wasn’t patronising. “Nice.” “It’s small,” she said. “It’s yours,” Callum replied, and something in his tone made her look away. His phone buzzed again. He stepped away from the window without being told this time and answered in a low voice. “Mara,” he said. “Yes. I’m— no, I’m fine. No, I’m not—” He glanced at Eira, then turned his back, as if that made privacy. “I said I’m fine.” Eira busied herself with moving a pile of books off the sofa, trying not to hear. Callum’s voice rose despite his attempts to keep it down. “No, I’m not in London. I’m— I’m not telling you exactly where I am.” A pause. His shoulders tightened. “I’m not— I’m not hiding,” he said, and Eira almost snorted. “I’m taking a break.” Another pause. His laugh was thin. “No, there are no… opportunities. I’m in a—” He glanced again at Eira, as if the word might offend her. “I’m in a small town.” Eira couldn’t help it. “It has a name.” Callum mouthed something like sorry and turned away again. “Mara, listen,” he said, voice dropping. “I need forty-eight hours.” Eira caught a few words through the wall of his body: *narrative*, *damage control*, *leak*, *don’t antagonise them*. Callum’s jaw clenched. “I’m not antagonising anyone. I’m just— I’m tired.” Silence. When he spoke again, his voice was quieter, stripped. “No, I’m alone.” Eira’s chest tightened at that word. Alone. As if it was an accusation. Callum ended the call. He stood for a moment looking at the black screen as if waiting for it to tell him what to do next. Eira cleared her throat. “Are they sending someone to fetch you.” His smile returned, shaky. “Do you get a lot of people fetched?” Eira ignored the question. “Are they.” Callum rubbed a hand over his face. “Not yet.” “Yet,” Eira repeated. He looked at her and for a moment didn’t try to charm. “They want me to leave. They think if I’m here it’s because I’ve done something.” “Have you,” Eira asked, more sharply than she intended. Callum’s eyes flashed. Pride. Hurt. Then he laughed, defensive. “What, like I’ve murdered someone and come to hide behind the romance section?” Eira’s mouth twitched despite herself. “It would be the crime section.” His grin widened, relieved. “You think I’d have the decency to choose correctly.” Eira stepped closer, close enough to see the fine lines at the corners of his eyes—evidence of real smiling, not just camera-ready. “I don’t care what you did,” she said. “But I do care what happens here.” Callum’s smile softened. “Here meaning… your shop.” “Here meaning my life,” Eira said, and immediately hated how intimate it sounded. Callum’s gaze held hers, steady. “Okay.” Eira swallowed. “So.” “So,” he echoed. “You can’t stay,” she said. His face fell too fast. Ego bruise, immediate. “I— I’m not asking to stay. I’m asking for… time.” “You already took time,” Eira said. “You took my afternoon.” He flinched. “I didn’t mean—” “I know what you meant,” Eira snapped, then exhaled, forcing her voice back down. “You can wait until it’s properly quiet and then you leave. That’s it.” Callum nodded, but his eyes flicked to the window as if calculating. Eira saw it and felt a flare of irritation. “Don’t.” “Don’t what.” “Don’t stand there weighing up whether you could make a dash for it,” she said. “You are not going to sprint past my customers like some… celebrity gazelle.” His laugh burst out. “Celebrity gazelle.” Eira glared. “It’s not funny.” “It is a little funny,” Callum said, still smiling, and then his face sobered. “Okay. I won’t.” A beat. He glanced around again, taking in the stacks, the pencil marks on her notebook, the cup ring on the side table. “You’ve got… a lot of books,” he said. “It’s a bookstore,” Eira replied automatically, then realised how stupid it sounded upstairs. “I like books.” Callum’s mouth curved. “I like that you had to clarify.” Eira felt heat climb up her neck. “I didn’t have to.” “You did,” Callum said gently, like he wasn’t teasing, like he was noting a fact about her the way he might note a mark on a script. Eira turned away abruptly and went back downstairs as if retreat were a strategy. Callum followed, slower now, quieter. In the back room again, Eira picked up her watch, stared at it, then shoved it in her pocket. Callum sat without being told this time, hands folded around the mug as it cooled. He watched her with unsettling attention. Eira busied herself with the box cutter, slicing open a carton labelled *DONATIONS*. “Fine,” she said, to the cardboard more than to him. Callum lifted his eyebrows. “Fine what.” Eira pulled out a stack of books, thumped them on the table. “You can stay upstairs tonight.” Callum went utterly still. Eira held up a hand before he could speak. “One night.” His throat worked. “Eira—” “Don’t,” she warned. He nodded, jaw tight with the effort of not thanking her like she’d saved his life. Eira kept her eyes on the books, on the safe solidity of paper. “You sleep. In the spare room. You leave at dawn. You do not open the curtains. You do not post anything. You do not tell anyone where you are.” Callum’s voice came out rough. “Why.” Eira’s hands stopped. She hated the question because it required an answer that wasn’t practical. “Because if you go out there now,” she said, “they’ll follow you again. And if they follow you again, they’ll come back here. And I don’t want them back here.” Callum looked at her as if she’d said something else entirely. “And,” Eira added quickly, too quickly, “because I can’t be bothered to mop up any more of your rainwater today.” His mouth twitched, but he didn’t smile fully. He seemed to be holding himself carefully, like a glass that had already been cracked. “I can help,” he said. Eira snorted. “With what. Mop theatrically.” “With the shop,” Callum said, earnest. “With whatever you need. If I’m here, I should be… useful.” Eira’s first instinct was to refuse. Her second was to picture him upstairs all night like a trapped animal, vibrating with nerves, and the small, unwanted part of her that cared. She pushed a stack of paperbacks toward him. “Sort those. Fiction. Alphabetical.” Callum stared at the pile like she’d handed him a live fish. “Alphabetical.” Eira nodded. “You know the alphabet.” He hesitated. “I— yes.” “Good,” Eira said, and turned away before he could see the smile that threatened. Behind her, he let out a quiet breath—relief, maybe, or the strange comfort of being told what to do. Outside, the rain kept falling. And somewhere in it, attention waited, patient as mould. Eira pretended she couldn’t feel it pressing at the glass. She pretended she couldn’t feel him, either—sitting at her table, sorting her books with careful hands as if the order of letters could keep the world out.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong craft in character development and dialogue, successfully building on the foundation established in Chapter 1. The writing maintains the distinct voices of both protagonists while deepening their dynamic through forced proximity and escalating tension. The characterization is particularly well-executed. Callum's fragile ego and people-pleasing compulsions are shown through specific behaviors - his over-apologizing, his physical reactions to his phone buzzing, and his desperate need for approval even in small interactions. His vulnerability emerges naturally through his conversation with his publicist, where we hear him claim he's "not hiding" while literally hiding. Eira's controlled exterior masking inner conflict is effectively portrayed through her practical deflections and the way she catches herself offering more help than she intended. The dialogue carries the chapter effectively, with each character maintaining their established voice patterns. Eira's dry, clipped responses ("It's a bookstore") contrast well with Callum's more expansive, approval-seeking speech. The subtext works well - particularly in moments like when Callum says "I'm alone" on the phone while Eira is present, or when she offers him the spare room "because I can't be bothered to mop up any more of your rainwater." The chapter follows its planned structure faithfully, moving from the back room setup through the phone call revelation to Eira's decision to let him stay overnight. The pacing feels natural, with tension building through small moments rather than manufactured drama. However, there are some weaknesses. Certain exchanges feel slightly over-written, particularly some of Eira's more cutting responses that border on being too perfectly witty. The "celebrity gazelle" moment, while amusing, feels slightly forced in its cleverness. Some of the internal observations about the characters' motivations occasionally tip toward telling rather than showing, though this is generally well-controlled. The emotional beats land effectively, particularly Callum's genuine gratitude when offered shelter and Eira's internal conflict about helping him. The chapter successfully maintains the romantic tension while avoiding premature intimacy, keeping both characters guarded but showing cracks in their defenses. The Welsh setting remains present but not overdone, integrated naturally through references to the town's social dynamics and Eira's lived experience. The confined space of the bookstore creates appropriate pressure for character development. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 3: Everybody’s Cousin By ten the next morning the rain had given up pretending it would stop. It softened, became a constant mist that clung to coats and hair and the edges of people’s moods. Eira unlocked the front door and flipped the sign to *OPEN* with an irritation that felt personal. The bell rang once, accusingly, as if the shop itself disapproved of the decision. Upstairs, the floorboards creaked. Eira didn’t look up. “Stay put.” A pause. Then Callum’s voice floated down the stairwell, careful, subdued. “I’m not moving.” “Good,” Eira called back, and bent to straighten the display of local history books that had been jostled by yesterday’s chaos. She’d expected him to sleep late, to sulk, to complain. Instead he’d been silent as a book all night. When she’d gone upstairs at eleven to make sure he hadn’t opened a window and waved at the world, she’d found him on the spare-room bed with the blanket pulled up too neatly, eyes open. “You asleep?” she’d asked. He’d blinked. “I’m… trying.” Now, in the morning light, he remained invisible. That was a relief. It was also—annoyingly—disappointing, like hearing a song end before the chorus. The bell rang. “Bore da,” came a familiar voice, cheerful as a habit. “Bore da, Mrs Parry,” Eira replied. Mrs Parry entered like she owned the air. She was small, bright-eyed, wrapped in a raincoat the colour of a warning sign. She carried a tote bag and a sense of purpose. “Cold out,” Mrs Parry announced, wiping her shoes on the mat with excessive vigour. “It’s November,” Eira said. Mrs Parry ignored that. “I saw you closed yesterday.” Eira reached for the receipt book, ready to weaponise administration. “I had things to do.” Mrs Parry’s gaze swept the shop, missing nothing. “Mm.” Eira knew that “Mm.” It meant: *I don’t believe you, but I’ll let you tell yourself you’ve hidden it.* Mrs Parry drifted to the counter, leaned in conspiratorially. “There were two men outside.” “Two men with umbrellas,” Eira corrected. “They didn’t have umbrellas,” Mrs Parry said, delighted by the detail. “They were getting soaked on purpose. Who does that?” “Idiots,” Eira said. Mrs Parry beamed, as if Eira had told a joke. “Couldn’t have been for you. Not unless you’ve got a secret admirer who can’t be bothered to buy flowers.” Eira forced a bland expression. “Do you want a book, Mrs Parry, or do you want to interrogate me?” Mrs Parry tapped the counter. “Both.” Before Eira could answer, there was a soft thud upstairs—like a footstep that had tried and failed to be quiet. Mrs Parry’s head snapped up. Eira’s stomach tightened. “What was that?” Mrs Parry asked. “Radiator,” Eira lied. Mrs Parry narrowed her eyes. “Your radiator has shoes.” Eira leaned forward. “Mrs Parry.” “Yes, cariad,” Mrs Parry said, and the endearment made it worse. “You know I only want the best for you.” Eira lowered her voice. “Then buy a book.” Mrs Parry laughed, delighted. “All right. I need something for my grandson. He’s eight. He doesn’t like reading.” “That’s because he’s eight,” Eira said, and reached for a shelf without looking up, grateful for the excuse to move. As she pulled out a book, she felt rather than saw Mrs Parry’s attention slide back toward the stairs. Upstairs, a board creaked again, followed by a sharp intake of breath—as if Callum had realised he’d made a sound. Eira closed her eyes briefly. *Stay put,* she thought at the ceiling, as if thoughts could travel through floorboards. Mrs Parry leaned around the display, trying for a better angle. Eira stepped into her line of sight, a human bookend. “This one,” she said, holding up a bright illustrated adventure. “He’ll like it.” Mrs Parry took it, inspected the cover. “He might.” Eira rang it up quickly, shoved it into a bag. “That’ll be £6.” Mrs Parry paid, still watching Eira’s face. “You’re tense.” “I’m alive,” Eira said. Mrs Parry’s smile softened, almost kind. “Eira. If you ever need help—” “I don’t,” Eira said too fast. Mrs Parry didn’t seem offended. She patted Eira’s hand once, brisk as a stamp. “All right then. But you can’t hide from the whole town. The town always finds out.” Eira held her smile in place. “Diolch.” Mrs Parry left, the bell ringing behind her. Eira exhaled slowly. She stared at the door as if it might open again and disgorge a camera crew. Upstairs, the floorboards creaked once, tentative. Eira looked up at the ceiling. “If you move, I swear to God—” Callum’s voice, muffled. “I was only— I dropped my sock.” Eira blinked. “What.” “I dropped my sock,” he repeated, as if it was a reasonable crisis. Eira pressed her fingers to her forehead. “How.” “I took my shoes off like a person,” he said defensively. “Then I stepped on my own sock. It fell. Gravity happened.” Eira closed her eyes. “Stop narrating your sock.” Silence. Then, quieter: “Sorry.” Eira took a breath. “Just— stay away from the windows.” “I am away,” Callum said. “I’m miles away. I’m basically in another postcode.” Eira couldn’t help the small laugh that escaped her. It startled her—sound she hadn’t planned. Upstairs there was a pause, then Callum’s voice softened. “That was a laugh.” “It was air,” Eira snapped, but it lacked conviction. The bell rang again. Eira straightened instinctively, wiped her hands on her jeans, put her shop face back on. This time it was Idris from the post office, carrying a cardboard parcel and wearing an expression that suggested he’d rather be anywhere else. “Morning,” Idris said, and held up the parcel. “Got one for you.” Eira took it. The label was typed. A return address in Cardiff. She didn’t recognise the sender. “Cheers,” she said. Idris didn’t leave. He hovered. Eira looked up. “What.” Idris scratched his jaw. “You all right, Eira?” Eira’s mouth went dry. “Why wouldn’t I be.” Idris glanced at the window, lowering his voice. “There was… talk.” “Talk,” Eira echoed, flat. “You know,” Idris said, uncomfortable. “Facebook.” Eira’s spine stiffened. “I’m not on Facebook.” “You don’t need to be,” Idris muttered. “It finds you anyway.” Eira’s fingers tightened around the parcel. “What does it say.” Idris hesitated. “Just— people saying they saw… someone. Yesterday. In town.” Eira forced her expression into mild boredom. “People see people.” Idris gave her a long look, then nodded once, like he was choosing not to push. “Right. Well. If anyone’s bothering you—” “I’m fine,” Eira said again. Idris shrugged and backed toward the door. “Okay. See you.” When he left, Eira set the parcel down hard on the counter. Upstairs, there was no sound. Eira stared at the parcel label until the letters blurred. Then she picked it up and carried it to the back room with purposeful steps, as if purpose could keep her from shaking. Callum came down the stairs like he couldn’t help it—slow, careful, one hand on the rail. He stopped at the bottom as soon as he saw her face. “You’re not fine,” he said. Eira snapped the back-room door shut behind her, leaving him in the corridor, then opened it again just enough to glare. “Get back upstairs.” Callum didn’t move. “Is it because of me.” Eira’s laugh was sharp. “Who else would it be because of.” He flinched, but he didn’t retreat. That, too, was a kind of performance. Bravery that asked for applause. “I can go,” he said. “I can leave now.” “And go where,” Eira demanded. “Down the street so they can follow you back again? Or do you think if you leave dramatically it stops being my problem?” Callum’s jaw tightened. “I’m not trying to be dramatic.” “You’re an actor,” Eira said. “Everything you do is dramatic.” His eyes flashed—hurt and anger together. “That’s not fair.” Eira opened her mouth to respond, then stopped. Her chest felt tight. She didn’t want to fight. She wanted—she didn’t know what she wanted. Quiet. Control. A refund. She took a breath and forced her voice lower. “Idris said there’s talk. Online. People guessing.” Callum’s shoulders sagged a fraction. “They’ll guess.” Eira looked at him. “And you’re just… okay with that.” He let out a humourless laugh. “No. I’m just used to it.” Something in Eira softened, unwillingly, at the flatness of that. Used to it. Like it was weather. She looked away quickly, back at the parcel on the table. “Go upstairs,” she said again. “You can’t be seen.” Callum stepped closer, then stopped, as if he’d learned at least one rule. “Eira. If it gets worse—if people come in here—” “It won’t,” she lied. Callum’s mouth twisted. “You don’t know that.” “I do know,” Eira said, because she needed to. “This town gets bored. They’ll move on.” Callum’s eyes held hers. “They don’t get bored of me.” The honesty in that—raw, unadorned—hit her like cold water. Eira swallowed. “Then you should leave.” Callum nodded slowly. “Okay.” He turned, took one step toward the stairs, then stopped. “What,” Eira said, already tired. Callum looked back at her, expression carefully blank, like he was holding something behind his teeth. “Thank you,” he said, very quietly. “For last night.” Eira’s irritation flared, instinctive. “Don’t.” His mouth curved, just a fraction. “I know. Sorry.” He went upstairs. Eira stood alone in the back room, staring at the closed door, annoyed at the heat in her face. She picked up the parcel and opened it with more force than necessary. Inside was a single book, wrapped in brown paper. A note slid out. Eira unfolded it. *Callum’s in Wales. Keep him quiet. Keep him safe. I’ll pay. — M.* Eira’s fingers went numb. Upstairs, a floorboard creaked softly, like a question. Eira stared at the note, then crumpled it in her fist. “Of course,” she said to the empty room, voice low and furious. “Of course that’s what this is.” She smoothed the book’s cover with her palm without thinking. It was a hardback—new, expensive. The title meant nothing to her. In the shop, the bell rang again. Eira shoved the note into her pocket and went out, face composed. A teenager stood by the counter, hood up, eyes too bright. Carys—one of her Saturday helpers, officially on “study leave” until exams ended, but apparently here anyway. “Hi,” Carys said, too casually. “I was just… passing.” Eira gave her a long look. “You never just pass.” Carys grinned. “Fair. So. Weird question.” Eira’s stomach tightened. “No.” Carys leaned in, lowering her voice dramatically. “Is there someone upstairs?” Eira didn’t answer. Carys’s eyes widened, triumphant. “Oh my God.” Eira’s voice went flat. “Carys.” Carys held up both hands. “I’m not saying anything! I just— I heard. Like, everyone’s saying. And then Mam said she saw a guy in a posh coat and—” “Carys,” Eira repeated, harder. Carys swallowed, excitement battling caution. “Is it him.” Eira stared at her. “Who is him.” Carys rolled her eyes like Eira was doing a bit. “Callum Hart.” Eira felt her pulse jump, traitorous. She kept her face still. “No.” Carys squinted. “That was the fastest no I’ve ever heard.” Eira leaned forward. “Do you want to help me today or do you want to gossip.” Carys hesitated. “Help.” “Then help,” Eira said. “And you don’t mention this again. To anyone.” Carys’s grin softened into something more serious. “Is he in trouble.” Eira looked at the girl—the sharpness, the curiosity, the way the whole world was a story waiting to be told. Eira remembered being that age. She remembered how power felt like knowing things. Eira’s voice softened despite herself. “Yes,” she said. “And if you tell, you’ll make it worse.” Carys nodded slowly. “Okay.” Upstairs, the floorboards were silent. But Eira could feel him listening anyway—like the whole building had become a nervous system. The bell rang again, and the day kept coming in, wet and nosy, as if it had every right.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong craft in several key areas while maintaining the established tone and character dynamics from the romance prompt. The writing successfully builds tension through the mounting pressure of small-town scrutiny, using dialogue-driven scenes to reveal character while advancing the plot. The characterizations remain sharp and consistent. Eira's defensive competence shines through her interactions with Mrs. Parry and Idris, showing her skill at deflecting curiosity while revealing her growing anxiety. Her voice maintains its dry precision ("This is a bookshop, not Narnia") while allowing glimpses of vulnerability. Callum's confined presence upstairs creates effective dramatic irony - his attempts to remain invisible (the dropped sock incident) humanize him while maintaining tension. The chapter excels at showing rather than telling emotional states. Eira's mounting stress manifests through physical actions (gripping the parcel, forcing her voice lower) and defensive responses rather than internal exposition. The town's growing awareness unfolds naturally through Mrs. Parry's probing questions and Idris's uncomfortable mention of Facebook talk, creating authentic small-town pressure. The dialogue feels natural and character-specific. Mrs. Parry's cheerful nosiness ("They didn't have umbrellas... Who does that?") contrasts effectively with Eira's clipped responses and Callum's muffled explanations from upstairs. The conversation rhythms feel authentic to the Welsh setting without relying on heavy dialect. The plot advancement is well-paced, introducing the mysterious note from "M" that adds complexity without feeling contrived. This revelation recontextualizes Callum's presence while raising new questions about his situation. The introduction of Carys as a potential complication feels organic to the small-town setting. However, some elements feel slightly mechanical. The sequence of visitors (Mrs. Parry, Idris, Carys) follows a predictable pattern of escalating suspicion. While each interaction serves the plot, the structure becomes somewhat formulaic. Additionally, some of Callum's dialogue from upstairs ("I'm basically in another postcode") occasionally tips toward trying too hard for charm, though this may be intentional characterization. The writing maintains good control over tone, balancing humor (the sock incident) with genuine tension. The prose is clean and purposeful, avoiding overwrought metaphors while including vivid details that ground the scene in its Welsh coastal setting. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 4: The Chapel Hall “You can’t come.” “I can carry a box,” Callum said. Eira didn’t look up from the ledger. “You can carry a box in the flat. Up and down the hall. Privately.” Callum leaned against the doorframe of the back room, arms folded like he was trying to look casual and failing. His hair had dried into the kind of careless wave people paid for. He’d borrowed one of her old jumpers—too short in the sleeves, stretched across his shoulders—and it annoyed her every time she noticed. “I’m not going to be seen,” he said. “I’ll wear… a hat.” “A hat,” Eira repeated, deadpan. “A magical invisibility hat.” “Do you have one,” Callum asked, equally deadpan back. “Or do we need to improvise with a tea towel.” Eira’s mouth twitched, quickly suppressed. “No.” Callum watched her face with hungry attentiveness. “That was nearly a smile.” “It was a facial spasm,” Eira said. “Caused by stress.” Callum pushed off the frame, coming into the room. “Eira.” She sighed, closed the ledger. “What.” “I’m going mad upstairs,” he said. “I’m not built for… hiding.” “You are literally built for it,” Eira replied. “It’s your whole job. Pretend to be someone else, in a room, without being caught.” “That’s not hiding,” Callum said. “That’s… being watched. On purpose. There are marks on the floor. People clap. Completely different.” Eira snorted. “Aw. Poor you. People clap.” He winced, then smiled anyway. “See. That. That’s what I mean. I can’t… do anything right with you.” Eira stared at him. “You’re doing fine. You’re alive. Congratulations.” Callum’s smile faded into something more cautious. “Are you always like this.” “Yes,” Eira lied. Callum tilted his head. “Then why did you let me stay.” Eira felt her chest tighten. She stood up too quickly. “Because I’m not heartless.” “Right,” he said softly. “Just immune.” Eira grabbed a stack of donated books, using weight as an excuse to not answer. “We need to take these to the chapel hall.” Callum stepped into her path, careful not to touch her, like he’d learned touch was a minefield. “Let me come with you.” “No.” “Why not,” he pressed. Not whining—testing, like he couldn’t help it. “Because you’ll be recognised,” Eira said. “I won’t,” Callum said. “I’ll keep my head down. I’ll be—” he searched for the word, “—background.” Eira barked a laugh. “You don’t know how to be background.” Callum’s jaw tightened. “I can learn.” Eira looked at him, properly, for the first time that day. He looked tired. Not sleepy—tired in a way that sat under the skin. He’d been too quiet since the Facebook post, since the note in the parcel. He kept checking his phone and pretending he wasn’t. He’d stopped trying to charm Carys when she came in, stopped trying to win Eira back when she snapped. He’d turned inward. That, more than anything, made her uneasy. Eira exhaled. “Fine.” Callum’s head lifted. Hope flashed. Eira held up a finger. “Conditions.” His mouth curved. “Of course.” “You wear something that doesn’t scream… you,” Eira said. He glanced down at the jumper. “This screams you.” Eira rolled her eyes. “Not that. A cap. Hood up. You keep your mouth shut.” “That seems unfair,” Callum said. “I don’t care,” Eira replied. “And you don’t walk beside me like some… escort.” Callum’s brows rose. “Escort. That’s a nice mental image.” Eira turned away, cheeks hot. “And if someone speaks to you—” “I don’t speak back,” he finished. Eira paused. “You can nod. People nod here.” Callum’s smile softened. “I can nod.” “And,” Eira added, because she could feel herself slipping, “the moment you feel recognised, we leave.” Callum nodded, serious. “Okay.” Eira shoved a beanie into his hands from the lost-and-found box by the counter. It was navy, slightly misshapen. Callum stared at it. “This is… stylish.” “It’s warm,” Eira said. “Put it on.” He did. It sat too high on his head at first; he tugged it down, hair springing out at the edges. Eira looked away quickly before she could laugh. They left through the back door into the lane, the air damp and cold. The town smelled of wet stone and seaweed and chimney smoke that couldn’t quite overcome the salt. Eira carried one box. Callum carried two, because of course he did, because usefulness was another kind of performance. They walked with a gap between them that felt deliberate, like a line drawn on the pavement. Callum kept his head down, gaze flicking up only to scan corners. Eira tried not to watch him do it. “Stop looking like that,” she muttered. Callum didn’t raise his head. “Like what.” “Like you’re about to bolt,” Eira said. “That’s because I might be about to bolt,” he replied, quietly. Eira’s mouth tightened. “Then don’t come.” “I’m here,” Callum said, and there was something stubborn in it. “I’m doing the thing you said.” Eira stopped outside the chapel hall and looked at him. The building was squat, grey stone, windows fogged. A handwritten sign by the door: *Noson Codi Arian — Tea & Cake — 7pm*. “You know you don’t have to prove anything,” she said, more gently than she intended. Callum’s eyes flicked up to hers. Under the beanie, his face looked younger, less like an image. “I’m not proving. I’m… trying.” Eira nodded once and pushed the door open. Warm air and chatter hit them. The smell of instant coffee and sponge cake. Someone had put out plastic chairs in neat rows. A woman at a folding table took coins in a tin. “Eira!” called Mrs Jenkins from the kitchen, wiping her hands on an apron. “Thank goodness. Put those on the stage.” Eira nodded and walked in, feeling the familiar tug of belonging and scrutiny. People glanced up, smiled, nodded. A chorus of “Bore da,” “All right?” “Cold, isn’t it.” Callum followed, head down, silent, the boxes balanced against his chest. Eira felt eyes follow the tall stranger behind her. She felt her spine tighten. Mrs Jenkins looked at Callum, then at Eira. Her gaze sharpened with interest. “Who’s this then.” Eira didn’t miss a beat. “Delivery.” Callum’s mouth twitched. Mrs Jenkins frowned. “He’s a bit handsome for a delivery.” Eira forced a laugh that sounded like choking. “He’s just helping.” Mrs Jenkins leaned closer, lowering her voice to stage whisper volume. “Is he yours.” Eira’s face went hot all over. “No.” Callum shifted behind her, and she could feel him listening. Of course he was. Mrs Jenkins hummed. “Pity.” Eira marched toward the stage area and set her box down with unnecessary force. “Where do you want these.” “Here,” said a man arranging a microphone stand. He glanced at Callum, then away, polite. “Diolch, mate.” Callum nodded once, as instructed, and placed his boxes down. He didn’t speak. Eira stared at him for a beat—impressed despite herself. He was actually doing it. He was holding himself inside his own skin. She turned away quickly, irritated at the admiration prickling through her. From the far side of the hall, Carys appeared, eyes wide, taking in the scene with greedy delight. Eira’s blood ran cold. Carys marched over, phone in hand. “Eira! I didn’t know you were coming early. Mam said—” Her gaze landed on Callum. Her eyes practically lit up. “Oh.” Eira stepped in front of her. “Carys.” Carys looked at Eira’s face, then at Callum’s beanie, then back again. “Right. Hello.” Callum nodded at Carys, expression neutral. Carys nodded back, lips pressed tight as if physically restraining herself from squealing. Eira lowered her voice. “Kitchen. Now.” Carys followed, still staring over Eira’s shoulder. In the kitchen, away from most eyes, Eira rounded on her. “What are you doing here.” Carys lifted her hands. “Helping. It’s the fundraiser.” “You’re supposed to be studying,” Eira hissed. Carys grinned. “I study better with cake.” Eira leaned in. “You can’t—” She glanced at the doorway, making sure no one was listening. “You cannot say anything.” Carys sobered. “I won’t. I promised.” Eira searched her face, looking for the crack—where excitement would break into betrayal. She saw, instead, a kind of awe. The same awe she’d refused to give. Carys whispered, “He looks… smaller.” Eira frowned. “What.” Carys shrugged, fidgeting. “On screens he’s like… huge. Here he’s just… a man in a sad hat.” Eira’s mouth twitched, unwilling. “It’s not a sad hat. It’s a warm hat.” Carys’s grin returned. “Okay. Warm. Sad.” Eira pointed at her. “Cake. Tea. Jobs. No phones.” Carys saluted. “Yes, boss.” Eira exhaled, then stepped back into the hall. Callum was standing near the stage, hands in his pockets, shoulders slightly hunched. He looked out of place and determined not to show it. A woman approached him—middle-aged, kind face. “You all right, love. You look a bit lost.” Eira’s pulse jumped. Callum’s mouth opened—habit ready to spill out. Eira caught his eye and gave a tiny shake of her head. Callum closed his mouth, swallowed, and nodded once. The woman smiled and patted his arm, motherly. “Good boy. Tea’s there.” Callum nodded again. As she walked away, Callum turned to Eira, eyes wide with something like panic and triumph. He leaned in, voice low. “I didn’t speak,” he whispered. Eira’s lips pressed together. “Well done.” Callum’s smile broke out, boyish and unguarded. “You sounded like you meant it.” “I didn’t,” Eira lied automatically. Callum’s grin widened. “You’re a terrible liar.” Eira felt her cheeks heat. “Be quiet.” He did. For a second. Then: “Is this what you do.” “What,” Eira said, scanning the hall, heart thumping too fast. “This,” Callum murmured. “This… world. Everyone knows where to stand. Everyone has a role. It’s like… theatre without applause.” Eira glanced at him. “There’s plenty of applause. You just don’t like it because it’s not for you.” Callum’s smile faltered, but he didn’t argue. He watched the people moving around, the women setting plates, the men adjusting chairs, the children darting between legs. His gaze softened. A man at the microphone tapped it. “Right! Settle down. We’ll start in five. And if anyone’s got a poem or a song, come up. No pressure.” A ripple of laughter. Eira began to move toward the back, to help Mrs Jenkins, to disappear into usefulness. Callum followed half a step behind before he caught himself and stopped. Eira turned, irritated. “Stay. There.” Callum obeyed, but his eyes stayed on her as she walked away, like he’d been told to stand still in a storm. Later—after tea poured and chairs scraped and someone sang a hymn slightly out of tune—Mrs Jenkins waved Eira over, flustered. “Eira,” she hissed. “Gareth’s gone and disappeared. He was meant to read his poem. He’s at home with a migraine, apparently.” Eira frowned. “So get someone else.” Mrs Jenkins’s eyes darted. “No one else will. They’re all shy.” Eira stared at her. “Then skip it.” “We can’t skip it,” Mrs Jenkins whispered, scandalised. “It’s on the programme.” Eira looked at the programme—photocopied sheets in a stack. *Poem Reading — Gareth Evans.* She felt, absurdly, the weight of the missing poem like a dropped plate. And then she saw Callum across the hall, leaning against the wall, hands in pockets, listening with that actor’s attention. He looked, for once, like he wanted to be useful without being seen. Eira’s stomach clenched. Mrs Jenkins followed her gaze, eyes lighting with mischievous interest. “Oh.” Eira snapped, “No.” Mrs Jenkins grinned. “He could do it.” “He can’t,” Eira hissed. Mrs Jenkins leaned closer. “Why not.” Because his voice was a fingerprint. Because the whole town would turn. Because she didn’t want to see what it would do to him, to her, to the fragile truce between hiding and living. Eira swallowed. “Because he doesn’t want to.” Mrs Jenkins straightened, already waving at Callum. “Hey! Tall boy! Can you read something for us.” Eira’s heart dropped straight into her boots. Callum’s head lifted. The room seemed to notice him, the way rooms do when something shifts. He looked at Mrs Jenkins, then at Eira. Eira held his gaze. She didn’t shake her head this time. Callum hesitated—charm and fear wrestling in his face. Then, quietly, he nodded. Eira’s throat tightened. Callum walked toward the stage, steps careful, shoulders squared like he was walking into a spotlight he hadn’t chosen. As he passed Eira, he leaned in, voice barely audible. “I can do background,” he murmured. “But I can also… read.” Eira didn’t trust herself to answer. Callum reached the microphone. He adjusted it down a fraction, hands steady. The hall quieted, expectant. He cleared his throat. And when he spoke—just a single, “Evening”—his voice filled the room in a way that made Eira’s stomach flip. Not because it was famous. Because it was beautiful.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong character work and dialogue craft, successfully executing the planned chapel hall sequence while maintaining the established dynamic between Eira and Callum. The writing shows particular strength in capturing the social dynamics of a small Welsh town and the tension between public and private selves. The characterization remains consistent and nuanced throughout. Eira's protective instincts war with her attraction, shown through her reluctant agreement to let Callum accompany her and her careful management of social interactions. Callum's struggle with his need for approval versus his attempt to remain invisible creates genuine internal conflict. His moment of triumph at successfully "not speaking" feels earned and reveals his vulnerability beneath the charm. The dialogue maintains distinct voices for each character. Eira's dry practicality ("This is a bookshop, not Narnia") contrasts effectively with Callum's more performative speech patterns, even when he's trying to be subdued. The supporting characters like Mrs. Jenkins and Carys feel authentic to the Welsh setting without becoming caricatures. The plot progression follows the chapter plan faithfully, building tension through the forced proximity in a public space where Callum must suppress his natural instincts. The climactic moment where he agrees to read creates genuine stakes - his voice being his "fingerprint" is a well-established vulnerability that pays off here. However, the chapter suffers from some pacing issues in the middle section, where the back-and-forth about whether Callum can come feels slightly repetitive. Some of the internal observations, while generally effective, occasionally veer toward over-explanation of character motivations that could be better shown through action. The Welsh setting feels authentic without being heavy-handed. Details like the bilingual sign and natural use of Welsh phrases ground the story in place. The chapel hall fundraiser provides an ideal pressure cooker for the central conflict between visibility and privacy. The ending creates effective dramatic tension, with Callum's agreement to read representing a significant character choice that will have consequences. The final line about his voice being "beautiful" rather than just "famous" suggests Eira's growing ability to see past his celebrity. The writing generally avoids purple prose, though there are occasional moments where metaphors feel slightly strained. The emotional beats feel earned rather than manipulative, and the lightness emerges naturally from character interactions rather than forced humor. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 5: Bad at Being Hidden The silence after Callum’s “Evening” had weight. It wasn’t the hush of recognition—not at first. It was the hush of a room surprised into listening. Callum glanced down at the programme in his hand as if it might save him. He didn’t have a poem. He didn’t have Gareth Evans’s migraine or his earnest rhymes about the sea. He had only himself. “I’m—” he began, then stopped. The smile tried to appear and didn’t quite manage it. He swallowed. “I don’t have what Gareth was going to read.” A ripple of laughter, gentle. Callum’s shoulders loosened a fraction. He leaned into it, reflexively. “So, unfortunately, you’re stuck with me.” More laughter. Warmer now. Eira, standing near the kitchen door with a stack of plates in her arms, felt her stomach drop with a complicated mix of dread and… pride, which she resented immediately. He’d done it. He’d found the room. Of course he had. He could find a room in the dark. Callum continued, voice steadying. “But I… I can read something else. If that’s all right.” Someone called, “Go on then!” Another voice: “Read some Dylan Thomas!” Callum smiled at that, quick and charming. “That feels like a trap.” The hall laughed again. Eira shut her eyes. This—this was exactly the thing. The moment he became the moment. The town would go home with it on their tongues. *You should’ve heard him. You should’ve seen him.* Callum looked down, then up, scanning the front rows. His gaze flicked briefly to Eira. He didn’t ask permission this time. He only checked she was still there. He began to read. Not Dylan Thomas. Something quieter, something about the sea and the way it takes and returns. His voice made it sound like a confession that didn’t need to be admitted. Eira stood very still, plates forgotten, as if moving would break the fragile spell. When he finished, the applause came. Not the screaming kind. The kind that meant: *Thank you for giving us something.* Callum took it like he was starving. He dipped his head, a small bow. The beanie stayed on, absurd and somehow intimate. “Diolch,” he said, and the Welsh word in his mouth was careful, almost reverent. That did it. A murmur ran through the room like wind through grass. Heads turned. People leaned. Eyes sharpened. Eira felt it in her bones: the shift from listening to *knowing*. Callum stepped down quickly. Too quickly. The spell broke. By the time Eira got him back out into the wet night, the town had already begun to write the story. They walked fast. Callum kept his head down. Eira kept her pace sharp enough to discourage conversation. Halfway down the lane, Callum let out a breath that shook. “That was… stupid.” Eira didn’t slow. “Yes.” Callum huffed a laugh, then swallowed it. “I thought I could— I don’t know. Just… do a thing.” “You did a thing,” Eira said. “You did a very recognisable thing with your very recognisable voice.” Callum’s jaw tightened. “You didn’t stop me.” Eira stopped so abruptly he nearly walked into her. She turned on him, rain misting her face. “You’re a grown man,” she said, low and furious. “I’m not your handler.” Callum stared at her, eyes wide. “I didn’t mean—” “I know what you meant,” Eira snapped. Then, because she couldn’t stop herself: “You were good.” Callum blinked. Eira instantly regretted it. She turned and started walking again. Behind her, Callum’s footsteps hurried to match. “You just— you just said I was good.” “I said you caused a problem,” Eira replied, too quickly. “That’s not what you said,” Callum insisted, and there was something almost boyish in the way he held onto it, like a child holding a sweet. Eira clenched her teeth. “Go home.” Callum’s laugh was breathy. “We’re going to the same place.” Eira flinched at the intimacy of that accidental truth and increased her pace. — The next morning the shop had the kind of busy that made Eira’s scalp prickle. Not Christmas-busy. Not tourist-season busy. A strange, pointed busy. People came in with too-bright smiles. People who didn’t usually come in, who pretended to browse while holding their phones at chest level. People who asked questions they didn’t care about. “Do you stock biographies?” a woman asked, eyes darting toward the stairs. “Sometimes,” Eira said. “Any… actor ones?” the woman pressed, grin tight. Eira gave her a flat look. “We’re a secondhand shop. We stock whatever people abandon.” The woman laughed too loud and wandered away. Carys hovered behind the counter, cheeks flushed with the excitement she was trying to contain. She was being useful—ringing up, tidying, making tea for Mrs Parry—but her eyes kept flicking to the staircase like it was an advent calendar. Eira leaned in and hissed, “Stop looking.” Carys whispered back, “I’m not looking.” “You’re looking,” Eira said. Carys’s lips twitched. “It’s hard not to.” Eira glanced toward the stairs. Callum hadn’t come down once. He’d obeyed, at least, that part. The bell rang again. A man in a raincoat stepped in, mid-thirties, clean-shaven, friendly face that didn’t reach his eyes. He smiled at Eira. “Morning.” “Morning,” Eira replied, already tired. “Can I help you?” He wandered to the display table, picked up a paperback without looking at the cover. His gaze kept lifting, measuring the shop. “I’m just browsing,” he said. Eira watched him. He didn’t browse like a reader. He browsed like someone waiting for something to happen. Carys leaned close, whispering, “That’s not one of ours.” “I know,” Eira murmured. The man drifted closer to the counter. “Quiet little town.” “It was,” Eira said. He smiled, the way people do when they think they’re on the same side. “I heard you had a bit of excitement.” Eira didn’t answer. The man tipped his head. “You know, my sister loves Callum Hart. Massive fan. She’d be over the moon if I could get a quick—” “No,” Eira said. He blinked as if he hadn’t understood. “Just a hello. Five seconds. I’d pay for a book.” “You can pay for a book without saying his name,” Eira replied. His smile tightened. “So he is here.” Eira’s voice went flat. “Buy something or leave.” The man’s gaze slid past her toward the back. “I’m not looking for trouble. I’m looking for a moment. You understand.” Eira leaned forward. “I understand entitlement.” Carys made a small sound behind her. Eira didn’t look; she could feel the girl’s tension. The man shrugged, still smiling. “All right, love. No need to be unfriendly. I’m only asking.” Eira’s fingers curled around the edge of the counter. “And I’m only answering.” The man held up his hands in mock surrender and backed away, still watching Eira as if he expected her to crack. When the bell rang behind him and the door shut, Eira exhaled through her nose. Carys whispered, “You were scary.” “I’m always scary,” Eira muttered. From upstairs came a soft footstep. Then silence, as if the building itself was holding its breath. — At midday, the first selfie request came from someone Eira didn’t hate. Mrs Parry breezed in, cheeks pink from the cold, eyes bright with information. “Eira!” Eira’s stomach sank. “Mrs Parry.” Mrs Parry leaned over the counter, voice lowered to a conspiratorial whisper that carried across the shop anyway. “It’s true then.” “It’s not,” Eira said automatically, because lying had become her cardio. Mrs Parry’s eyes danced. “Don’t be silly. I heard him. At the hall. That voice! Honestly. Like butter.” Eira felt heat crawl up her neck. “You were at the hall.” “I’m always at the hall,” Mrs Parry said, offended. “Anyway. I won’t tell anyone.” Eira stared at her. “You just told me.” Mrs Parry waved a hand. “I won’t tell anyone new. But—” She leaned closer. “Just one photo, Eira. For my niece. She’s in hospital in Carmarthen. Poor thing. She’s had a hard year.” Eira’s chest tightened. Not because she believed the story—though it might be true. Because it was good. A good story. A guilt-shaped key. “I can’t,” Eira said. Mrs Parry’s smile faltered, briefly revealing real disappointment. “Oh, cariad.” “No,” Eira repeated, firmer. Mrs Parry sighed. “All right. All right. Worth asking.” Eira’s voice softened despite herself. “How’s your niece?” Mrs Parry brightened again, relieved to pivot to real life. “She’ll be fine. She’s tougher than she looks.” Eira nodded. “Good.” Mrs Parry patted the counter. “Tell him I said hello.” Eira closed her eyes. “Mrs Parry.” Mrs Parry laughed and wandered off to browse, humming. Carys leaned in, whispering, “Did you hear that? Hospital. That’s—” “That’s manipulation,” Eira murmured back, harsher than she meant. Then she softened: “Or it’s just… wanting. People want things.” Carys frowned. “Is that… bad.” Eira watched Mrs Parry’s bright head bob between the shelves. “Not always. But it doesn’t make it theirs.” Upstairs, a floorboard creaked. Eira looked up. Callum stood at the top of the stairs, partially hidden by the wall, hair damp as if he’d showered. He wore the beanie again, like armour. His eyes were fixed on Eira, expression tight. Eira’s stomach flipped. “Go back,” she mouthed. Callum didn’t. He came down slowly, each step a decision. Carys’s eyes went huge. She clapped a hand over her mouth. Mrs Parry looked up at the sound of feet and froze mid-browse. The shop seemed to tilt toward him. Callum reached the bottom of the stairs and stopped beside the counter, close enough that Eira could smell soap and the faint scent of old wool from her jumper. He leaned in, voice low, only for her. “I can fix it.” Eira’s pulse spiked. “No.” He swallowed. “I can go out. I can— I can do a smile. A wave. Then they’ll leave you alone.” Eira stared at him, horrified. “That’s not how it works.” “It is how it works,” Callum said, urgent. “I’ve done it a thousand times.” “That’s the problem,” Eira snapped, and felt eyes turning toward them, hungry. She lowered her voice. “You’re not doing it here.” Callum’s jaw clenched, the fragile ego prickling. “So you’d rather I hide upstairs while people harass you.” “I’d rather you stop making decisions like your need to be liked is a public service,” Eira hissed. Callum flinched as if she’d slapped him. Mrs Parry, delight sparkling, stepped closer. “Well,” she said loudly, “if it isn’t him.” Eira shot her a look of pure murder. Mrs Parry beamed back, unbothered. Callum turned his head slowly toward Mrs Parry. His smile flickered on out of reflex. Mrs Parry clasped her hands. “Callum Hart. In my little shop. Honestly. My niece will die.” Eira’s stomach dropped. Callum’s smile tightened. “I’m sorry to hear your niece is unwell.” Mrs Parry’s eyes shone. “Oh, she’s fine. But she’d love a photo.” Eira’s breath stopped. Callum’s gaze flicked to Eira—seeking instruction, seeking approval, seeking relief. Eira’s voice came out cold. “No photos.” Mrs Parry’s smile dimmed. “Eira—” Eira leaned forward, tone quiet and lethal. “No photos.” Callum’s mouth twitched, trapped between relief and resentment. He turned back to Mrs Parry, smile still in place. “I’m sorry. I can’t.” Mrs Parry looked between them, then sighed theatrically. “Well. Worth asking.” She patted Callum’s arm as if he belonged to the town now. “You look tired, love.” Callum’s smile slipped. The kindness landed harder than the manipulation. “Yeah,” he said softly, and it wasn’t an actor’s line. It was just true. Mrs Parry wandered away again, humming, and the shop exhaled, disappointed by the lack of spectacle. Eira turned on Callum. “Upstairs. Now.” Callum stared at her, face tight. “No.” Eira blinked. “What.” He swallowed, pride rising. “I’m not a dog.” Eira’s voice sharpened. “Then stop behaving like one.” Callum’s eyes flashed. He glanced around at the watching customers, the phones half-hidden, the story taking shape. And then—because he couldn’t help himself, because being disliked felt like suffocating—he turned toward the front window. Eira grabbed his sleeve. He looked down at her hand on his arm, then up at her face, something wild and wounded in his eyes. “Let go,” he said quietly. Eira didn’t. Callum pulled his arm free—not rough, but decisive. He stepped toward the door. Eira felt panic and anger collide in her chest. “Callum—” He opened the door. The bell rang once, bright and betraying. And outside, as if summoned, a camera lens lifted.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong character work and dialogue craft, effectively building tension through escalating public attention and the protagonists' conflicting responses to it. The writing successfully captures the claustrophobic feeling of a small town where privacy becomes impossible, and the dialogue feels natural and character-specific throughout. The chapter's greatest strength lies in its nuanced portrayal of both main characters. Callum's compulsive need for approval is shown through action rather than exposition - his inability to resist the chapel hall reading, his reflexive charm with Mrs. Parry, and his final destructive decision to open the door. Eira's protective instincts and control issues are equally well-rendered, particularly in her interactions with the intrusive stranger and her physical restraint of Callum. The supporting characters, especially Mrs. Parry, feel authentic rather than functional. The escalating tension is well-paced, moving from the chapel hall recognition through increasingly invasive shop visitors to the final confrontation. Each beat raises the stakes naturally. The dialogue crackles with subtext - Eira's "I understand entitlement" and Callum's wounded "I'm not a dog" both reveal character while advancing conflict. However, the chapter suffers from some structural issues. The opening section feels disconnected from the rest, jumping abruptly from the chapel hall to the next morning without adequate transition. Some moments strain credibility - would Callum really shower upstairs while hiding, and would the sound carry so clearly? The ending, while dramatically effective, feels slightly rushed in its escalation from argument to door-opening. The writing occasionally veers toward overwrought description ("the shop seemed to tilt toward him," "story taking shape") but generally maintains restraint. The Welsh setting feels authentic without being performative, and the small-town dynamics ring true. The chapter successfully follows its planned arc of Callum's people-pleasing becoming destructive, though it compresses considerable action into a relatively short space. The character consistency is excellent - Callum's fragile ego and approval addiction drive every choice, while Eira's protective control manifests in both kindness and harshness. Their conflict feels earned rather than manufactured, growing organically from their established personality flaws. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
## Chapter 6: Low Tide By evening the photo was everywhere it could possibly be while still being almost nothing. A grainy shot through rain: Callum in a navy beanie, half-turned in a doorway, one hand lifted in what might have been a wave or might have been surrender. Behind him, blurred: Eira’s face, sharp with something like fury. The caption on a tabloid site Carys had shown her—after swearing she wouldn’t look, after looking anyway—was cheerful and poisonous. *CALLUM HART HIDES OUT IN SEASIDE BOOKSHOP.* Hides out. Like she’d offered him a kennel. Eira closed the shop early without telling anyone why. She didn’t flip the sign to *CLOSED* until the last customer left, then she bolted the door and stood with her back against it, breathing too hard. Upstairs, silence. He’d gone. She’d told him to. Not in a dramatic shouting match. In two clipped sentences in the corridor after the doorbell had betrayed them and the cameras had found him like scent. “You have to leave,” she’d said. He’d stared at her as if she’d pushed him into the sea. “I know,” he’d said, voice rough. Then he’d gone upstairs and come down ten minutes later with a bag that looked lighter than it should have, as if he’d left half of himself in her flat. He’d paused at the door. “Eira.” “What,” she’d said. “I didn’t mean—” “I know,” she’d cut in, because if she let him finish, she’d soften, and then she’d do something stupid like ask him to stay. He’d nodded, once, like he understood the rules of her pride. Then he’d left into the damp. Now the flat above the shop felt too quiet, as if the building itself was listening for him. Eira climbed the stairs with the sort of determination people have when they’re trying not to cry. She made tea. She didn’t drink it. She went to bed without reading. She stared at the ceiling until her eyes burned. At three in the morning, she got up and checked the window, even though she knew he wasn’t there. She saw nothing but wet streetlights and the empty shine of the road. *Good,* she told herself. *Good. Gone. Not my circus.* Her phone buzzed once, then again, then again. Unknown numbers. Messages from people she barely knew. *Is he really in your shop??* *Omg you didn’t tell me!!* *Can you ask him to sign something for Megan?* Eira turned the phone off and lay back down, staring at the dark. Her chest ached with something she refused to name. — In the morning, she opened the shop like a person with no choice. Carys arrived ten minutes early, face pale and furious on Eira’s behalf. “This is disgusting.” Eira didn’t ask which part. “Make tea.” Carys made tea aggressively. Customers came in in little waves—some genuine, some curious. Eira could tell the difference by their eyes: readers looked at shelves, not at her. She fielded a dozen small questions that were really one question. No, she hadn’t seen anything. No, she didn’t know. No, she didn’t care. Yes, she had books on Wales. No, she wouldn’t check the back. By noon, her jaw hurt from holding her face steady. At one, the bell rang and Eira looked up ready to be cold. Callum stood in the doorway. Not performing, not smiling. Just there. Hair damp. No beanie. No disguise. Like he’d decided being seen was inevitable and chosen to do it on his own terms. For a second, Eira couldn’t move. Carys made a strangled noise behind the counter. Then she remembered herself and ducked into the back room like she’d been shot. Callum stepped inside and shut the door behind him carefully, quietly, as if the bell were a sleeping animal. Eira’s heart thumped hard enough to make her dizzy. “What are you doing,” she said, and heard the tremor she didn’t want. Callum’s gaze flicked over her face. He didn’t try to soften it with charm. He looked… cautious. Real. “I forgot something,” he said. Eira stared at him. “You didn’t.” Callum’s mouth twitched, almost a smile, then didn’t. “I did.” Eira forced herself to breathe. “What.” He held up a paperback. Her paperback. Eira’s stomach dropped. It was the margin-marked one from her upstairs pile. The one she’d snapped shut on him the first night. “How—” Eira began, then stopped because the answer was obvious. He’d taken it. Because he couldn’t stand leaving without something to hold onto. Because he’d wanted a piece of her that wasn’t permission. Eira’s voice went sharp. “You stole my book.” Callum flinched. “I borrowed it.” “You didn’t ask.” “I know,” he said, voice quiet. “I’m sorry.” Eira felt anger flare, bright and useful. “That’s not—” “I’m sorry,” Callum repeated, and something in his tone stopped her mid-rant. Not a performance. Not a line. A stubborn insistence on saying the only true thing he had. Eira swallowed. “Why are you here.” Callum’s gaze dropped to the counter, to the pile of returns, to the scuffed floor where his rain had puddled. “Because I… left like an idiot.” Eira stared at him. “Yes.” Callum exhaled. “And because I can’t stop thinking about your face in that doorway. Like I’d dragged you into it.” “You did,” Eira said. Callum’s jaw tightened. He nodded once, taking it. “Yeah.” A beat. Eira’s anger began to wobble on its feet. She hated that. She grabbed onto practicality like a rope. “Where did you go.” Callum hesitated. “Bryn’s place was… too obvious. Too many cars. Too easy to spot.” Eira blinked. “Bryn.” Callum’s eyes flicked to hers. “The producer friend. The ‘quiet house.’” “So where,” Eira demanded. Callum rubbed the back of his neck. “A B&B. In Llanbedr.” “That’s forty minutes,” Eira said, incredulous. “Thirty-five,” he corrected, then winced as if he’d just tried to charm her with a fact. He dropped his hand. “I didn’t sleep.” Eira felt an unwanted pinch in her chest. “Why not.” Callum’s gaze lifted, held hers. “Because every time I closed my eyes I could hear your bell.” Eira’s throat tightened. She forced her voice flat. “That’s ridiculous.” Callum’s mouth twitched. “I know. It’s—” He stopped, then let out a breath. “It’s not even about the bell.” Eira stared at him, pulse loud in her ears. “Then what is it about.” Callum opened his mouth.
